Answer: 
The patient presents with symptoms of <fact2>intermittent vertigo</fact2>, <fact4>vomiting</fact4>, and <fact5>complete hearing loss</fact5> in her <fact6>left ear</fact6>, which are indicative of a severe ear infection. The presence of a <fact15>suppurative, erythematous, bulging tympanic membrane</fact15> and <fact16>immobile tympanic membrane</fact16> further supports this diagnosis. Additionally, the patient's <fact19>complete blood count with differential and comprehensive metabolic panel</fact19> shows an elevated <fact22>white blood cell count of 14,500 /mm3</fact22> and <fact24>neutrophil percentage of 81.6%</fact24>, indicating a bacterial infection. Given the severity of the infection and the potential for complications, a broad-spectrum antibiotic is necessary. Among the options provided, <fact>cefotaxime</fact> (option C) is a third-generation cephalosporin with broad-spectrum activity against Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria, including those commonly causing ear infections. Therefore, the most appropriate antibiotic choice for this patient is {C}.

question:
A 38-year-old G4P3 presents to her obstetrician’s office for her 20-week anatomy ultrasound. She reports that she feels well and has not experienced any contractions or vaginal bleeding. She also reports good fetal movement. The patient declined prenatal screening earlier in the pregnancy for religious reasons but would now like an anatomy ultrasound to ensure the fetus is growing appropriately. The patient’s previous pregnancies were uncomplicated, and she delivered three healthy babies at full term. On the ultrasound, the technician observes a male fetus with likely intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR). She also notes microcephaly, convex-rounded feet, and clenched fists with overlapping fingers. The technician further notes a medium-sized ventricular septal defect (VSD). The amniotic fluid index (AFI) is 26 cm.

Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be observed in this fetus?
A) Cleft palate
B) Epicanthal folds
C) Micropthlamia
D) Prominent occiput
E) Webbed neck
answer:
Reformatted Question:

A <fact1>38-year-old G4P3</fact1> presents to her obstetrician’s office for her <fact2>20-week anatomy ultrasound</fact2>. She reports that she feels well and has not experienced any <fact3>contractions or vaginal bleeding</fact3>. She also reports <fact4>good fetal movement</fact4>. The patient declined <fact5>prenatal screening earlier in the pregnancy for religious reasons</fact5> but would now like an <fact2>anatomy ultrasound</fact2> to ensure the fetus is growing appropriately. The patient’s previous pregnancies were uncomplicated, and she delivered three healthy babies at full term. On the <fact2>ultrasound</fact2>, the technician observes a male fetus with likely <fact6>intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR)</fact6>. She also notes <fact7>microcephaly</fact7>, <fact8>convex-rounded feet</fact8>, and <fact9>clenched fists with overlapping fingers</fact9>. The technician further notes a <fact10>medium-sized ventricular septal defect (VSD)</fact10>. The <fact11>amniotic fluid index (AFI) is 26 cm</fact11>.

Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be observed in this fetus?
A) Cleft palate
B) Epicanthal folds
C) Micropthlamia
D) Prominent occiput
E) Webbed neck

Answer: The fetus has been observed with <fact6>intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR)</fact6>, <fact7>microcephaly</fact7>, <fact8>convex-rounded feet</fact8>, <fact9>clenched fists with overlapping fingers</fact9>, and a <fact10>medium-sized ventricular septal defect (VSD)</fact10>, which are all indicative of a chromosomal abnormality. Specifically, these features are commonly associated with Trisomy 18 (Edwards Syndrome). Given the presence of these characteristic findings, it is likely that the fetus also has a <fact4>prominent occiput</fact4>, which is another common feature of Trisomy 18. Therefore, the correct answer is {D}.

question:
Four days after admission to the hospital for pneumonia, a 68-year-old woman develops abdominal pain and watery, foul-smelling diarrhea. Current medications include intravenous ceftriaxone and oral azithromycin. Stool cultures grow gram-positive, anaerobic rods. She is moved to an isolated hospital room. Sterilization with which of the following agents is most likely to prevent transmission of this pathogen to the next patient who will occupy her room?
A) Chlorine-based solution
B) Chlorhexidine-based solution
C) Iodine-based solution
D) Isopropanol-based solution
E) Quaternary amine-based solution
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>68-year-old woman</fact1> develops <fact2>abdominal pain and watery, foul-smelling diarrhea</fact2> four days after admission to the hospital for <fact3>pneumonia</fact3>. Her current medications include <fact4>intravenous ceftriaxone and oral azithromycin</fact4>. Stool cultures grow <fact5>gram-positive, anaerobic rods</fact5>. She is moved to an isolated hospital room. Sterilization with which of the following agents is most likely to prevent transmission of this pathogen to the next patient who will occupy her room? 
A) Chlorine-based solution
B) Chlorhexidine-based solution
C) Iodine-based solution
D) Isopropanol-based solution
E) Quaternary amine-based solution

Answer: The patient's development of <fact2>abdominal pain and watery, foul-smelling diarrhea</fact2> while on <fact4>intravenous ceftriaxone and oral azithromycin</fact4> suggests antibiotic-associated diarrhea, likely caused by Clostridioides difficile, a gram-positive, anaerobic rod as indicated by the <fact5>stool cultures</fact5>. To prevent transmission of this pathogen, effective sterilization of the hospital room is crucial. Among the options provided, a <fact6>chlorine-based solution</fact6> is the most effective agent against C. difficile spores. Therefore, the answer is {A}.

question:
An 18-year-old male is brought in by fire rescue. The patient was an unrestrained passenger in a motor vehicle crash and was ejected from the vehicle after collision. Upon arrival to the trauma bay, the patient has a Glasgow coma scale (GCS) of 6. He is rapidly intubated, and vitals are a temperature of 99.5°F (37.5°C), pulse of 130 bpm, and blood pressure of 83/64 mmHg. He is noted to have multiple ecchymoses over his body, as well as petechiae and purpura. He has a laceration over his clavicle that continues to bleed despite a pressure bandage. Radiographs of his lower extremity show multiple long bone fractures. Two large bore IV lines are placed, and the patient oozes from around the sites of venepuncture. Labs are notable for a WBC of 20,000/mm^3, Hb of 10.1g/dL, platelets of 48,000/mm^3, and prolongation of the PT and aPTT. This patient's presentation can best be explained by which of the following diagnoses?
A) Fat embolization
B) Air embolization
C) Tension pneumothorax
D) Disseminated intravascular coagulation
E) Coagulopathy of trauma
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
An <fact1>18-year-old male</fact1> is brought in by fire rescue. The patient was an <fact2>unrestrained passenger in a motor vehicle crash</fact2> and was <fact3>ejected from the vehicle after collision</fact3>. Upon arrival to the trauma bay, the patient has a <fact4>Glasgow coma scale (GCS) of 6</fact4>. He is rapidly intubated, and vitals are a <fact5>temperature of 99.5°F (37.5°C)</fact5>, <fact6>pulse of 130 bpm</fact6>, and <fact7>blood pressure of 83/64 mmHg</fact7>. He is noted to have <fact8>multiple ecchymoses over his body</fact8>, as well as <fact9>petechiae and purpura</fact9>. He has a <fact10>laceration over his clavicle that continues to bleed despite a pressure bandage</fact10>. Radiographs of his lower extremity show <fact11>multiple long bone fractures</fact11>. Two large bore IV lines are placed, and the patient <fact12>oozes from around the sites of venepuncture</fact12>. Labs are notable for a <fact13>WBC of 20,000/mm^3</fact13>, <fact14>Hb of 10.1g/dL</fact14>, <fact15>platelets of 48,000/mm^3</fact15>, and <fact16>prolongation of the PT and aPTT</fact16>. This patient's presentation can best be explained by which of the following diagnoses?

A) Fat embolization
B) Air embolization
C) Tension pneumothorax
D) Disseminated intravascular coagulation
E) Coagulopathy of trauma

Answer: 
Considering the patient's presentation, including the <fact2>unrestrained passenger in a motor vehicle crash</fact2> and <fact3>ejection from the vehicle</fact3>, leading to severe trauma, the patient's symptoms such as <fact8>multiple ecchymoses</fact8>, <fact9>petechiae and purpura</fact9>, <fact10>continued bleeding from a laceration</fact10>, and <fact12>oozing from venepuncture sites</fact12> are indicative of a coagulopathy. The laboratory findings of <fact15>thrombocytopenia</fact15> and <fact16>prolongation of PT and aPTT</fact16> further support this diagnosis. The patient's severe trauma and evidence of coagulopathy are most consistent with {E} Coagulopathy of trauma.

question:
A 25-year-old man with a past medical history of constipation and fibromyalgia presents to the emergency department with generalized malaise and severe diarrhea. The patient states that he has not felt well for the past 24 hours and his symptoms are no longer tolerable. He denies taking any medications or illicit drugs and states he is generally healthy. His temperature is 99.3°F (37.4°C), blood pressure is 122/88 mmHg, pulse is 107/min, respirations are 19/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical exam demonstrates an ill appearing young man. Physical exam is notable for rhinorrhea, lacrimation, and piloerection. The patient’s pupils are dilated and reactive to light. During placement of an ultrasound guided IV, multiple scars are noted in the antecubital fossa, and it is noted that it is very difficult to place an IV in this patient. During the exam, he begins actively vomiting. Which of the following could be an appropriate treatment for this patient’s symptoms?
A) Clonidine
B) Diazepam taper
C) Haloperidol and diphenhydramine
D) Naloxone
E) Oseltamivir
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>25-year-old man</fact1> with a past medical history of <fact2>constipation and fibromyalgia</fact2> presents to the emergency department with <fact3>generalized malaise and severe diarrhea</fact3>. The patient states that he has not felt well for the past <fact4>24 hours</fact4> and his symptoms are no longer tolerable. He denies taking any medications or illicit drugs and states he is generally healthy. His <fact5>temperature is 99.3°F (37.4°C)</fact5>, <fact6>blood pressure is 122/88 mmHg</fact6>, <fact7>pulse is 107/min</fact7>, <fact8>respirations are 19/min</fact8>, and <fact9>oxygen saturation is 99% on room air</fact9>. Physical exam demonstrates an <fact10>ill appearing young man</fact10>. Physical exam is notable for <fact11>rhinorrhea, lacrimation, and piloerection</fact11>. The patient’s <fact12>pupils are dilated and reactive to light</fact12>. During placement of an ultrasound guided IV, <fact13>multiple scars are noted in the antecubital fossa</fact13>, and it is noted that it is very difficult to place an IV in this patient. During the exam, he begins <fact14>actively vomiting</fact14>. Which of the following could be an appropriate treatment for this patient’s symptoms?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's symptoms of <fact3>generalized malaise and severe diarrhea</fact3>, along with <fact11>rhinorrhea, lacrimation, and piloerection</fact11> and <fact12>dilated pupils</fact12>, these signs are indicative of opioid withdrawal. Additionally, the presence of <fact13>multiple scars in the antecubital fossa</fact13> suggests a history of intravenous drug use. The patient's <fact14>active vomiting</fact14> further supports the diagnosis of opioid withdrawal. In this case, an appropriate treatment for the patient's symptoms would be a medication that can help alleviate the symptoms of opioid withdrawal. Among the options provided, Clonidine is often used to manage the symptoms of opioid withdrawal, including diarrhea, nausea, and vomiting. Therefore, the answer is {A}.

question:
A 28-year-old primigravid woman at 39 weeks gestation is admitted to the hospital in active labor. On examination, the cervix is 100% effaced and 10 cm dilated. After 5 minutes of pushing, there is a prolonged deceleration of the fetal heart rate to 90/min. A decision to perform an episiotomy is made to expedite vaginal delivery. The anesthesiologist locates the ischial spines by palpating the posterolateral vaginal sidewall and administers an anesthetic. Three minutes later, pinching the posterior vulva does not provoke pain. The anesthetized nerve most likely also supplies which of the following structures?
A) Obturator externus muscle
B) Skin of the lateral thigh
C) External anal sphincter
D) Skin of the mons pubis
E) Detrusor muscle
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>28-year-old primigravid woman</fact1> at <fact2>39 weeks gestation</fact2> is admitted to the hospital in active labor. On examination, the cervix is <fact3>100% effaced and 10 cm dilated</fact3>. After <fact4>5 minutes of pushing</fact4>, there is a prolonged deceleration of the <fact5>fetal heart rate to 90/min</fact5>. A decision to perform an <fact6>episiotomy</fact6> is made to expedite vaginal delivery. The anesthesiologist locates the <fact7>ischial spines</fact7> by palpating the <fact8>posterolateral vaginal sidewall</fact8> and administers an anesthetic. Three minutes later, pinching the <fact9>posterior vulva</fact9> does not provoke pain. The anesthetized nerve most likely also supplies which of the following structures?

Answer: 
The anesthesiologist administered an anesthetic after locating the <fact7>ischial spines</fact7> by palpating the <fact8>posterolateral vaginal sidewall</fact8>, which is indicative of a pudendal nerve block. The pudendal nerve supplies the muscles and skin of the perineum, including the <fact9>posterior vulva</fact9>. Among the options provided, the pudendal nerve also supplies the <fact10>external anal sphincter</fact10>. Therefore, the correct answer is {C}.

question:
A 45-year-old woman comes to the physician with a lump on her throat that has steadily increased in size over the past 5 months. She does not have difficulties swallowing, dyspnea, or changes in voice. Examination shows a 3-cm, hard swelling on the left side of her neck that moves with swallowing. There is no cervical or axillary lymphadenopathy. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Thyroid functions tests are within the reference range. Ultrasound of the neck shows an irregular, hypoechogenic mass in the left lobe of the thyroid. A fine-needle aspiration biopsy is inconclusive. The surgeon and patient agree that the most appropriate next step is a diagnostic lobectomy and isthmectomy. Surgery shows a 3.5-cm gray tan thyroid tumor with invasion of surrounding blood vessels, including the veins. The specimen is sent for histopathological examination. Which of the following is most likely to be seen on microscopic examination of the mass?
A) Undifferentiated giant cells
B) Capsular invasion
C) Psammoma bodies
D) Infiltration of atypical lymphoid tissue
E) Orphan Annie nuclei
"
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>45-year-old woman</fact1> comes to the physician with a <fact2>lump on her throat that has steadily increased in size over the past 5 months</fact2>. She does not have <fact3>difficulties swallowing, dyspnea, or changes in voice</fact3>. Examination shows a <fact4>3-cm, hard swelling on the left side of her neck that moves with swallowing</fact4>. There is no <fact5>cervical or axillary lymphadenopathy</fact5>. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. <fact6>Thyroid functions tests are within the reference range</fact6>. Ultrasound of the neck shows an <fact7>irregular, hypoechogenic mass in the left lobe of the thyroid</fact7>. A fine-needle aspiration biopsy is inconclusive. The surgeon and patient agree that the most appropriate next step is a diagnostic lobectomy and isthmectomy. Surgery shows a <fact8>3.5-cm gray tan thyroid tumor with invasion of surrounding blood vessels, including the veins</fact8>. The specimen is sent for histopathological examination. Which of the following is most likely to be seen on microscopic examination of the mass?
A) Undifferentiated giant cells
B) Capsular invasion
C) Psammoma bodies
D) Infiltration of atypical lymphoid tissue
E) Orphan Annie nuclei

Answer: 
Given the information provided in the question, the key findings that guide the diagnosis are the presence of a <fact4>3-cm, hard swelling on the left side of her neck that moves with swallowing</fact4> and the <fact8>3.5-cm gray tan thyroid tumor with invasion of surrounding blood vessels, including the veins</fact8> found during surgery. These findings, along with the <fact7>irregular, hypoechogenic mass in the left lobe of the thyroid</fact7> observed on ultrasound, suggest an aggressive thyroid tumor. Among the options provided, the most characteristic microscopic feature of a thyroid malignancy that matches the description given is <fact8>capsular invasion</fact8>, which is a hallmark of papillary thyroid carcinoma, but more indicative of follicular thyroid carcinoma given the lack of other distinctive features of papillary carcinoma like psammoma bodies or Orphan Annie nuclei. However, the invasion of blood vessels further supports the diagnosis of follicular carcinoma, which is known for its tendency to invade blood vessels. Therefore, the best answer is {B}.

question:
An investigator is studying the pattern of glutamate release from presynaptic nerve terminals in human volunteers with Alzheimer disease. The concentration of glutamate in the CA1 region of the hippocampus is measured using magnetic resonance spectroscopy after Schaffer collateral fibers are electrically stimulated. Which of the following events most likely occurs immediately prior to the release of neurotransmitters?
A) Activation of G protein-coupled receptors
B) Synthesis of glutamine
C) Accumulation of cAMP
D) Opening of ligand-gated ion channels
E) Influx of calcium
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
An investigator is studying the pattern of <fact1>glutamate release</fact1> from <fact2>presynaptic nerve terminals</fact2> in human volunteers with Alzheimer disease. The concentration of <fact3>glutamate</fact3> in the <fact4>CA1 region of the hippocampus</fact4> is measured using <fact5>magnetic resonance spectroscopy</fact5> after <fact6>Schaffer collateral fibers</fact6> are electrically stimulated. Which of the following events most likely occurs immediately prior to the <fact7>release of neurotransmitters</fact7>?

A) Activation of G protein-coupled receptors
B) Synthesis of glutamine
C) Accumulation of cAMP
D) Opening of ligand-gated ion channels
E) Influx of calcium

Answer: E) Influx of calcium

Explanation: 
The question asks about the event that occurs immediately prior to the <fact7>release of neurotransmitters</fact7> in the context of <fact1>glutamate release</fact1> from <fact2>presynaptic nerve terminals</fact2> in Alzheimer disease. Given that the concentration of <fact3>glutamate</fact3> is measured in the <fact4>CA1 region of the hippocampus</fact4> using <fact5>magnetic resonance spectroscopy</fact5> after <fact6>Schaffer collateral fibers</fact6> are electrically stimulated, the focus is on the neural mechanisms involved in neurotransmitter release. Among the options, the <fact8>influx of calcium</fact8> is the critical event that triggers the release of neurotransmitters from the presynaptic terminal. When an action potential reaches the presynaptic terminal, voltage-gated calcium channels open, allowing an influx of calcium ions. This increase in intracellular calcium triggers the fusion of vesicles containing neurotransmitters with the presynaptic membrane, leading to the release of neurotransmitters into the synaptic cleft.

question:
A 31-year-old woman comes to the physician because of dragging pelvic pain and a 3 kg (6 lb 9 oz) weight loss over the past 6 months. Menses occur at irregular 30- to 45-day intervals; her last menstrual period was 5 weeks ago. Her temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), heart rate is 102/min, and blood pressure is 128/84 mm Hg. Physical examination shows hyperreflexia. Urine pregnancy test is negative. Ultrasonography shows a 6-cm hypoechoic adnexal mass. This adnexal mass is most likely derived from which of the following cell types?
A) Ovarian epithelial cells
B) Germ cells
C) Chorionic epithelial cells
D) Endometrial cells
E) Stromal cells
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>31-year-old woman</fact1> comes to the physician because of <fact2>dragging pelvic pain</fact2> and a <fact3>3 kg (6 lb 9 oz) weight loss</fact3> over the past <fact4>6 months</fact4>. Menses occur at irregular <fact5>30- to 45-day intervals</fact5>; her last menstrual period was <fact6>5 weeks ago</fact6>. Her <fact7>temperature is 38°C (100.4°F)</fact7>, <fact8>heart rate is 102/min</fact8>, and <fact9>blood pressure is 128/84 mm Hg</fact9>. Physical examination shows <fact10>hyperreflexia</fact10>. Urine pregnancy test is <fact11>negative</fact11>. Ultrasonography shows a <fact12>6-cm hypoechoic adnexal mass</fact12>. This adnexal mass is most likely derived from which of the following cell types?

Answer: Considering the patient's presentation, including <fact2>dragging pelvic pain</fact2>, <fact3>weight loss</fact3>, and <fact12>ultrasonography showing a 6-cm hypoechoic adnexal mass</fact12>, along with <fact11>negative urine pregnancy test</fact11>, suggests that the mass is likely related to an ovarian pathology rather than pregnancy. Among the provided options, ovarian epithelial cells are the most common origin of ovarian neoplasms, which can present as adnexal masses. The patient's <fact5>irregular menstrual cycles</fact5> and <fact7>temperature</fact7> may also be related to hormonal effects of the tumor. Therefore, the adnexal mass is most likely derived from {A} ovarian epithelial cells.

question:
A 51-year-old woman goes to respiratory function testing in order to evaluate her shortness of breath. She recently joined a walking program with her friends in order to lose weight; however, she noticed that she was not able to keep up with her friends during the program. She has a 60-pack-year history of smoking as well as hypertension well-controlled on medication. The following represent the parameters for this patient's respiratory anatomy and function:

Vital capacity (VC): 5,000 mL
Inspiratory reserve volume (IRV): 2,500 mL
Functional reserve capacity (FRC): 2,700 mL
Residual volume (RV): 1,000 mL
Upper airway volume: 100 mL
Conducting airway volume: 125 mL

Inspired CO2 pressure (PiCO2): 1 mmHg
Arterial CO2 pressure (PaCO2): 50 mmHg
Expired CO2 pressure (PeCO2): 20 mmHg

Which of the following best represents the total volume of gas in this patient's airways and lungs that does not participate in gas exchange?
A) 225 mL
B) 480 mL
C) 600 mL
D) 800 mL
E) 1200 mL
answer:
Reformatted Question: 

A 51-year-old woman goes to respiratory function testing in order to evaluate her <fact1>shortness of breath</fact1>. She recently joined a walking program with her friends in order to lose weight; however, she noticed that she was not able to keep up with her friends during the program. She has a <fact2>60-pack-year history of smoking</fact2> as well as <fact3>hypertension well-controlled on medication</fact3>. The following represent the parameters for this patient's respiratory anatomy and function:

<fact4>Vital capacity (VC): 5,000 mL</fact4>
<fact5>Inspiratory reserve volume (IRV): 2,500 mL</fact5>
<fact6>Functional reserve capacity (FRC): 2,700 mL</fact6>
<fact7>Residual volume (RV): 1,000 mL</fact7>
<fact8>Upper airway volume: 100 mL</fact8>
<fact9>Conducting airway volume: 125 mL</fact9>

<fact10>Inspired CO2 pressure (PiCO2): 1 mmHg</fact10>
<fact11>Arterial CO2 pressure (PaCO2): 50 mmHg</fact11>
<fact12>Expired CO2 pressure (PeCO2): 20 mmHg</fact12>

Which of the following best represents the total volume of gas in this patient's airways and lungs that does not participate in gas exchange?

Answer: The total volume of gas in the airways and lungs that does not participate in gas exchange is represented by the anatomical dead space. This includes the volume of the upper airway and the conducting airway. Therefore, the total volume of gas that does not participate in gas exchange is the sum of the <fact8>upper airway volume</fact8> and the <fact9>conducting airway volume</fact9>, which is 100 mL + 125 mL = 225 mL.

question:
A 58-year-old African American man presents for his yearly wellness visit. He says he has been unsuccessful at losing weight and would like help. His last colonoscopy was 8 years previously, which was normal. Past medical history is significant for obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) and hypertension. Current medications are isosorbide dinitrate/hydralazine and aspirin 81 mg orally daily. He is also on CPAP to manage his OSA. The patient denies any history of smoking or recreational drug use and drinks 1 or 2 beers on weekends. Family history is significant for prostate cancer in his father and hypertension and diabetes mellitus type 2 in his mother. His vital signs include: temperature 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse 97/min, respiratory rate 16/min, blood pressure 120/75 mm Hg. BMI is 30 kg/m2. Physical examination is unremarkable. Fasting blood glucose is 90 mg/dL. Which of the following preventative screening tests would be most appropriate for this patient at this time?
A) PSA
B) Digital rectal exam
C) HbA1C
D) Abdominal ultrasound
E) Flexible sigmoidoscopy
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>58-year-old African American man</fact1> presents for his yearly wellness visit. He says he has been unsuccessful at losing weight and would like help. His <fact2>last colonoscopy was 8 years previously, which was normal</fact2>. Past medical history is significant for <fact3>obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) and hypertension</fact3>. Current medications are isosorbide dinitrate/hydralazine and aspirin 81 mg orally daily. He is also on CPAP to manage his <fact3>OSA</fact3>. The patient denies any history of smoking or recreational drug use and drinks 1 or 2 beers on weekends. <fact4>Family history is significant for prostate cancer in his father</fact4> and <fact5>hypertension and diabetes mellitus type 2 in his mother</fact5>. His vital signs include: temperature 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse 97/min, respiratory rate 16/min, blood pressure 120/75 mm Hg. <fact6>BMI is 30 kg/m2</fact6>. Physical examination is unremarkable. <fact7>Fasting blood glucose is 90 mg/dL</fact7>. Which of the following preventative screening tests would be most appropriate for this patient at this time?
A) PSA
B) Digital rectal exam
C) HbA1C
D) Abdominal ultrasound
E) Flexible sigmoidoscopy

Answer: 
Considering the patient's <fact1>age</fact1> and <fact4>family history of prostate cancer</fact4>, the most appropriate preventative screening test would be the Prostate-Specific Antigen (PSA) test. Although the patient's <fact7>fasting blood glucose</fact7> is within the normal range, his <fact5>family history of diabetes mellitus type 2</fact5> and <fact6>BMI of 30 kg/m2</fact6> indicate a risk for developing diabetes; however, the PSA test takes precedence given his age and family history of prostate cancer. Therefore, the answer is {A}.

question:
A 45-year-old female presents to the emergency department with gross hematuria and acute, colicky flank pain. She denies any previous episodes of hematuria. She reports taking high doses of acetaminophen and aspirin over several weeks due to persistent upper back pain. The patient’s blood pressure and temperature are normal, but she is found to have proteinuria. Physical examination is negative for palpable flank masses. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis:
A) Diffuse cortical necrosis
B) Chronic pyelonephritis
C) Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease
D) Papillary necrosis
E) Acute Nephrolithiasis
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>45-year-old female</fact1> presents to the emergency department with <fact2>gross hematuria</fact2> and <fact3>acute, colicky flank pain</fact3>. She denies any previous episodes of <fact2>hematuria</fact2>. She reports taking <fact4>high doses of acetaminophen and aspirin</fact4> over several weeks due to persistent <fact5>upper back pain</fact5>. The patient’s <fact6>blood pressure and temperature are normal</fact6>, but she is found to have <fact7>proteinuria</fact7>. Physical examination is <fact8>negative for palpable flank masses</fact8>. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's presentation with <fact2>gross hematuria</fact2> and <fact3>acute, colicky flank pain</fact3>, along with the absence of previous episodes of <fact2>hematuria</fact2> and the presence of <fact7>proteinuria</fact7>, several differential diagnoses could be considered. However, the key piece of information is the patient's history of taking <fact4>high doses of acetaminophen and aspirin</fact4> over several weeks due to persistent <fact5>upper back pain</fact5>. This suggests a possible analgesic nephropathy, which can lead to papillary necrosis. The <fact6>normal blood pressure and temperature</fact6> help to rule out some other conditions. The <fact8>negative physical examination for palpable flank masses</fact8> also points away from conditions like <fact3>chronic pyelonephritis</fact3> or <fact3>autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease</fact3>. Given these factors, the most likely diagnosis is {D} Papillary necrosis.

question:
A 62-year-old man comes to the physician because of worsening involuntary movements of both arms for the past 7 months. He reports that certain daily activities have become more difficult to perform. His father had a similar condition that was treated with medications. The patient appears anxious. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a low-amplitude tremor bilaterally when the arms are outstretched that worsens when reaching out to grab a pen. Muscle strength and tone is normal bilaterally. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. On mental status examination, his mood is good. His speech is normal in rate and rhythm. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
A) Deep brain stimulation
B) Thalamotomy
C) Levodopa and carbidopa therapy
D) Clonazepam therapy
E) Propranolol therapy
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>62-year-old man</fact1> comes to the physician because of <fact2>worsening involuntary movements of both arms</fact2> for the past <fact3>7 months</fact3>. He reports that <fact4>certain daily activities have become more difficult to perform</fact4>. His <fact5>father had a similar condition</fact5> that was treated with medications. The patient appears anxious. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a <fact6>low-amplitude tremor bilaterally</fact6> when the arms are outstretched that worsens when reaching out to grab a pen. Muscle strength and tone is normal bilaterally. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. On mental status examination, his mood is good. His speech is normal in rate and rhythm. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's <fact2>worsening involuntary movements of both arms</fact2> and a <fact5>family history of a similar condition</fact5>, the most likely diagnosis is essential tremor, a condition that often presents with a <fact6>low-amplitude tremor</fact6> that worsens with action. Given the impact on <fact4>certain daily activities</fact4>, treatment is warranted. Among the options provided, propranolol is a commonly used medication for the treatment of essential tremor. Therefore, the most appropriate next step in management is {E} Propranolol therapy.

question:
A 68-year-old man presents with a 6-month history of worsening fatigue and weight loss. He is especially concerned about a recent episode in which he noticed a blurring of his vision and headache; he also notes that his “memory is not as good as it used to be,” which his wife confirms. Physical exam is notable only for pallor and general weakness. Laboratory studies reveal anemia as well as an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate. Serum protein electrophoresis (SPEP) reveals a sharp, narrow spike of monoclonal IgM; serum IgM concentration is 6.3 g/dL. What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
A) IgM monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS)
B) Multiple myeloma
C) Waldenstrom’s macroglobulinemia
D) Non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma
E) Chronic lymphocytic leukemia
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>68-year-old man</fact1> presents with a <fact2>6-month history of worsening fatigue and weight loss</fact2>. He is especially concerned about a recent episode in which he noticed a <fact3>blurring of his vision and headache</fact3>; he also notes that his <fact4>“memory is not as good as it used to be,”</fact4> which his wife confirms. Physical exam is notable only for <fact5>pallor and general weakness</fact5>. Laboratory studies reveal <fact6>anemia</fact6> as well as an <fact7>elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate</fact7>. Serum protein electrophoresis (SPEP) reveals a <fact8>sharp, narrow spike of monoclonal IgM</fact8>; serum IgM concentration is <fact9>6.3 g/dL</fact9>. What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?

Answer: 
Analyzing the patient's symptoms, including a <fact2>6-month history of worsening fatigue and weight loss</fact2>, a recent episode of <fact3>blurring of his vision and headache</fact3>, and decreased memory (<fact4>“memory is not as good as it used to be”</fact4>), alongside laboratory findings of <fact6>anemia</fact6> and an <fact7>elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate</fact7>, points towards a hematological disorder. The presence of a <fact8>sharp, narrow spike of monoclonal IgM</fact8> on serum protein electrophoresis (SPEP) and a significantly elevated serum IgM concentration of <fact9>6.3 g/dL</fact9> are characteristic of a lymphoproliferative disorder. Given these findings, the most likely diagnosis is Waldenstrom’s macroglobulinemia, a condition characterized by the proliferation of malignant lymphoplasmacytic cells that produce monoclonal IgM. This diagnosis is supported by the patient's symptoms, such as blurred vision and headaches, which can be attributed to the hyperviscosity syndrome associated with high levels of IgM. Therefore, the answer is {C}.

question:
A group of researchers wants to evaluate how often the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) is related to high-risk behaviors in female sex workers from their country. An additional aim is to evaluate the association between HIV acquisition and certain sociodemographic factors. The researchers collect data through interviewer-administered questionnaires (for behavioral and sociodemographic data) as well as through clinical and serological evaluation/screening methods for HIV and other sexually transmitted infections. Which of the following could be the main outcome measure of their study?
A) Incidence
B) Prevalence
C) Hazard rate
D) Relative risk
E) Attributable risk
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A group of researchers wants to evaluate how often the <fact1>human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)</fact1> is related to <fact2>high-risk behaviors</fact2> in <fact3>female sex workers</fact3> from their country. An additional aim is to evaluate the association between <fact4>HIV acquisition</fact4> and certain <fact5>sociodemographic factors</fact5>. The researchers collect data through <fact6>interviewer-administered questionnaires</fact6> (for <fact7>behavioral</fact7> and <fact8>sociodemographic data</fact8>) as well as through <fact9>clinical and serological evaluation/screening methods</fact9> for <fact1>HIV</fact1> and other <fact10>sexually transmitted infections</fact10>. Which of the following could be the main outcome measure of their study?

Answer: 
The main outcome measure of this study could be the <fact4>HIV acquisition</fact4> among <fact3>female sex workers</fact3>, which is related to <fact2>high-risk behaviors</fact2> and certain <fact5>sociodemographic factors</fact5>. Since the study aims to evaluate how often <fact1>HIV</fact1> is related to these factors, the outcome measure should reflect the frequency or proportion of <fact1>HIV</fact1> cases among the study population. Among the options provided, <fact11>prevalence</fact11> is the most suitable outcome measure, as it represents the total number of <fact1>HIV</fact1> cases present in the study population at a given time or over a period. Therefore, the answer is {B}.

question:
A 63-year-old patient presents to the emergency department because of severe left leg pain and tingling. His condition started suddenly 30 minutes ago. He has had hypertension for the past 10 years for which he takes bisoprolol. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.7°F), the blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg, and the pulse is 100/min and irregular. On physical examination, the patient appears in severe pain and his left leg is pale and cool. The popliteal pulse is weaker on the left side compared to the right side. Which of the following is the most common cause of this patient's condition?
A) Vasculitis
B) Hyperhomocysteinemia
C) Arterial thrombosis
D) Arterial emboli
E) Arterial trauma
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>63-year-old patient</fact1> presents to the emergency department because of <fact2>severe left leg pain and tingling</fact2>. His condition started <fact3>suddenly 30 minutes ago</fact3>. He has had <fact4>hypertension for the past 10 years</fact4> for which he takes bisoprolol. He does not <fact5>smoke or drink alcohol</fact5>. His <fact6>temperature is 37.1°C (98.7°F)</fact6>, the <fact7>blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg</fact7>, and the <fact8>pulse is 100/min and irregular</fact8>. On physical examination, the patient appears in <fact9>severe pain</fact9> and his <fact10>left leg is pale and cool</fact10>. The <fact11>popliteal pulse is weaker on the left side compared to the right side</fact11>. Which of the following is the most common cause of this patient's condition?
A) Vasculitis
B) Hyperhomocysteinemia
C) Arterial thrombosis
D) Arterial emboli
E) Arterial trauma

Answer: Analyzing the patient's presentation, the <fact1>63-year-old patient</fact1> with <fact2>severe left leg pain and tingling</fact2> that started <fact3>suddenly 30 minutes ago</fact3> suggests an acute vascular event. The patient's history of <fact4>hypertension for the past 10 years</fact4> increases his risk for cardiovascular disease. The physical examination findings of a <fact10>pale and cool left leg</fact10> and a <fact11>weaker popliteal pulse on the left side</fact11> indicate impaired blood flow to the left leg. Given the sudden onset and the patient's irregular <fact8>pulse</fact8>, the most likely cause is an <fact12>embolic event</fact12>. Therefore, the answer is {D}.

question:
A 25-year-old male is hospitalized for acute agitation, photophobia, and dysphagia. His parents report that he has been experiencing flu-like symptoms for one week prior to hospital admission. Five weeks ago, the patient was in Mexico, where he went on several spelunking expeditions with friends. The patient ultimately becomes comatose and dies. Autopsy of brain tissue suggests a viral infection. The likely causal virus spreads to the central nervous system (CNS) in the following manner:
A) Hematogenous dissemination to the meninges
B) Entrance via cribiform plate
C) Retrograde migration up peripheral nerve axons
D) Reactivation of virus previously latent in dorsal root ganglia
E) Infection of oligodendrocytes and astrocytes
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>25-year-old male</fact1> is hospitalized for <fact2>acute agitation, photophobia, and dysphagia</fact2>. His parents report that he has been experiencing <fact3>flu-like symptoms</fact3> for one week prior to hospital admission. Five weeks ago, the patient was in <fact4>Mexico</fact4>, where he went on several <fact5>spelunking expeditions</fact5> with friends. The patient ultimately becomes comatose and dies. Autopsy of <fact6>brain tissue</fact6> suggests a <fact7> viral infection</fact7>. The likely causal virus spreads to the central nervous system (CNS) in the following manner:

Answer: 
Given the patient's symptoms of <fact2>acute agitation, photophobia, and dysphagia</fact2> and the fact that he went on <fact5>spelunking expeditions</fact5> in <fact4>Mexico</fact4>, it is likely that he contracted a viral infection that is transmitted through an animal vector commonly found in caves, such as bats. The virus that fits this description is rabies. Rabies virus spreads to the central nervous system (CNS) through <fact8>retrograde migration up peripheral nerve axons</fact8>. This occurs after the virus is introduced into the body through a bite or scratch from an infected animal, allowing it to travel up the nerve axons to the CNS. Therefore, the correct answer is {C}.

question:
A 24-year-old G2P1 woman at 39 weeks’ gestation presents to the emergency department complaining of painful contractions occurring every 10 minutes for the past 2 hours, consistent with latent labor. She says she has not experienced vaginal discharge, bleeding, or fluid leakage, and is currently taking no medications. On physical examination, her blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg, heart rate is 86/min, and temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F). She has had little prenatal care and uses condoms inconsistently. Her sexually transmitted infections status is unknown. As part of the patient’s workup, she undergoes a series of rapid screening tests that result in the administration of zidovudine during delivery. The infant is also given zidovudine to reduce the risk of transmission. A confirmatory test is then performed in the mother to confirm the diagnosis of HIV. Which of the following is most true about the confirmatory test?
A) It determines the genotype of the virus
B) It is a Southwestern blot, identifying the presence of DNA-binding proteins
C) It is a Northern blot, identifying the presence of RNA
D) It is a Northern blot, identifying the presence of DNA
E) It is an HIV-1/HIV2 antibody differentiation immunoassay
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>24-year-old G2P1 woman</fact1> at <fact2>39 weeks’ gestation</fact2> presents to the emergency department complaining of <fact3>painful contractions</fact3> occurring every 10 minutes for the past 2 hours, consistent with latent labor. She says she has not experienced <fact4>vaginal discharge, bleeding, or fluid leakage</fact4>, and is currently taking no medications. On physical examination, her <fact5>blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg, heart rate is 86/min, and temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F)</fact5>. She has had <fact6>little prenatal care</fact6> and uses <fact7>condoms inconsistently</fact7>. Her <fact8>sexually transmitted infections status is unknown</fact8>. As part of the patient’s workup, she undergoes a series of <fact9>rapid screening tests</fact9> that result in the administration of <fact10>zidovudine during delivery</fact10>. The infant is also given <fact10>zidovudine</fact10> to reduce the risk of transmission. A <fact11>confirmatory test</fact11> is then performed in the mother to confirm the diagnosis of <fact12>HIV</fact12>. Which of the following is most true about the <fact11>confirmatory test</fact11>?
A) It determines the genotype of the virus
B) It is a Southwestern blot, identifying the presence of DNA-binding proteins
C) It is a Northern blot, identifying the presence of RNA
D) It is a Northern blot, identifying the presence of DNA
E) It is an HIV-1/HIV2 antibody differentiation immunoassay

Answer: 
Considering the patient underwent <fact9>rapid screening tests</fact9> that resulted in the administration of <fact10>zidovudine</fact10> during delivery, it is clear that the screening tests were positive for <fact12>HIV</fact12>. The <fact11>confirmatory test</fact11> performed to confirm the diagnosis of <fact12>HIV</fact12> is most likely to be an HIV-1/HIV2 antibody differentiation immunoassay. This type of test is used to confirm the presence of HIV antibodies in the blood and differentiate between HIV-1 and HIV-2 infections. Therefore, the correct answer is {E}.

question:
A 68-year-old man comes to the physician with a 1-week history of painless hematuria. A CT scan of the urinary tract shows areas of bladder wall thickening. Cystoscopy shows several sessile masses with central necrosis arising from the bladder wall. A biopsy specimen of the bladder masses shows moderately differentiated urothelial cells with abundant mitotic figures and nuclear atypia. The patient most likely has a history of exposure to which of the following?
A) Ionizing radiation
B) Aromatic amines
C) Aflatoxins
D) Vinyl chloride
E) Radon
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>68-year-old man</fact1> comes to the physician with a <fact2>1-week history of painless hematuria</fact2>. A <fact3>CT scan of the urinary tract</fact3> shows <fact4>areas of bladder wall thickening</fact4>. <fact5>Cystoscopy</fact5> shows <fact6>several sessile masses with central necrosis arising from the bladder wall</fact6>. A <fact7>biopsy specimen of the bladder masses</fact7> shows <fact8>moderately differentiated urothelial cells with abundant mitotic figures and nuclear atypia</fact8>. The patient most likely has a history of exposure to which of the following?

Answer: Based on the patient's presentation with <fact2>painless hematuria</fact2> and the findings of <fact4>bladder wall thickening</fact4> and <fact6>sessile masses with central necrosis arising from the bladder wall</fact6> during <fact3>CT scan of the urinary tract</fact3> and <fact5>cystoscopy</fact5>, respectively, the diagnosis of bladder cancer is likely. The <fact7>biopsy specimen</fact7> showing <fact8>moderately differentiated urothelial cells with abundant mitotic figures and nuclear atypia</fact8> supports this diagnosis. Urothelial cancer is a type of bladder cancer that has been linked to exposure to certain chemicals. Among the options provided, <fact9>aromatic amines</fact9> are a known risk factor for bladder cancer, particularly urothelial cancer. Therefore, the patient most likely has a history of exposure to {B} aromatic amines.

question:
A 60-year-old man presents to the office for shortness of breath. The shortness of breath started a year ago and is exacerbated by physical activity. He has been working in the glass manufacturing industry for 20 years. His vital signs include: heart rate 72/min, respiratory rate 30/min, and blood pressure 130/80 mm Hg. On physical exam, there are diminished respiratory sounds on both sides. On the chest radiograph, interstitial fibrosis with reticulonodular infiltrate is found on both sides, and there is also an eggshell calcification of multiple adenopathies. What is the most likely diagnosis?
A) Berylliosis
B) Silicosis
C) Asbestosis
D) Talcosis
E) Byssinosis
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>60-year-old man</fact1> presents to the office for <fact2>shortness of breath</fact2>. The <fact2>shortness of breath</fact2> started <fact3>a year ago</fact3> and is exacerbated by <fact4>physical activity</fact4>. He has been working in the <fact5>glass manufacturing industry</fact5> for <fact6>20 years</fact6>. His vital signs include: <fact7>heart rate 72/min</fact7>, <fact8>respiratory rate 30/min</fact8>, and <fact9>blood pressure 130/80 mm Hg</fact9>. On physical exam, there are <fact10>diminished respiratory sounds on both sides</fact10>. On the chest radiograph, <fact11>interstitial fibrosis with reticulonodular infiltrate</fact11> is found on both sides, and there is also an <fact12>eggshell calcification of multiple adenopathies</fact12>. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's symptoms of <fact2>shortness of breath</fact2> that started <fact3>a year ago</fact3> and worsen with <fact4>physical activity</fact4>, along with his prolonged exposure to the <fact5>glass manufacturing industry</fact5> for <fact6>20 years</fact6>, suggests an occupational lung disease. The presence of <fact11>interstitial fibrosis with reticulonodular infiltrate</fact11> and <fact12>eggshell calcification of multiple adenopathies</fact12> on the chest radiograph further supports this diagnosis. Among the options provided, silicosis is a lung disease caused by the inhalation of silica particles, commonly found in industries such as glass manufacturing. Therefore, the most likely diagnosis is {B}.

question:
A 32-year-old man with HIV infection is brought to the emergency department by his roommate because of a 2-week history of progressively worsening headache and vomiting. Current medications include trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, dolutegravir, and tenofovir-emtricitabine. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F). Physical examination shows nuchal rigidity. Kernig and Brudzinski signs are present. A lumbar puncture is performed and shows an opening pressure of 32 cm H2O (N: < 20). The pathogen isolated from the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) can be cultured on Sabouraud agar. Further evaluation of this patient's CSF is most likely to show which of the following additional findings?
A) Positive latex agglutination test
B) Positive PCR for HSV-2 DNA
C) Presence of tachyzoites
D) Increased adenosine deaminase concentration
E) Positive PCR for JC virus DNA
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>32-year-old man with HIV infection</fact1> is brought to the emergency department by his roommate because of a <fact2>2-week history of progressively worsening headache and vomiting</fact2>. Current medications include <fact3>trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, dolutegravir, and tenofovir-emtricitabine</fact3>. His <fact4>temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F)</fact4>. Physical examination shows <fact5>nuchal rigidity</fact5>. Kernig and Brudzinski signs are present. A <fact6>lumbar puncture is performed and shows an opening pressure of 32 cm H2O (N: < 20)</fact6>. The pathogen isolated from the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) can be cultured on <fact7>Sabouraud agar</fact7>. Further evaluation of this patient's CSF is most likely to show which of the following additional findings?

Answer: A) Positive latex agglutination test

question:
A 28-year-old female comes to the physician’s office with a complaint of episodic chest pain. She describes the pain as squeezing and tightness in her chest. This pain has been happening every few days for 3 months. She says there is no association of the pain with food or exercise. She is able to climb up to her fourth floor apartment daily without issue. Her only past medical history is migraines for which she takes appropriate medication. Here temperature is 98.6°F (37°C), blood pressure is 120/68 mmHg, pulse is 60/min, respirations are 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. She has no known family history. The patient is not in pain on presentation and EKG in the office is normal. 24-hour ECG monitoring shows transient ST elevations during the episodes of pain that resolve completely. The mechanism of this patient’s chest pain is most similar to the mechanism behind which of the following?
A) Raynaud's phenomenon
B) Myocardial infarction
C) Aortic dissection
D) Costochondritis
E) Dysphagia
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>28-year-old female</fact1> comes to the physician’s office with a complaint of <fact2>episodic chest pain</fact2>. She describes the pain as <fact3>squeezing and tightness in her chest</fact3>. This pain has been happening <fact4>every few days for 3 months</fact4>. She says there is <fact5>no association of the pain with food or exercise</fact5>. She is able to <fact6>climb up to her fourth floor apartment daily without issue</fact6>. Her only past medical history is <fact7>migraines</fact7> for which she takes appropriate medication. Her temperature is <fact8>98.6°F (37°C)</fact8>, blood pressure is <fact9>120/68 mmHg</fact9>, pulse is <fact10>60/min</fact10>, respirations are <fact11>16/min</fact11>, and oxygen saturation is <fact12>98% on room air</fact12>. She has <fact13>no known family history</fact13>. The patient is not in pain on presentation and <fact14>EKG in the office is normal</fact14>. <fact15>24-hour ECG monitoring shows transient ST elevations during the episodes of pain that resolve completely</fact15>. The mechanism of this patient’s chest pain is most similar to the mechanism behind which of the following?
A) Raynaud's phenomenon
B) Myocardial infarction
C) Aortic dissection
D) Costochondritis
E) Dysphagia

Answer: 
The patient's <fact2>episodic chest pain</fact2> described as <fact3>squeezing and tightness in her chest</fact3> with <fact15>transient ST elevations during the episodes of pain that resolve completely</fact15> on 24-hour ECG monitoring suggests a condition involving transient coronary artery spasm. This is most similar to the mechanism behind Raynaud's phenomenon, which involves vasospasm of the arteries supplying the fingers and toes in response to cold or stress. Both conditions involve abnormal vasoreactivity leading to transient ischemia. Therefore, the answer is {A}.

question:
A 78-year-old woman presents to the office for an annual health check-up with her family physician accompanied by her daughter. She has no complaints during this visit but her daughter states that she is having difficulty locating objects such as the television remote, car keys, and her purse. Her medical history is significant for Alzheimer’s dementia, coronary artery disease, diabetes mellitus, hypothyroidism, congestive heart failure, osteoarthritis and centrilobular emphysema. The patient takes memantine, atorvastatin, metformin, levothyroxine, lisinopril, aspirin, albuterol, and ipratropium. The patient’s vitals are within normal limits today. Physical exam reveals an elderly female in no acute distress, oriented to person, place and year, but not to month or day of the week. She has a 3/6 holosystolic murmur at the left sternal border along with an S3 gallop. There are mild crackles at the lung bases. The remainder of the exam is normal. A previous urine culture reports growth of > 100,000 CFU of Enterobacter. Urinalysis findings are offered below:
Leukocyte esterase  positive
WBCs 50-100 cell/HPF
Nitrites positive
RBCs 2 cell/HPF
Epithelial cells 2 cell/HPF
Urine pH 5.7
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?
A) TMP-SMX
B) Nitrofurantoin
C) Levofloxacin
D) Cephalexin
E) No treatment is necessary
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>78-year-old woman</fact1> presents to the office for an annual health check-up with her family physician accompanied by her daughter. She has no complaints during this visit but her daughter states that she is having difficulty locating objects such as the <fact2>television remote, car keys, and her purse</fact2>. Her medical history is significant for <fact3>Alzheimer’s dementia, coronary artery disease, diabetes mellitus, hypothyroidism, congestive heart failure, osteoarthritis and centrilobular emphysema</fact3>. The patient takes <fact4>memantine, atorvastatin, metformin, levothyroxine, lisinopril, aspirin, albuterol, and ipratropium</fact4>. The patient’s vitals are within normal limits today. Physical exam reveals an elderly female in no acute distress, oriented to person, place and year, but not to month or day of the week. She has a <fact5>3/6 holosystolic murmur at the left sternal border along with an S3 gallop</fact5>. There are mild crackles at the lung bases. The remainder of the exam is normal. A previous urine culture reports growth of <fact6>> 100,000 CFU of Enterobacter</fact6>. Urinalysis findings are offered below:
<fact7>Leukocyte esterase  positive</fact7>
<fact8>WBCs 50-100 cell/HPF</fact8>
<fact9>Nitrites positive</fact9>
<fact10>RBCs 2 cell/HPF</fact10>
<fact11>Epithelial cells 2 cell/HPF</fact11>
<fact12>Urine pH 5.7</fact12>
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's <fact6>urine culture report showing growth of > 100,000 CFU of Enterobacter</fact6>, along with the urinalysis findings of <fact7>positive leukocyte esterase</fact7>, <fact8>50-100 WBCs/HPF</fact8>, and <fact9>positive nitrites</fact9>, it is clear that the patient has a urinary tract infection (UTI). Given the patient's age and medical history, including <fact3>Alzheimer’s dementia, coronary artery disease, diabetes mellitus, hypothyroidism, congestive heart failure, osteoarthritis and centrilobular emphysema</fact3>, it is essential to choose an antibiotic that is effective against Enterobacter and has a suitable safety profile for this patient. Nitrofurantoin is generally not effective against Enterobacter, and TMP-SMX may not be the best choice due to potential interactions with the patient's medications, such as <fact4>memantine, atorvastatin, metformin, levothyroxine, lisinopril, aspirin, albuterol, and ipratropium</fact4>. Cephalexin is a suitable option for treating Enterobacter UTIs and is generally well-tolerated in elderly patients. Therefore, the most appropriate next step is to prescribe {D} Cephalexin.

question:
A 63-year-old man with diverticular disease comes to the emergency department because of painless rectal bleeding, dizziness, and lightheadedness for 2 hours. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.6°F), pulse is 115/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 86/60 mm Hg. He appears pale. Physical examination shows bright red rectal bleeding. Colonoscopy shows profuse diverticular bleeding; endoscopic hemostasis is performed. After initiating fluid resuscitation, the patient becomes hemodynamically stable. The following day, laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 8 g/dL
Leukocyte count 15,500/mm3
Platelet count 170,000/mm3
Serum
Urea nitrogen 60 mg/dL
Creatinine 2.1 mg/dL
Bilirubin
Total 1.2 mg/dL
Indirect 0.3 mg/dL
Alkaline phosphatase 96 U/L
Alanine aminotransferase (ALT, GPT) 2,674 U/L
Aspartate aminotransferase (AST, GOT) 2,254 U/L
Which of the following cells in the patient's liver were most likely damaged first?"
A) Hepatic stellate (Ito) cells
B) Periportal hepatocytes
C) Hepatic sinusoidal endothelial cells
D) Hepatic Kupffer cells
E) Centrilobular hepatocytes
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>63-year-old man</fact1> with <fact2>diverticular disease</fact2> comes to the emergency department because of <fact3>painless rectal bleeding, dizziness, and lightheadedness</fact3> for 2 hours. His <fact4>temperature is 37.6°C (99.6°F)</fact4>, <fact5>pulse is 115/min</fact5>, <fact6>respirations are 24/min</fact6>, and <fact7>blood pressure is 86/60 mm Hg</fact7>. He appears pale. Physical examination shows <fact8>bright red rectal bleeding</fact8>. Colonoscopy shows <fact9>profuse diverticular bleeding</fact9>; endoscopic hemostasis is performed. After initiating fluid resuscitation, the patient becomes hemodynamically stable. The following day, laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin <fact10>8 g/dL</fact10>
Leukocyte count <fact11>15,500/mm3</fact11>
Platelet count <fact12>170,000/mm3</fact12>
Serum
Urea nitrogen <fact13>60 mg/dL</fact13>
Creatinine <fact14>2.1 mg/dL</fact14>
Bilirubin
Total <fact15>1.2 mg/dL</fact15>
Indirect <fact16>0.3 mg/dL</fact16>
Alkaline phosphatase <fact17>96 U/L</fact17>
Alanine aminotransferase (ALT, GPT) <fact18>2,674 U/L</fact18>
Aspartate aminotransferase (AST, GOT) <fact19>2,254 U/L</fact19>
Which of the following cells in the patient's liver were most likely damaged first?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's presentation with <fact3>painless rectal bleeding, dizziness, and lightheadedness</fact3> and the laboratory findings, particularly the significantly elevated liver enzymes <fact18>ALT of 2,674 U/L</fact18> and <fact19>AST of 2,254 U/L</fact19>, it is indicative of acute liver injury. The pattern of enzyme elevation, with ALT being higher than AST, points towards a hepatocellular injury pattern. In the context of hypovolemic shock due to <fact9>profuse diverticular bleeding</fact9>, the liver injury is likely due to ischemia. The liver cells most susceptible to ischemic injury are those located in the centrilobular region (zone III), which are farthest from the hepatic artery and portal vein and thus most prone to hypoxia. Therefore, the cells in the patient's liver that were most likely damaged first are the <fact20>centrilobular hepatocytes</fact20>. The answer is E.

question:
A routine newborn screening test for phenylketonuria in a male neonate shows a serum phenylalanine concentration of 44 mg/dL (N < 20). He is started on a special diet and the hyperphenylalaninemia resolves. At a routine well-child examination 4 months later, the physician notices that he has persistent head lag. On examination, he has blue eyes, pale skin, blonde hair, and generalized hypotonia. His serum prolactin level is markedly elevated. Supplementation of which of the following substances is most likely to prevent further complications of this patient's condition?
A) Tyrosine
B) Pyridoxine
C) Thiamine
D) Tetrahydrobiopterin
E) Niacin
answer:
Reformatted Question: A routine newborn screening test for <fact1>phenylketonuria</fact1> in a male neonate shows a serum <fact2>phenylalanine concentration of 44 mg/dL (N < 20)</fact2>. He is started on a special diet and the <fact3>hyperphenylalaninemia resolves</fact3>. At a routine well-child examination 4 months later, the physician notices that he has <fact4>persistent head lag</fact4>. On examination, he has <fact5>blue eyes, pale skin, blonde hair, and generalized hypotonia</fact5>. His serum <fact6>prolactin level is markedly elevated</fact6>. Supplementation of which of the following substances is most likely to prevent further complications of this patient's condition?

Answer: Considering the patient's diagnosis of <fact1>phenylketonuria</fact1> and the resolution of <fact3>hyperphenylalaninemia</fact3> after dietary changes, the development of <fact4>persistent head lag</fact4>, <fact5>blue eyes, pale skin, blonde hair, and generalized hypotonia</fact5>, along with a <fact6>markedly elevated serum prolactin level</fact6>, suggests a possible issue with neurotransmitter synthesis. Tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4) is a cofactor necessary for the hydroxylation of phenylalanine to tyrosine, which is then used to synthesize dopamine and serotonin. Elevated prolactin levels can be seen in conditions affecting dopamine synthesis. Therefore, supplementation of {D} Tetrahydrobiopterin is most likely to prevent further complications of this patient's condition.

question:
A 47-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of worsening pain, discoloration, and swelling of her right hand. Two days ago, she was camping outdoors in Texas with her two young children. She was awoken in the middle of the night by “something crawling on my hand.” The following morning, she saw a wound on her hand that was initially painless, but over the next several hours she noticed reddening and blistering. Yesterday, the lesion turned blue with a blackish discoloration at the center. Her temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 83/min, and blood pressure is 128/84 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a bluish plaque with a central area of necrosis surrounded by a rim of erythema at the dorsum of the right hand. Which of the following animals is most likely responsible for the patient's symptoms?
A) Bald-faced hornet
B) Diamondback rattlesnake
C) Brown recluse spider
D) Striped bark scorpion
E) Deer tick
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>47-year-old woman</fact1> comes to the emergency department because of <fact2>worsening pain, discoloration, and swelling of her right hand</fact2>. Two days ago, she was <fact3>camping outdoors in Texas</fact3> with her two young children. She was awoken in the middle of the night by <fact4>“something crawling on my hand.”</fact4> The following morning, she saw a <fact5>wound on her hand that was initially painless</fact5>, but over the next several hours she noticed <fact6>reddening and blistering</fact6>. Yesterday, the lesion turned <fact7>blue with a blackish discoloration at the center</fact7>. Her <fact8>temperature is 38°C (100.4°F)</fact8>, <fact9>pulse is 83/min</fact9>, and <fact10>blood pressure is 128/84 mm Hg</fact10>. Physical examination shows a <fact11>bluish plaque with a central area of necrosis surrounded by a rim of erythema at the dorsum of the right hand</fact11>. Which of the following animals is most likely responsible for the patient's symptoms?

Answer: Considering the <fact1>47-year-old woman's</fact1> symptoms of <fact2>worsening pain, discoloration, and swelling of her right hand</fact2> after being <fact4>“something crawling on my hand”</fact4> while <fact3>camping outdoors in Texas</fact3>, along with the progression of the wound from <fact5>painless</fact5> to <fact6>reddening and blistering</fact6>, and eventually turning <fact7>blue with a blackish discoloration at the center</fact7>, the description is highly suggestive of a spider bite. Specifically, the <fact11>bluish plaque with a central area of necrosis surrounded by a rim of erythema at the dorsum of the right hand</fact11> is characteristic of a brown recluse spider bite. Therefore, the most likely animal responsible for the patient's symptoms is the {C} Brown recluse spider.

question:
A 76-year-old man with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) presents complaining of 3 weeks of cough and progressive dyspnea on exertion in the setting of a 20 pound weight loss. He is a 60 pack-year smoker, worked as a shipbuilder 30 years ago, and recently traveled to Ohio to visit family. Chest radiograph shows increased bronchovascular markings, reticular parenchymal opacities, and multiple pleural plaques. Labs are unremarkable except for a slight anemia. Which of the following is the most likely finding on this patient's chest CT?
A) Nodular mass spreading along pleural surfaces
B) Honeycombing
C) Air bronchogram
D) Granulomatous nodule
E) Lower lobe cavitary mass
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>76-year-old man</fact1> with <fact2>chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)</fact2> presents complaining of <fact3>3 weeks of cough and progressive dyspnea on exertion</fact3> in the setting of a <fact4>20 pound weight loss</fact4>. He is a <fact5>60 pack-year smoker</fact5>, <fact6>worked as a shipbuilder 30 years ago</fact6>, and <fact7>recently traveled to Ohio to visit family</fact7>. <fact8>Chest radiograph</fact8> shows <fact9>increased bronchovascular markings</fact9>, <fact10>reticular parenchymal opacities</fact10>, and <fact11>multiple pleural plaques</fact11>. <fact12>Labs are unremarkable except for a slight anemia</fact12>. Which of the following is the most likely finding on this patient's chest CT?

Answer: 
Given the patient's history of <fact5>60 pack-year smoking</fact5> and <fact6>working as a shipbuilder 30 years ago</fact6>, which likely exposed him to asbestos, along with the presence of <fact11>multiple pleural plaques</fact11> on the chest radiograph, the most likely diagnosis is asbestosis. Asbestosis is a chronic lung disease characterized by scarring of the lungs caused by the inhalation of asbestos fibers. On chest CT, the hallmark of asbestosis is the presence of <fact10>reticular parenchymal opacities</fact10> and <fact11>pleural plaques</fact11>. Among the options provided, the description of <fact10>honeycombing</fact10> is the most consistent with asbestosis. Honeycombing is a characteristic radiographic pattern seen in advanced asbestosis, representing a network of small air-filled cysts and fibrosis within the lung parenchyma. Therefore, the correct answer is {B}.

question:
A 25-year-old man presents to the emergency department with altered mental status. He was found down in the middle of the street. His past medical history is unknown. His temperature is 99.0°F (37.2°C), blood pressure is 104/64 mmHg, pulse is 70/min, respirations are 5/min, and oxygen saturation is 91% on room air. The patient is being resuscitated in the trauma bay. Which of the following was most likely to be found on exam?
A) Ataxia
B) Conjunctival injection
C) Miosis
D) Mydriasis
E) Nystagmus
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>25-year-old man</fact1> presents to the emergency department with <fact2>altered mental status</fact2>. He was found down in the middle of the street. His past medical history is unknown. His <fact3>temperature is 99.0°F (37.2°C)</fact3>, <fact4>blood pressure is 104/64 mmHg</fact4>, <fact5>pulse is 70/min</fact5>, <fact6>respirations are 5/min</fact6>, and <fact7>oxygen saturation is 91% on room air</fact7>. The patient is being resuscitated in the trauma bay. Which of the following was most likely to be found on exam?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's <fact2>altered mental status</fact2> and significantly decreased <fact6>respirations at 5/min</fact6>, it is likely that he is experiencing respiratory depression. This can be caused by various factors, including opioid overdose. Opioid overdose is known to cause respiratory depression, and it is a common cause of altered mental status in patients found unresponsive. One of the classic signs of opioid use is <fact8>miosis</fact8>, which is the constriction of the pupils. Therefore, the answer is {C}.

question:
A group of investigators is studying the association between a fire retardant chemical used on furniture and interstitial lung disease. They use hospital records to identify 50 people who have been diagnosed with interstitial lung disease. They also identify a group of 50 people without interstitial lung disease who are matched in age and geographic location to those with the disease. The participants' exposure to the chemical is assessed by surveys and home visits. Which of the following best describes this study design?
A) Case-control study
B) Cross-sectional study
C) Case series
D) Retrospective cohort study
E) Randomized controlled trial
answer:
Reformatted Question: A group of investigators is studying the association between a <fact1>fire retardant chemical used on furniture</fact1> and <fact2>interstitial lung disease</fact2>. They use <fact3>hospital records</fact3> to identify <fact4>50 people who have been diagnosed with interstitial lung disease</fact4>. They also identify a group of <fact5>50 people without interstitial lung disease</fact5> who are <fact6>matched in age and geographic location</fact6> to those with the disease. The participants' <fact7>exposure to the chemical</fact7> is assessed by <fact8>surveys and home visits</fact8>. Which of the following best describes this study design?

Answer: A) Case-control study. The study design is a case-control study because it involves identifying <fact4>50 people who have been diagnosed with interstitial lung disease</fact4> (cases) and comparing them to <fact5>50 people without interstitial lung disease</fact5> (controls) who are <fact6>matched in age and geographic location</fact6> to the cases. The study aims to investigate the association between <fact1>exposure to the fire retardant chemical</fact1> and the development of <fact2>interstitial lung disease</fact2> by assessing the participants' <fact7>exposure to the chemical</fact7> through <fact8>surveys and home visits</fact8>.

question:
A 60-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of sudden, painless loss of vision in her right eye that occurred 30 minutes ago while watching TV. She has coronary artery disease, hypertension, and type 2 diabetes mellitus; she has had trouble adhering to her medication regimen. Her blood pressure is 160/85 mm Hg. Examination shows 20/50 vision in the left eye and no perception of light in the right eye. Direct pupillary reflex is present in the left eye, but absent in the right eye. Accommodation is intact bilaterally. Intraocular pressure is 16 mm Hg in the left eye and 18 mm Hg in the right eye. Fundoscopic examination of the right eye shows a pale, white retina with a bright red area within the macula. The optic disc appears normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
A) Central retinal vein occlusion
B) Retinal detachment
C) Central retinal artery occlusion
D) Acute angle-closure glaucoma
E) Anterior ischemic optic neuropathy
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>60-year-old woman</fact1> is brought to the emergency department because of <fact2>sudden, painless loss of vision in her right eye</fact2> that occurred <fact3>30 minutes ago</fact3> while watching TV. She has <fact4>coronary artery disease, hypertension, and type 2 diabetes mellitus</fact4>; she has had trouble adhering to her medication regimen. Her <fact5>blood pressure is 160/85 mm Hg</fact5>. Examination shows <fact6>20/50 vision in the left eye and no perception of light in the right eye</fact6>. Direct pupillary reflex is present in the left eye, but absent in the right eye. Accommodation is intact bilaterally. Intraocular pressure is <fact7>16 mm Hg in the left eye and 18 mm Hg in the right eye</fact7>. Fundoscopic examination of the right eye shows a <fact8>pale, white retina with a bright red area within the macula</fact8>. The optic disc appears normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's <fact1>age</fact1> and <fact4>medical history of coronary artery disease, hypertension, and type 2 diabetes mellitus</fact4>, along with the <fact2>sudden, painless loss of vision in her right eye</fact2> that occurred <fact3>30 minutes ago</fact3>, the presentation is highly suggestive of a vascular event affecting the eye. The <fact5>high blood pressure</fact5> further supports the likelihood of a vascular cause. The key findings include <fact6>no perception of light in the right eye</fact6>, absent direct pupillary reflex in the right eye, and normal intraocular pressure (<fact7>18 mm Hg in the right eye</fact7>). The fundoscopic examination showing a <fact8>pale, white retina with a bright red area within the macula</fact8> is characteristic of retinal ischemia due to arterial occlusion. Therefore, the most likely diagnosis is {C} Central retinal artery occlusion.

question:
A 32-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 0, at 22 weeks' gestation comes to the emergency department for abdominal pain and heavy vaginal bleeding for 2 hours. She has had no prenatal care. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 102/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 138/82 mm Hg. The abdomen is nontender, and regular contractions are felt every 2 minutes. The uterus is consistent in size with a 20-week gestation. There is blood on the vulva, introitus, and medial aspect of the thighs. Ultrasound shows complete detachment of the placenta from the uterus. Fetal heart tones are absent. An emergent cesarean delivery is performed. Following the procedure, the patient becomes tearful and distraught. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial response by the physician?
A) “I'm sorry for your loss. This must be a difficult situation for you.”
B) “Losing a baby is difficult, but I'm sure next time it'll work out.”
C) “I'm sorry for your loss. Let's talk about how to move forward from here.”
D) “Losing a baby is difficult; but I see this every day, and I know you'll get through it.”
E) “I'm sorry for your loss. I can write you a prescription to help with your anxiety and grief.”
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>32-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 0</fact1>, at <fact2>22 weeks' gestation</fact2> comes to the emergency department for <fact3>abdominal pain and heavy vaginal bleeding</fact3> for 2 hours. She has had <fact4>no prenatal care</fact4>. Her <fact5>temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F)</fact5>, <fact6>pulse is 102/min</fact6>, <fact7>respirations are 16/min</fact7>, and <fact8>blood pressure is 138/82 mm Hg</fact8>. The <fact9>abdomen is nontender</fact9>, and regular contractions are felt every 2 minutes. The <fact10>uterus is consistent in size with a 20-week gestation</fact10>. There is <fact11>blood on the vulva, introitus, and medial aspect of the thighs</fact11>. Ultrasound shows <fact12>complete detachment of the placenta from the uterus</fact12>. <fact13>Fetal heart tones are absent</fact13>. An emergent <fact14>cesarean delivery is performed</fact14>. Following the procedure, the patient becomes <fact15>tearful and distraught</fact15>. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial response by the physician?

Answer: A) “I'm sorry for your loss. This must be a difficult situation for you.”

Explanation: The patient is experiencing a traumatic event, having undergone an emergent cesarean delivery due to <fact12>complete detachment of the placenta from the uterus</fact12> and <fact13>absent fetal heart tones</fact13>, resulting in the loss of her baby. She is now <fact15>tearful and distraught</fact15>. The most appropriate initial response by the physician should acknowledge her loss and show empathy. Option A is the most suitable response as it offers condolences and acknowledges the difficulty of the situation, allowing the patient to process her emotions.

question:
A 52-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician for abdominal pain and diarrhea. The patient states that she has been experiencing watery diarrhea for weeks now. During this same period she states she has been constantly thirsty and does not have the same energy levels that she once had. The patient has a past medical history of anxiety and depression and is currently taking fluoxetine. She was recently treated for a middle ear infection and sinusitis with amoxicillin-clavulanic acid one week ago. Her temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), blood pressure is 110/58 mmHg, pulse is 100/min, respirations are 17/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Laboratory values are obtained and shown below.

Serum:
Na+: 139 mEq/L
Cl-: 100 mEq/L
K+: 2.9 mEq/L
HCO3-: 27 mEq/L
BUN: 25 mg/dL
Glucose: 99 mg/dL
Creatinine: 1.4 mg/dL
Ca2+: 10.2 mg/dL
AST: 12 U/L
ALT: 10 U/L

Which of the following is associated with the most likely diagnosis?
A) Enterotoxin
B) Impaired iron absorption
C) Increased serotonin production
D) Invasive bacterial infection
E) Normal flora destruction
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>52-year-old woman</fact1> presents to her primary care physician for <fact2>abdominal pain and diarrhea</fact2>. The patient states that she has been experiencing <fact3>watery diarrhea</fact3> for weeks now. During this same period she states she has been constantly <fact4>thirsty</fact4> and does not have the same <fact5>energy levels</fact5> that she once had. The patient has a past medical history of <fact6>anxiety and depression</fact6> and is currently taking <fact7>fluoxetine</fact7>. She was recently treated for a <fact8>middle ear infection</fact8> and <fact9>sinusitis</fact9> with <fact10>amoxicillin-clavulanic acid</fact10> one week ago. Her <fact11>temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C)</fact11>, <fact12>blood pressure is 110/58 mmHg</fact12>, <fact13>pulse is 100/min</fact13>, <fact14>respirations are 17/min</fact14>, and <fact15>oxygen saturation is 98% on room air</fact15>. Laboratory values are obtained and shown below.

Serum:
<fact16>Na+: 139 mEq/L</fact16>
<fact17>Cl-: 100 mEq/L</fact17>
<fact18>K+: 2.9 mEq/L</fact18>
<fact19>HCO3-: 27 mEq/L</fact19>
<fact20>BUN: 25 mg/dL</fact20>
<fact21>Glucose: 99 mg/dL</fact21>
