<fact22>Creatinine: 1.4 mg/dL</fact22>
<fact23>Ca2+: 10.2 mg/dL</fact23>
<fact24>AST: 12 U/L</fact24>
<fact25>ALT: 10 U/L</fact25>

Which of the following is associated with the most likely diagnosis?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's symptoms of <fact3>watery diarrhea</fact3>, <fact4>thirst</fact4>, and decreased <fact5>energy levels</fact5>, along with laboratory values showing <fact18>hypokalemia (K+: 2.9 mEq/L)</fact18>, <fact20>slightly elevated BUN (25 mg/dL)</fact20>, and <fact22>mildly elevated creatinine (1.4 mg/dL)</fact22>, it is likely that the patient is experiencing a complication related to antibiotic use. The recent treatment with <fact10>amoxicillin-clavulanic acid</fact10> for <fact8>middle ear infection</fact8> and <fact9>sinusitis</fact9> may have led to an overgrowth of Clostridioides difficile (C. difficile), a common cause of antibiotic-associated diarrhea. C. difficile produces <fact26>enterotoxin</fact26>, which causes the colon to secrete large amounts of fluid, resulting in watery diarrhea. Therefore, the correct answer is {A}.

question:
A 64-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 2-day history of lower back pain, fever, and chills. He has had nausea but no vomiting during this time. He has hypertension, chronic kidney disease, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Three months ago, he underwent amputation of his left third toe because of a non-healing ulcer. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 48 years. Current medications include hydrochlorothiazide, metoprolol, and insulin. His temperature is 39.4°C (102.9°F), pulse is 102/min, blood pressure is 150/94 mm Hg, and respirations are 18/min. Examination shows a 1-cm (0.4-in) round ulcer on the sole of his right foot. There is costovertebral angle tenderness on the left side. The abdomen is soft. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 11.5 g/dL
Leukocyte count 19,000/mm3
Serum
Na+ 140 mEq/L
Cl− 102 mEq/L
K+ 5.0 mEq/L
HCO3− 25 mEq/L
Urea nitrogen 65 mg/dL
Creatinine 2.4 mg/dL
Glucose 240 mg/dL
Urine
Blood 1+
Protein 1+
WBC 100/hpf
Nitrite 2+
WBC casts numerous
Urine and blood samples for culture and sensitivity tests are obtained. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?"
A) Inpatient treatment with intravenous ciprofloxacin
B) Outpatient treatment with oral levofloxacin
C) Outpatient treatment with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole
D) Initiate hemodialysis
E) Perform CT scan with contrast of the abdomen
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>64-year-old man</fact1> comes to the emergency department because of a <fact2>2-day history of lower back pain, fever, and chills</fact2>. He has had <fact3>nausea but no vomiting</fact3> during this time. He has <fact4>hypertension, chronic kidney disease, and type 2 diabetes mellitus</fact4>. Three months ago, he underwent <fact5>amputation of his left third toe because of a non-healing ulcer</fact5>. He has <fact6>smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 48 years</fact6>. Current medications include <fact7>hydrochlorothiazide, metoprolol, and insulin</fact7>. His <fact8>temperature is 39.4°C (102.9°F)</fact8>, <fact9>pulse is 102/min</fact9>, <fact10>blood pressure is 150/94 mm Hg</fact10>, and <fact11>respirations are 18/min</fact11>. Examination shows a <fact12>1-cm (0.4-in) round ulcer on the sole of his right foot</fact12>. There is <fact13>costovertebral angle tenderness on the left side</fact13>. The abdomen is soft. Laboratory studies show:
<fact14>Hemoglobin 11.5 g/dL</fact14>
<fact15>Leukocyte count 19,000/mm3</fact15>
Serum
<fact16>Na+ 140 mEq/L</fact16>
<fact17>Cl− 102 mEq/L</fact17>
<fact18>K+ 5.0 mEq/L</fact18>
<fact19>HCO3− 25 mEq/L</fact19>
<fact20>Urea nitrogen 65 mg/dL</fact20>
<fact21> Creatinine 2.4 mg/dL</fact21>
<fact22>Glucose 240 mg/dL</fact22>
Urine
<fact23>Blood 1+</fact23>
<fact24>Protein 1+</fact24>
<fact25>WBC 100/hpf</fact25>
<fact26>Nitrite 2+</fact26>
<fact27>WBC casts numerous</fact27>
Urine and blood samples for culture and sensitivity tests are obtained. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

Answer: 
Given the patient's presentation with <fact2>fever, chills, and lower back pain</fact2>, alongside laboratory findings of <fact15>leukocytosis</fact15>, <fact23>hematuria</fact23>, <fact24>proteinuria</fact24>, and <fact25>pyuria</fact25>, a urinary tract infection (UTI) is highly suspected. The presence of <fact26>nitrite-positive</fact26> and <fact27>WBC casts</fact27> further supports this diagnosis, indicating an upper urinary tract infection. Considering the patient's <fact4>chronic kidney disease</fact4> and <fact21>elevated creatinine</fact21>, it is crucial to manage the infection promptly and effectively to prevent further renal damage. Given the severity of the infection and the patient's <fact8>high fever</fact8> and <fact9>rapid pulse</fact9>, inpatient treatment with intravenous antibiotics is warranted. Among the options provided, intravenous ciprofloxacin is a reasonable choice for treating a severe UTI, especially considering the patient's <fact22>glucose level</fact22> and potential for renal impairment, which may necessitate dose adjustment. Therefore, the most appropriate next step in management is {A}.

question:
A 26-year-old woman comes to the physician because of fatigue, weight loss, and muscle aches during the past 2 months. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. Her only medication is a multivitamin. A metyrapone stimulation test is performed and the results rule out a diagnosis of adrenal insufficiency. Which of the following changes in laboratory findings are most likely to have been observed in this patient following the administration of the drug?
A) Increase in serum ACTH
B) Decrease in urinary 17-hydroxycorticosteroids
C) Decrease in serum 11-deoxycortisol
D) Increase in serum cortisol
E) Increase in urine metanephrines
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>26-year-old woman</fact1> comes to the physician because of <fact2>fatigue, weight loss, and muscle aches</fact2> during the past <fact3>2 months</fact3>. There is no <fact4>personal or family history of serious illness</fact4>. Her only medication is a <fact5>multivitamin</fact5>. A <fact6>metyrapone stimulation test</fact6> is performed and the results rule out a diagnosis of <fact7>adrenal insufficiency</fact7>. Which of the following changes in laboratory findings are most likely to have been observed in this patient following the administration of the drug?

Answer: To answer this question, we need to understand the mechanism of the <fact6>metyrapone stimulation test</fact6> and its effects on the body's hormonal responses. Metyrapone is a medication that inhibits the enzyme 11-beta-hydroxylase, which is crucial for the conversion of 11-deoxycortisol to cortisol in the adrenal glands. When metyrapone is administered, it blocks this conversion, leading to an accumulation of 11-deoxycortisol and a decrease in cortisol production. As a result, the body responds by increasing the production of adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) from the pituitary gland in an attempt to stimulate the adrenal glands to produce more cortisol. Given this information, the most likely change in laboratory findings following the administration of metyrapone would be an <fact8>increase in serum ACTH</fact8> as the body tries to compensate for the blocked cortisol production. Therefore, the answer is {A}.

question:
A 68-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with complaints of increased fatigue and back pain for the past year. His symptoms are progressively getting worse over the past few months despite adequate rest and trial of over the counter analgesics. His back pain is constant and non-radiating in nature. He denies any trauma to his back. His past medical history is insignificant. On examination, there is mild tenderness over the lumbar region in the midline with an absence of paraspinal muscle tenderness. Straight leg raise test is negative. His skin and conjunctiva appear pale. The physician orders basic blood work. His results are provided below.
Complete blood count
RBC 4.9 million cells/µL
Hemoglobin 9.8 g/dL
Hematocrit 41%
Total leukocyte count 6,800 cells/µL
Neutrophils 70%
Lymphocyte 26%
Monocytes 3%
Eosinophil 1%
Basophils 0%
Platelets 230,000 cells/µL
Basic Metabolic Panel
Sodium 136 mEq/L
Potassium 5.1 mEq/L
Chloride 101 mEq/L
Bicarbonate 24 mEq/L
Albumin 3.6 mg/ dL
Urea nitrogen 31 mg/dL
Creatinine 2.7 mg/dL
Uric Acid 6.7 mg/dL
Calcium 12.1 mg/dL
Glucose 105 mg/dL
Urinalysis shows proteinuria without any RBCs or pus cells. The patient’s proteinuria best fits in which of the following category?
A) Overflow proteinuria
B) Transient (functional) proteinuria
C) Tubular proteinuria
D) Orthostatic proteinuria
E) Isolated proteinuria
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>68-year-old man</fact1> presents to his primary care physician with complaints of <fact2>increased fatigue and back pain</fact2> for the past year. His symptoms are progressively getting worse over the past few months despite adequate rest and trial of over the counter analgesics. His back pain is <fact3>constant and non-radiating in nature</fact3>. He denies any trauma to his back. His past medical history is insignificant. On examination, there is <fact4>mild tenderness over the lumbar region in the midline</fact4> with an absence of paraspinal muscle tenderness. Straight leg raise test is negative. His skin and conjunctiva appear <fact5>pale</fact5>. The physician orders basic blood work. His results are provided below.
Complete blood count
<fact6>RBC 4.9 million cells/µL</fact6>
<fact7>Hemoglobin 9.8 g/dL</fact7>
<fact8>Hematocrit 41%</fact8>
Total leukocyte count 6,800 cells/µL
Neutrophils 70%
Lymphocyte 26%
Monocytes 3%
Eosinophil 1%
Basophils 0%
<fact9>Platelets 230,000 cells/µL</fact9>
Basic Metabolic Panel
Sodium 136 mEq/L
Potassium 5.1 mEq/L
Chloride 101 mEq/L
Bicarbonate 24 mEq/L
Albumin 3.6 mg/ dL
<fact10>Urea nitrogen 31 mg/dL</fact10>
<fact11>Creatinine 2.7 mg/dL</fact11>
Uric Acid 6.7 mg/dL
<fact12>Calcium 12.1 mg/dL</fact12>
Glucose 105 mg/dL
Urinalysis shows <fact13>proteinuria without any RBCs or pus cells</fact13>. The patient’s proteinuria best fits in which of the following category?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's presentation with <fact2>increased fatigue and back pain</fact2> along with laboratory findings such as <fact7>low hemoglobin</fact7>, <fact10>elevated urea nitrogen</fact10>, <fact11>high creatinine</fact11>, and <fact12>high calcium levels</fact12>, it suggests the presence of multiple myeloma, a plasma cell dyscrasia. The <fact13>proteinuria without any RBCs or pus cells</fact13> can be attributed to the presence of Bence-Jones proteins in the urine, which is characteristic of multiple myeloma. This condition is associated with <fact5>pale skin and conjunctiva</fact5> due to anemia, <fact3>constant and non-radiating back pain</fact3> due to bone lesions, and <fact4>mild tenderness over the lumbar region</fact4> due to vertebral involvement. The presence of proteinuria in this context best fits the category of overflow proteinuria, which occurs when the glomeruli are overwhelmed by an excessive amount of proteins, such as Bence-Jones proteins, that are produced by the abnormal plasma cells. Therefore, the answer is {A}.

question:
A 55-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a progressively growing mass in his axilla. During this period, he has had recurrent episodes of low-grade fever lasting for 7 to 10 days, and an 8-kg (18-lb) weight loss. His only medication is a multivitamin. Physical examination shows nontender, right axillary, cervical, and inguinal lymphadenopathy. His serum calcium concentration is 15.1 mg/dL and parathyroid hormone (PTH) concentration is 9 pg/mL. A lymph node biopsy shows granuloma formation and large CD15-positive, CD30-positive cells with bilobed nuclei. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's laboratory findings?
A) Excessive intake of dietary ergocalciferol
B) Increased release of PTH by parathyroid chief cells
C) Induction of focal osteolysis by tumor cells
D) Secretion of γ-interferon by activated T-lymphocytes
E) Production of PTH-related peptide by malignant cells
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>55-year-old man</fact1> comes to the physician because of a <fact2>3-month history of a progressively growing mass in his axilla</fact2>. During this period, he has had <fact3>recurrent episodes of low-grade fever lasting for 7 to 10 days</fact3>, and an <fact4>8-kg (18-lb) weight loss</fact4>. His only medication is a <fact5>multivitamin</fact5>. Physical examination shows <fact6>nontender, right axillary, cervical, and inguinal lymphadenopathy</fact6>. His <fact7>serum calcium concentration is 15.1 mg/dL</fact7> and <fact8>parathyroid hormone (PTH) concentration is 9 pg/mL</fact8>. A <fact9>lymph node biopsy shows granuloma formation and large CD15-positive, CD30-positive cells with bilobed nuclei</fact9>. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's laboratory findings?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's <fact2>3-month history of a progressively growing mass in his axilla</fact2> and <fact6>nontender, right axillary, cervical, and inguinal lymphadenopathy</fact6>, along with the findings from the <fact9>lymph node biopsy</fact9>, it is likely that the patient has a type of lymphoma. The <fact7>serum calcium concentration is 15.1 mg/dL</fact7>, which is elevated, and the <fact8>parathyroid hormone (PTH) concentration is 9 pg/mL</fact8>, which is within the normal range but on the lower side. This suggests that the hypercalcemia is not due to increased PTH release. The presence of <fact9>granuloma formation and large CD15-positive, CD30-positive cells with bilobed nuclei</fact9> in the lymph node biopsy is indicative of Hodgkin lymphoma. In this context, the most likely explanation for the patient's laboratory findings is the production of a factor that stimulates osteoclast activity, leading to hypercalcemia. This is often seen in lymphomas, where tumor cells can produce various cytokines that induce bone resorption. Among the options provided, the one that best matches this explanation is {C} Induction of focal osteolysis by tumor cells.

question:
A 25-year-old African American man presents to his primary care provider for routine blood work. He is a well-known case of sickle cell disease treated with hydroxyurea and tramadol as needed for pain. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. The patient asks if his disease can adversely affect his kidneys because his friend was recently diagnosed with end-stage renal failure. Which of the following is a renal complication of sickle cell disease?
A) Transitional cell carcinoma
B) Membranous glomerulonephritis
C) Proximal renal tubular acidosis
D) Impaired urine diluting ability
E) Impaired urine concentration ability
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>25-year-old African American man</fact1> presents to his primary care provider for routine blood work. He is a well-known case of <fact2>sickle cell disease</fact2> treated with <fact3>hydroxyurea</fact3> and <fact4>tramadol</fact4> as needed for pain. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. The patient asks if his disease can adversely affect his kidneys because his friend was recently diagnosed with <fact5>end-stage renal failure</fact5>. Which of the following is a renal complication of <fact2>sickle cell disease</fact2>?
A) Transitional cell carcinoma
B) Membranous glomerulonephritis
C) Proximal renal tubular acidosis
D) Impaired urine diluting ability
E) Impaired urine concentration ability

Answer: Given the patient's history of <fact2>sickle cell disease</fact2>, a condition that affects hemoglobin production and can cause various systemic complications, it is essential to consider how this disease can impact renal function. One known complication of <fact2>sickle cell disease</fact2> is its effect on the kidneys' ability to concentrate urine, which can lead to <fact5>end-stage renal failure</fact5> in severe cases. Among the options provided, choice E, <fact6>Impaired urine concentration ability</fact6>, is a direct consequence of the damage that sickled red blood cells can cause to the renal medulla, leading to a decreased ability to concentrate urine. This is a well-documented renal complication of <fact2>sickle cell disease</fact2>, making option E the correct answer.

question:
A 2-year-old girl with recurrent urinary tract infections is brought to the physician for a follow-up examination. Renal ultrasound shows bilateral dilation of the renal pelvis. A voiding cystourethrography shows retrograde flow of contrast into the ureters during micturition. Histologic examination of a kidney biopsy specimen is most likely to show which of the following findings?
A) Diffuse interstitial infiltration with T lymphocytes
B) Glomerular crescents with macrophages
C) Matrix expansion with mesangial proliferation
D) Cortical thinning with tubular atrophy
E) Thickened glomerular capillary loops
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>2-year-old girl</fact1> with <fact2>recurrent urinary tract infections</fact2> is brought to the physician for a follow-up examination. Renal ultrasound shows <fact3>bilateral dilation of the renal pelvis</fact3>. A <fact4>voiding cystourethrography</fact4> shows <fact5>retrograde flow of contrast into the ureters during micturition</fact5>. Histologic examination of a kidney biopsy specimen is most likely to show which of the following findings?

Answer: 
Considering the <fact1>2-year-old girl's</fact1> history of <fact2>recurrent urinary tract infections</fact2>, the renal ultrasound findings of <fact3>bilateral dilation of the renal pelvis</fact3>, and the <fact4>voiding cystourethrography</fact4> results showing <fact5>retrograde flow of contrast into the ureters during micturition</fact5>, the most likely diagnosis is Vesicoureteral Reflux (VUR). This condition often leads to chronic kidney damage due to the backflow of urine from the bladder to the kidneys, resulting in inflammation and scarring. The histologic examination of a kidney biopsy specimen in a patient with VUR would most likely show <fact6>cortical thinning with tubular atrophy</fact6>, indicating chronic kidney damage and scarring. Therefore, the correct answer is {D}.

question:
A 24-year-old man, who recently migrated from a developing country, presents to a physician because of a 2-year history of cough, blood in his sputum, fever, and weight loss. His sputum smear and culture confirm the diagnosis of pulmonary tuberculosis due to Mycobacterium tuberculosis. His Mantoux test is 2 mm × 3 mm, and his chest radiograph is normal. High-sensitivity enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay for HIV-1 and Western blot assay for HIV-1 are positive. His CD4+ T cell count is 90/μL and HIV RNA is 30,000 copies/mL. He is started on a 4-drug regimen consisting of isoniazid, rifampin, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol in appropriate doses. He becomes sputum smear-negative after 4 weeks and reports significant improvement in symptoms. After another 4 weeks, the physician removes pyrazinamide from the antitubercular regimen and adds antiretroviral therapy (dolutegravir/tenofovir/emtricitabine). After 3 weeks, the patient presents with complaints of fever and significantly increased cough for 3 days. There is no respiratory distress but generalized lymphadenopathy is present. His chest radiograph shows pulmonary infiltrates and mediastinal lymphadenopathy, sputum smear is negative, Mantoux test is 12 mm × 14 mm, CD4+ T cell count is 370/μL, and HIV RNA is 2,900 copies/mL. What is the most appropriate initial step in treatment?
A) Stop antiretroviral therapy and continue antitubercular therapy
B) Change antiretroviral therapy to darunavir/ritonavir plus tenofovir/emtricitabine
C) Change antitubercular therapy to isoniazid-rifampin-pyrazinamide-ethambutol-streptomycin
D) Change antitubercular therapy to isoniazid-rifampin-ethambutol-streptomycin
E) Continue antitubercular therapy and antiretroviral therapy without any change
answer:
Reformatted Question:

A <fact1>24-year-old man</fact1>, who recently migrated from a developing country, presents to a physician because of a <fact2>2-year history of cough, blood in his sputum, fever, and weight loss</fact2>. His <fact3>sputum smear and culture confirm the diagnosis of pulmonary tuberculosis due to Mycobacterium tuberculosis</fact3>. His <fact4>Mantoux test is 2 mm × 3 mm</fact4>, and his <fact5>chest radiograph is normal</fact5>. High-sensitivity enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay for <fact6>HIV-1</fact6> and Western blot assay for <fact6>HIV-1</fact6> are positive. His <fact7>CD4+ T cell count is 90/μL</fact7> and <fact8>HIV RNA is 30,000 copies/mL</fact8>. He is started on a <fact9>4-drug regimen consisting of isoniazid, rifampin, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol</fact9> in appropriate doses. He becomes <fact10>sputum smear-negative after 4 weeks</fact10> and reports significant improvement in symptoms. After another 4 weeks, the physician removes <fact11>pyrazinamide from the antitubercular regimen</fact11> and adds <fact12>antiretroviral therapy (dolutegravir/tenofovir/emtricitabine)</fact12>. After 3 weeks, the patient presents with complaints of <fact13>fever and significantly increased cough for 3 days</fact13>. There is no respiratory distress but <fact14>generalized lymphadenopathy is present</fact14>. His <fact15>chest radiograph shows pulmonary infiltrates and mediastinal lymphadenopathy</fact15>, <fact16>sputum smear is negative</fact16>, <fact17>Mantoux test is 12 mm × 14 mm</fact17>, <fact18>CD4+ T cell count is 370/μL</fact18>, and <fact19>HIV RNA is 2,900 copies/mL</fact19>. What is the most appropriate initial step in treatment?

Answer: The patient's symptoms of <fact13>fever and significantly increased cough for 3 days</fact13>, along with <fact14>generalized lymphadenopathy</fact14>, <fact15>pulmonary infiltrates and mediastinal lymphadenopathy on chest radiograph</fact15>, and a significant increase in <fact17>Mantoux test</fact17> and <fact18>CD4+ T cell count</fact18>, suggest an immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS) due to the initiation of <fact12>antiretroviral therapy</fact12>. IRIS is a known complication of starting antiretroviral therapy in patients with tuberculosis and HIV co-infection. The appropriate management of IRIS typically involves continuing the <fact9>antitubercular therapy</fact9> and <fact12>antiretroviral therapy</fact12> without any changes, as discontinuing antiretroviral therapy can lead to worsening of the HIV infection and discontinuing antitubercular therapy can lead to worsening of the tuberculosis. Therefore, the most appropriate initial step in treatment is to continue the current regimen without any changes.

question:
A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of decreased appetite and abdominal pain for the last several weeks. Physical examination shows a well-appearing toddler with a palpable left-sided abdominal mass that does not cross the midline. A CT of the abdomen shows a large, necrotic tumor on the left kidney. Histological examination of the kidney mass shows primitive blastemal cells and immature tubules and glomeruli. This tissue is most likely derived from the same embryological structure as which of the following?
A) Carotid body
B) Adrenal medulla
C) Thyroid gland
D) Papillary muscles
E) Anterior pituitary
"
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>2-year-old boy</fact1> is brought to the physician because of <fact2>decreased appetite and abdominal pain</fact2> for the last several weeks. Physical examination shows a well-appearing toddler with a <fact3>palpable left-sided abdominal mass</fact3> that does not cross the midline. A <fact4>CT of the abdomen</fact4> shows a large, <fact5>necrotic tumor on the left kidney</fact5>. Histological examination of the kidney mass shows <fact6>primitive blastemal cells and immature tubules and glomeruli</fact6>. This tissue is most likely derived from the same embryological structure as which of the following?
A) Carotid body
B) Adrenal medulla
C) Thyroid gland
D) Papillary muscles
E) Anterior pituitary

Answer: 
Considering the <fact1>2-year-old boy's</fact1> presentation with a <fact3>palpable left-sided abdominal mass</fact3> and the <fact4>CT of the abdomen</fact4> showing a large, <fact5>necrotic tumor on the left kidney</fact5>, along with the histological findings of <fact6>primitive blastemal cells and immature tubules and glomeruli</fact6>, the diagnosis is likely Wilms tumor, a type of kidney cancer that typically affects children. Wilms tumor arises from the metanephric blastema, which is the embryological structure that gives rise to the kidney. Another structure that develops from the same neural crest cells as the metanephric blastema is the adrenal medulla. Therefore, the tissue is most likely derived from the same embryological structure as the <fact7>adrenal medulla</fact7>. The answer is {B}.

question:
A 68-year-old man presents with difficulty breathing for the last 3 hours. Upon asking about other symptoms, he mentions that he had a cough for the last 4 months which he attributes to his smoking. He says he had frequent nasal stuffiness and headaches over the last 3 months, for which he takes over-the-counter cold medications and analgesics. Over the last 2 months, he often felt that his face was mildly swollen, especially in the morning hours, but he did not consider it to be anything serious. No significant past medical history. He reports a 20-pack-year smoking history. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.4°F), pulse is 96/min, blood pressure is 108/78 mm Hg, and the respiratory rate is 24/min. On physical examination, auscultation of the chest reveals rhonchi and crepitus over the right lung. The remainder of the exam is unremarkable. A chest radiograph reveals a mass in the middle lobe of the right lung. Which of the following clinical signs would most likely be present in this patient?
A) Bilateral pedal edema
B) Distended veins over lower abdomen
C) Papilledema
D) Positive Adson test
E) Sensory loss over the ulnar aspect of right forearm and right hand
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>68-year-old man</fact1> presents with <fact2>difficulty breathing for the last 3 hours</fact2>. Upon asking about other symptoms, he mentions that he had a <fact3>cough for the last 4 months</fact3> which he attributes to his <fact4>smoking</fact4>. He says he had <fact5>requent nasal stuffiness and headaches</fact5> over the last <fact6>3 months</fact6>, for which he takes over-the-counter cold medications and analgesics. Over the last <fact7>2 months</fact7>, he often felt that his <fact8>face was mildly swollen, especially in the morning hours</fact8>, but he did not consider it to be anything serious. No significant past medical history. He reports a <fact9>20-pack-year smoking history</fact9>. His <fact10>temperature is 36.8°C (98.4°F)</fact10>, <fact11>pulse is 96/min</fact11>, <fact12>blood pressure is 108/78 mm Hg</fact12>, and the <fact13>respiratory rate is 24/min</fact13>. On physical examination, <fact14>auscultation of the chest reveals rhonchi and crepitus over the right lung</fact14>. The remainder of the exam is unremarkable. A <fact15>chest radiograph reveals a mass in the middle lobe of the right lung</fact15>. Which of the following clinical signs would most likely be present in this patient?
A) Bilateral pedal edema
B) Distended veins over lower abdomen
C) Papilledema
D) Positive Adson test
E) Sensory loss over the ulnar aspect of right forearm and right hand

Answer: Analyzing the situation, the <fact1>68-year-old man</fact1> with a <fact9>20-pack-year smoking history</fact9> presents with <fact2>difficulty breathing</fact2> and a <fact15>chest radiograph</fact15> revealing a <fact15>mass in the middle lobe of the right lung</fact15>. Given the location of the mass and the patient's symptoms, including <fact8>mild facial swelling</fact8> and <fact5>nasal stuffiness</fact5>, it is likely that the mass is causing superior vena cava syndrome (SVCS). SVCS is characterized by the obstruction of the superior vena cava, leading to increased venous pressure in the upper body. A common clinical sign of SVCS is the distension of veins over the lower abdomen and chest due to collateral circulation. Therefore, the correct answer is {B}.

question:
A 46-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 15 minutes after being involved in a motor vehicle collision where he was the unrestrained driver. On arrival, he is unconscious. His respirations are 24/min, and palpable systolic blood pressure is 60 mm Hg, and pulse is 141/min and irregularly irregular. Examination shows multiple ecchymoses over the chest. There is a 3-cm (1.2-in) laceration over the abdomen and a 4-cm (1.6-in) laceration over the scalp. Jugular venous pressure is increased. Bilateral crackles are heard at the lung bases. Cardiac examination shows no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. The abdomen is soft. Two large bore intravenous catheters are inserted and 0.9% saline infusion is begun. Focused assessment with sonography in trauma (FAST) is negative. An electrocardiogram shows absent p-waves. After 5 minutes, his pulse is 160/min and palpable systolic blood pressure is 50 mm Hg. Vasopressors are administered. One hour later, the patient dies. Which of the following was the most likely diagnosis?
A) Cardiac contusion
B) Hemothorax
C) Aortic dissection
D) Pulmonary contusion
E) Cardiac tamponade
"
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>46-year-old man</fact1> is brought to the emergency department <fact2>15 minutes after being involved in a motor vehicle collision</fact2> where he was the <fact3>unrestrained driver</fact3>. On arrival, he is <fact4>unconscious</fact4>. His <fact5>respirations are 24/min</fact5>, and <fact6>palpable systolic blood pressure is 60 mm Hg</fact6>, and <fact7>pulse is 141/min and irregularly irregular</fact7>. Examination shows <fact8>multiple ecchymoses over the chest</fact8> and a <fact9>3-cm (1.2-in) laceration over the abdomen</fact9> and a <fact10>4-cm (1.6-in) laceration over the scalp</fact10>. <fact11>Jugular venous pressure is increased</fact11>. <fact12>Bilateral crackles are heard at the lung bases</fact12>. Cardiac examination shows <fact13>no murmurs, rubs, or gallops</fact13>. The abdomen is <fact14>soft</fact14>. Two large bore intravenous catheters are inserted and <fact15>0.9% saline infusion is begun</fact15>. <fact16>FAST is negative</fact16>. An electrocardiogram shows <fact17>absent p-waves</fact17>. After 5 minutes, his <fact18>pulse is 160/min</fact18> and <fact19>palpable systolic blood pressure is 50 mm Hg</fact19>. <fact20>Vasopressors are administered</fact20>. One hour later, the patient dies. Which of the following was the most likely diagnosis?
A) Cardiac contusion
B) Hemothorax
C) Aortic dissection
D) Pulmonary contusion
E) Cardiac tamponade

Answer: Considering the patient's presentation and the provided information, the most likely diagnosis is {E} Cardiac tamponade. This conclusion is based on several key points: 
1. The patient was an <fact3>unrestrained driver</fact3> in a motor vehicle collision, which increases the risk of thoracic trauma.
2. The patient had <fact8>multiple ecchymoses over the chest</fact8>, indicating chest trauma.
3. The patient's <fact11>jugaular venous pressure is increased</fact11>, which is a sign of increased intrathoracic pressure.
4. The <fact16>FAST is negative</fact16>, which makes abdominal bleeding less likely.
5. The patient's <fact18>pulse is 160/min</fact18> and <fact19>palpable systolic blood pressure is 50 mm Hg</fact19> despite fluid resuscitation, indicating severe hypotension and tachycardia.
6. The patient's electrocardiogram shows <fact17>absent p-waves</fact17>, which can be seen in cardiac tamponade due to the compression of the heart.

While other options could also be considered based on the patient's presentation, the combination of these factors makes cardiac tamponade the most likely diagnosis.

question:
A 50-year-old woman is brought to the office by her daughter with a chief complaint of finger pain in her left hand. She is slightly confused and can’t remember when the pain started. Her daughter states that the pain has been present for approximately one month. She expresses concern that her mother has been progressively more confused during the past week. She reports that her mother also has had worsening nausea for several months. The patient’s vital signs are heart rate 92/min, respiratory rate 13/min, temperature 37.1°C (98.8°F), and blood pressure 120/86 mm Hg. Upon physical examination, the patient reports pain when the fingers of the left hand are palpated, and small palpable tumors are visible on the fingers. An X-ray image of the left-hand shows thin bones with brown tumors and osteolysis of the distal phalanges. What is the most likely cause for this patient’s condition?
A) Hyperparathyroidism
B) Hypocalcemia
C) Osteosarcoma
D) Multiple myeloma
E) Osteoporosis
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>50-year-old woman</fact1> is brought to the office by her daughter with a chief complaint of <fact2>finger pain in her left hand</fact2>. She is slightly confused and can’t remember when the pain started. Her daughter states that the pain has been present for approximately <fact3>one month</fact3>. She expresses concern that her mother has been progressively more confused during the past <fact4>week</fact4>. She reports that her mother also has had <fact5>worsening nausea for several months</fact5>. The patient’s vital signs are <fact6>heart rate 92/min, respiratory rate 13/min, temperature 37.1°C (98.8°F), and blood pressure 120/86 mm Hg</fact6>. Upon physical examination, the patient reports pain when the fingers of the left hand are palpated, and <fact7>small palpable tumors are visible on the fingers</fact7>. An X-ray image of the left-hand shows <fact8>thin bones with brown tumors and osteolysis of the distal phalanges</fact8>. What is the most likely cause for this patient’s condition?

Answer: The most likely cause of this patient's condition is {A} Hyperparathyroidism. This conclusion is based on several key findings from the case. Firstly, the presence of <fact7>small palpable tumors on the fingers</fact7> and the X-ray findings of <fact8>thin bones with brown tumors and osteolysis of the distal phalanges</fact8> are characteristic of osteitis fibrosa cystica, a condition commonly associated with hyperparathyroidism. Additionally, the patient's symptoms of <fact2>finger pain</fact2>, <fact5>worsening nausea</fact5>, and progressive confusion over the past <fact4>week</fact4> can be linked to the systemic effects of hyperparathyroidism, including hypercalcemia, which can cause neuropsychiatric symptoms and bone pain. The duration of symptoms, including pain present for approximately <fact3>one month</fact3> and worsening nausea for several months, also supports a diagnosis of a chronic condition like hyperparathyroidism.

question:
A 45-year-old woman comes into your office with complaints of "lump" she found on her neck while showering. She denies any other symptoms and states that she has not gained any weight. On exam, you notice a 2 cm nodule on her anterior neck. Her TSH level is normal and radionucleotide scan reveals a cold nodule. Fine needle aspiration biopsy (FNAB) reveals follicular architecture suspicious for malignancy. What is the next best step?
A) Punch biopsy
B) Surgical excision
C) Thyroxine administration
D) Ultrasound
E) CT scan
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>45-year-old woman</fact1> comes into your office with complaints of a <fact2>"lump" she found on her neck while showering</fact2>. She denies any other symptoms and states that she has not gained any weight. On exam, you notice a <fact3>2 cm nodule on her anterior neck</fact3>. Her <fact4>TSH level is normal</fact4> and <fact5>radionucleotide scan reveals a cold nodule</fact5>. <fact6>Fine needle aspiration biopsy (FNAB) reveals follicular architecture suspicious for malignancy</fact6>. What is the next best step?

Answer: 
Considering the <fact1>45-year-old woman's</fact1> presentation with a <fact2>palpable lump on her neck</fact2> and the findings of a <fact3>2 cm nodule on her anterior neck</fact3>, the initial evaluation of a normal <fact4>TSH level</fact4> helps to rule out thyroid dysfunction as the cause of the nodule. However, the <fact5>radionucleotide scan revealing a cold nodule</fact5> suggests that the nodule may not be producing thyroid hormones and could potentially be malignant. The <fact6>FNAB results showing follicular architecture suspicious for malignancy</fact6> further supports the need for a definitive diagnosis. Given these findings, the next best step would be to proceed with a more definitive diagnostic procedure to determine the nature of the nodule. Among the options provided, {B} Surgical excision is the most appropriate next step, as it will allow for a complete histopathological examination of the nodule and provide a definitive diagnosis, which is critical in guiding further management.

question:
A previously healthy 24-year-old man comes to the physician 1 day after the onset of burning pain, swelling, and multiple blisters over the left index finger. He works as a dental assistant and is concerned about not being able to work. The patient wonders if the symptoms might be related to a hunting trip he returned from 1 week ago because he remembers seeing a lot of poison oak. He is sexually active with one female partner, and they do not use condoms. His father has a history of thromboangiitis obliterans. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 5 years. He drinks two to four beers on social occasions. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows swelling and erythema of the pulp space of the left index finger; there are multiple 3-mm vesicles. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 12,000 cells/mm3. In addition to supportive therapy, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
A) Oral acyclovir
B) Incision and drainage of the pulp space
C) Oral cephalexin
D) Smoking cessation
E) Washing thoroughly
"
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>previously healthy 24-year-old man</fact1> comes to the physician <fact2>1 day after the onset of burning pain, swelling, and multiple blisters over the left index finger</fact2>. He works as a <fact3>dental assistant</fact3> and is concerned about not being able to work. The patient wonders if the symptoms might be related to a <fact4>hunting trip he returned from 1 week ago</fact4> because he remembers seeing a lot of <fact5>poison oak</fact5>. He is <fact6>sexually active with one female partner, and they do not use condoms</fact6>. His <fact7>father has a history of thromboangiitis obliterans</fact7>. He has <fact8>smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 5 years</fact8>. He drinks <fact9>two to four beers on social occasions</fact9>. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows <fact10>swelling and erythema of the pulp space of the left index finger; there are multiple 3-mm vesicles</fact10>. Laboratory studies show a <fact11>leukocyte count of 12,000 cells/mm3</fact11>. In addition to supportive therapy, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
A) Oral acyclovir
B) Incision and drainage of the pulp space
C) Oral cephalexin
D) Smoking cessation
E) Washing thoroughly

Answer: 
Given the <fact1>24-year-old man's</fact1> symptoms of <fact2>burning pain, swelling, and multiple blisters over the left index finger</fact2> that started <fact2>1 day ago</fact2>, along with the physical examination findings of <fact10>swelling and erythema of the pulp space of the left index finger; there are multiple 3-mm vesicles</fact10>, the most likely diagnosis is herpetic whitlow, a viral infection caused by the herpes simplex virus (HSV). This condition is common among healthcare workers, such as <fact3>dental assistants</fact3>, who are at risk of exposure to the virus through contact with infected patients. The presence of <fact11>leukocytosis (elevated leukocyte count of 12,000 cells/mm3)</fact11> further supports the diagnosis of an infectious process. The most appropriate next step in management, in addition to supportive therapy, is to initiate antiviral treatment with oral acyclovir to help manage the symptoms and reduce the risk of complications. Therefore, the answer is {A}.

question:
A 4-month-old boy is brought to the pediatrician by his parents. He presents to the pediatric ward with fever, dyspnea, and cough, which he developed 3 days ago. His mother also reports he had poor weight gain despite a good appetite during the past 2 months as well as frequent stools with an unpleasant smell. He was born at 29 weeks via spontaneous vaginal delivery. He is meeting all of his milestones and is up to date with all vaccines. The child is breastfed exclusively. His blood pressure is 80/50 mm Hg, the heart rate is 109/min, the respiratory rate is 29/min, and the temperature is 39.1°C (102.4°F). The patient’s weight is between the 5th and 10th percentile. His length is between the 50th and 75th percentile. The patient is sluggish and reacts torpidly to examination. His skin is pale and dry with decreased turgor and elasticity. On auscultation, there are diminished vesicular sounds and disseminated moist rales at the bases of both lungs. Heart sounds are normal. The abdomen is distended without palpable masses. The patient’s blood analysis shows the following findings:
Complete blood count 
 Erythrocytes  3.3 x 106/mm3
 Hb  12 g/dL
 Total leukocyte count  17,500/mm3
 Neutrophils
 59%
 Lymphocytes
 32%
 Eosinophils
 3%
 Monocytes
 6%
 Basophils
 0
Platelet count
232,000/mm3
Sputum culture grows Pseudomonas aeruginosa. A sweat test shows chloride concentration of 85 mEq/L (elevated). Which of the following is involved in the pathogenesis of this patient’s symptoms?
A) Neutrophil elastase damages lung tissue due to lack of alpha-1-antitrypsin.
B) Abnormal CFTR protein
C) Eosinophils infiltrate blood vessel walls.
D) Electron transport chain in mitochondria is disrupted due to lack of glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase.
E) Due to mutations in dynein, the ciliary epithelium fails to provide appropriate mucociliary clearance.
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>4-month-old boy</fact1> is brought to the pediatrician by his parents. He presents to the pediatric ward with <fact2>fever, dyspnea, and cough</fact2>, which he developed <fact3>3 days ago</fact3>. His mother also reports he had <fact4>poor weight gain despite a good appetite during the past 2 months</fact4> as well as <fact5>requent stools with an unpleasant smell</fact5>. He was born at <fact6>29 weeks via spontaneous vaginal delivery</fact6>. He is meeting all of his milestones and is up to date with all vaccines. The child is <fact7>breastfed exclusively</fact7>. His blood pressure is <fact8>80/50 mm Hg</fact8>, the heart rate is <fact9>109/min</fact9>, the respiratory rate is <fact10>29/min</fact10>, and the temperature is <fact11>39.1°C (102.4°F)</fact11>. The patient’s weight is between the <fact12>5th and 10th percentile</fact12>. His length is between the <fact13>50th and 75th percentile</fact13>. The patient is sluggish and reacts torpidly to examination. His skin is pale and dry with decreased turgor and elasticity. On auscultation, there are diminished vesicular sounds and disseminated moist rales at the bases of both lungs. Heart sounds are normal. The abdomen is distended without palpable masses. The patient’s blood analysis shows the following findings:
Complete blood count 
 Erythrocytes  <fact14>3.3 x 106/mm3</fact14>
 Hb  <fact15>12 g/dL</fact15>
 Total leukocyte count  <fact16>17,500/mm3</fact16>
 Neutrophils
 <fact17>59%</fact17>
 Lymphocytes
 <fact18>32%</fact18>
 Eosinophils
 <fact19>3%</fact19>
 Monocytes
 <fact20>6%</fact20>
 Basophils
 <fact21>0</fact21>
Platelet count
<fact22>232,000/mm3</fact22>
<fact23>Sputum culture grows Pseudomonas aeruginosa</fact23>. A <fact24>sweat test shows chloride concentration of 85 mEq/L (elevated)</fact24>. Which of the following is involved in the pathogenesis of this patient’s symptoms?

Answer: 
Considering the <fact1>4-month-old boy's</fact1> presentation with <fact2>fever, dyspnea, and cough</fact2> and the findings of a <fact23>sputum culture growing Pseudomonas aeruginosa</fact23> along with an <fact24>elevated chloride concentration of 85 mEq/L on a sweat test</fact24>, it is highly suggestive of Cystic Fibrosis (CF). The pathogenesis of CF is primarily due to mutations in the CFTR (cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator) gene, which encodes for a chloride channel. This results in abnormal chloride transport across epithelial membranes, leading to thickened mucus secretions that are difficult to clear, making patients more susceptible to respiratory infections, including those caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Therefore, the correct answer is {B} Abnormal CFTR protein.

question:
A 37-year-old primigravid woman at 12 weeks' gestation comes to the emergency department because of vaginal bleeding and dull suprapubic pain for 3 hours. She has had spotting during the last 3 days. Her medications include folic acid and a multivitamin. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 15 years. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 89/65 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows a dilated cervical os and a uterus consistent in size with an 11-week gestation. Ultrasonography shows an embryo of 4 cm in crown-rump length and no fetal cardiac activity. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
A) Misoprostol therapy
B) Follow-up ultrasonography
C) Methotrexate therapy
D) Dilation and curettage
E) Complete bed rest
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>37-year-old primigravid woman</fact1> at <fact2>12 weeks' gestation</fact2> comes to the emergency department because of <fact3>vaginal bleeding and dull suprapubic pain</fact3> for 3 hours. She has had <fact4>spotting during the last 3 days</fact4>. Her medications include <fact5>folic acid and a multivitamin</fact5>. She has <fact6>smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 15 years</fact6>. Her <fact7>temperature is 37°C (98.6°F)</fact7>, <fact8>pulse is 110/min</fact8>, and <fact9>blood pressure is 89/65 mm Hg</fact9>. <fact10>Pelvic examination</fact10> shows a <fact11>dilated cervical os</fact11> and a <fact12>uterus consistent in size with an 11-week gestation</fact12>. <fact13>Ultrasonography</fact13> shows an <fact14>embryo of 4 cm in crown-rump length</fact14> and <fact15>no fetal cardiac activity</fact15>. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's presentation of <fact3>vaginal bleeding and dull suprapubic pain</fact3> along with a history of <fact4>spotting during the last 3 days</fact4>, and the findings of a <fact11>dilated cervical os</fact11> and <fact15>no fetal cardiac activity</fact15> on <fact13>ultrasonography</fact13>, it is evident that the patient is experiencing a miscarriage. The most appropriate next step in management would be to complete the miscarriage and prevent potential complications. Among the options provided, dilation and curettage (D&C) is the procedure that would achieve this by dilating the cervix and removing the remaining fetal tissue from the uterus. Therefore, the answer is {D}.

question:
Two days after admission to the hospital for treatment of acute myelogenous leukemia, a 35-year-old man develops nausea, vomiting, fatigue, and muscle cramps. He has a history of diet-controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for 15 years and reports occasionally using marijuana. His temperature is 38.7°C (101.1°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 110/65 mm Hg. Laboratory studies show:
Leukocyte count 16,000/mm3
Hemoglobin 13.4 g/dL
Platelet count 180,000/mm3
Serum
Na+ 134 mEq/L
K+ 5.9 mEq/L
Cl- 101 mEq/L
HCO3- 24 mEq/L
Urea nitrogen 27 mg/dL
Uric acid 11.2 mg/dL
Creatinine 2.2 mg/dL
Glucose 134 mg/dL
Ca2+ 6.8 mg/dL
Mg2+ 1.8 g/dL
Phosphorus 8.9 mg/dL
Which of the following would have been most effective in preventing this patient's current symptoms?"
A) Urine alkalinization
B) Corticosteroids
C) Rasburicase
D) Allopurinol
E) Intravenous hydration
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>35-year-old man</fact1> develops <fact2>nausea, vomiting, fatigue, and muscle cramps</fact2> two days after admission to the hospital for treatment of <fact3>acute myelogenous leukemia</fact3>. He has a history of <fact4>diet-controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus</fact4>. He has <fact5>smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for 15 years</fact5> and reports occasionally using marijuana. His <fact6>temperature is 38.7°C (101.1°F)</fact6>, <fact7>pulse is 85/min</fact7>, <fact8>respirations are 25/min</fact8>, and <fact9>blood pressure is 110/65 mm Hg</fact9>. Laboratory studies show: 
<fact10>Leukocyte count 16,000/mm3</fact10>
<fact11>Hemoglobin 13.4 g/dL</fact11>
<fact12>Platelet count 180,000/mm3</fact12>
<fact13>Serum Na+ 134 mEq/L</fact13>
<fact14>Serum K+ 5.9 mEq/L</fact14>
<fact15>Serum Cl- 101 mEq/L</fact15>
<fact16>Serum HCO3- 24 mEq/L</fact16>
<fact17>Serum urea nitrogen 27 mg/dL</fact17>
<fact18>Serum uric acid 11.2 mg/dL</fact18>
<fact19>Serum creatinine 2.2 mg/dL</fact19>
<fact20>Serum glucose 134 mg/dL</fact20>
<fact21>Serum Ca2+ 6.8 mg/dL</fact21>
<fact22>Serum Mg2+ 1.8 g/dL</fact22>
<fact23>Serum phosphorus 8.9 mg/dL</fact23>
Which of the following would have been most effective in preventing this patient's current symptoms?

Answer: Analyzing the patient's symptoms and laboratory results, it is evident that he is experiencing tumor lysis syndrome (TLS), a complication of cancer treatment, particularly with <fact3>acute myelogenous leukemia</fact3>. TLS is characterized by the release of intracellular contents into the bloodstream, leading to hyperkalemia (<fact14>Serum K+ 5.9 mEq/L</fact14>), hyperphosphatemia (<fact23>Serum phosphorus 8.9 mg/dL</fact23>), hyperuricemia (<fact18>Serum uric acid 11.2 mg/dL</fact18>), and hypocalcemia (<fact21>Serum Ca2+ 6.8 mg/dL</fact21>). The patient's symptoms of <fact2>nausea, vomiting, fatigue, and muscle cramps</fact2> are consistent with these electrolyte imbalances. To prevent TLS, it is essential to manage the risk factors, including the use of uric acid-lowering agents. Among the options provided, <fact24>Rasburicase</fact24> is a recombinant urate oxidase that catalyzes the oxidation of uric acid to allantoin, thereby reducing uric acid levels and preventing TLS. Therefore, the most effective measure in preventing this patient's current symptoms would have been the administration of <fact24>Rasburicase</fact24>.

question:
A 14-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with hand pain after falling from his skateboard one day ago. He reports that he lost his balance while attempting a new trick and fell on his outstretched hands. He has been icing his hand and taking several tablets of ibuprofen every few hours, but the pain and swelling have not improved. The patient reports that he has not been able to use the hand to take notes in school. His past medical history is significant for infectious mononucleosis last year and type 1 diabetes mellitus for which he has an insulin pump. On physical exam, there is mild swelling over the dorsal aspect of the hand and wrist. He has tenderness in the region between the extensor pollicus longus and the extensor pollicus brevis of the right hand.

Which of the following is the best next step in management?
A) Reassurance and pain management
B) Radiograph of the wrist
C) MRI of the wrist
D) Thumb spica cast
E) Radial gutter cast
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>14-year-old boy</fact1> presents to the emergency department with <fact2>hand pain</fact2> after falling from his skateboard <fact3>one day ago</fact3>. He reports that he lost his balance while attempting a new trick and fell on his <fact4>outstretched hands</fact4>. He has been icing his hand and taking several tablets of ibuprofen every few hours, but the <fact5>pain and swelling have not improved</fact5>. The patient reports that he has not been able to use the hand to take notes in school. His past medical history is significant for <fact6>infectious mononucleosis last year</fact6> and <fact7>type 1 diabetes mellitus</fact7> for which he has an insulin pump. On physical exam, there is <fact8>mild swelling over the dorsal aspect of the hand and wrist</fact8>. He has <fact9>tenderness in the region between the extensor pollicus longus and the extensor pollicus brevis of the right hand</fact9>.

Which of the following is the best next step in management?
A) Reassurance and pain management
B) Radiograph of the wrist
C) MRI of the wrist
D) Thumb spica cast
E) Radial gutter cast

Answer: Given the patient's presentation with <fact2>hand pain</fact2> and <fact5>pain and swelling that have not improved</fact5> despite conservative management, along with <fact8>mild swelling over the dorsal aspect of the hand and wrist</fact8> and <fact9>tenderness in a specific region of the hand</fact9>, it is essential to rule out any underlying fractures or bony injuries. The mechanism of injury, falling on <fact4>outstretched hands</fact4>, increases the risk of such injuries. Therefore, the best next step in management is to obtain a <fact10>radiograph of the wrist</fact10> to evaluate for any bony abnormalities or fractures. The answer is {B}.

question:
A 49-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department with progressive dyspnea and cough which she developed approx. 8 hours ago. 2 weeks ago she had a prophylactic ovariectomy because of a family history of ovarian cancer. She is known to have type 2 diabetes mellitus and stage 1 hypertension, but she does not take her antihypertensives because she is not concerned about her blood pressure. Also, she has a history of opioid abuse. She takes metformin 1000 mg and aspirin 81 mg. She has been smoking 1 pack of cigarettes per day for 22 years. Her vital signs are as follows: blood pressure 155/80 mm Hg, heart rate 101/min, respiratory rate 31/min, and temperature 37.9℃ (100.2℉). Blood saturation on room air is 89%. On examination, the patient is dyspneic and acrocyanotic. Lung auscultation reveals bilateral rales over the lower lobes. A cardiac examination is significant for S2 accentuation best heard in the second intercostal space at the left sternal border and S3 presence. There is no leg edema. Neurological examination is within normal limits. Arterial blood gases analysis shows the following results:
pH 7.49
PaO2 58 mm Hg
PaCO2 30 mm Hg
HCO3-  22 mEq/L
Based on the given data, which of the following could cause respiratory failure in this patient?
A) Increased alveolar dead space due to absent perfusion of certain alveoli
B) Ischemia of the medullary respiratory center neurons
C) Alveolar fibrosis
D) Depression of the respiratory center via opioid receptors activation
E) Decreased V/Q due to bronchial obstruction
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>49-year-old woman</fact1> is brought to the emergency department with <fact2>progressive dyspnea and cough</fact2> which she developed approximately <fact3>8 hours ago</fact3>. <fact4>2 weeks ago she had a prophylactic ovariectomy</fact4> because of a family history of ovarian cancer. She is known to have <fact5>type 2 diabetes mellitus and stage 1 hypertension</fact5>, but she does not take her antihypertensives because she is not concerned about her blood pressure. Also, she has a <fact6>history of opioid abuse</fact6>. She takes <fact7>metformin 1000 mg and aspirin 81 mg</fact7>. She has been <fact8>smoking 1 pack of cigarettes per day for 22 years</fact8>. Her vital signs are as follows: <fact9>blood pressure 155/80 mm Hg</fact9>, <fact10>heart rate 101/min</fact10>, <fact11>respiratory rate 31/min</fact11>, and <fact12>temperature 37.9℃ (100.2℉)</fact12>. <fact13>Blood saturation on room air is 89%</fact13>. On examination, the patient is <fact14>dyspneic and acrocyanotic</fact14>. Lung auscultation reveals <fact15>bilateral rales over the lower lobes</fact15>. A cardiac examination is significant for <fact16>S2 accentuation best heard in the second intercostal space at the left sternal border and S3 presence</fact16>. There is <fact17>no leg edema</fact17>. Neurological examination is within normal limits. Arterial blood gases analysis shows the following results:
<fact18>pH 7.49</fact18>
<fact19>PaO2 58 mm Hg</fact19>
<fact20>PaCO2 30 mm Hg</fact20>
<fact21>HCO3-  22 mEq/L</fact21>
Based on the given data, which of the following could cause respiratory failure in this patient?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's symptoms of <fact2>progressive dyspnea and cough</fact2> and her history of <fact4>recent surgery</fact4> and <fact8>long-term smoking</fact8>, along with the arterial blood gases analysis showing a <fact19>low PaO2 of 58 mm Hg</fact19> and a <fact20>low PaCO2 of 30 mm Hg</fact20>, the most likely cause of respiratory failure is increased alveolar dead space due to absent perfusion of certain alveoli. This condition, known as pulmonary embolism, is a common complication following surgery and can also be associated with smoking and immobility. The patient's symptoms of <fact14>dyspnea and acrocyanosis</fact14>, <fact15>bilateral rales over the lower lobes</fact15>, and <fact16>S2 accentuation</fact16> are consistent with this diagnosis. Therefore, the answer is {A}.

question:
A 63-year-old man is admitted to the intensive care unit for hemodynamic instability. Several days prior, he had been swimming in the Gulf coast when he stepped on a sharp rock and cut his right foot. Three days ago, the patient presented to the emergency room after noticing painful redness spreading along his skin up from his right foot and was subsequently admitted for antibiotic treatment. Currently, his temperature is 101.8°F (38.8°C), blood pressure is 84/46 mmHg with a mean arterial pressure of 59 mmHg, pulse is 104/min, and respirations are 14/min. His telemetry shows sinus tachycardia. His blood cultures are pending, but Gram stain demonstrated gram-negative bacilli. Which of the following best describes the form of shock and the skin exam?
A) Cardiogenic shock with cold skin
B) Distributive shock with warm skin
C) Hypovolemic shock with warm skin
D) Neurogenic shock with cold skin
E) Obstructive shock with cold skin
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>63-year-old man</fact1> is admitted to the intensive care unit for <fact2>hemodynamic instability</fact2>. Several days prior, he had been swimming in the Gulf coast when he stepped on a <fact3>sharp rock and cut his right foot</fact3>. Three days ago, the patient presented to the emergency room after noticing <fact4>painful redness spreading along his skin up from his right foot</fact4> and was subsequently admitted for antibiotic treatment. Currently, his <fact5>temperature is 101.8°F (38.8°C)</fact5>, <fact6>blood pressure is 84/46 mmHg with a mean arterial pressure of 59 mmHg</fact6>, <fact7>pulse is 104/min</fact7>, and <fact8>respirations are 14/min</fact8>. His telemetry shows <fact9>sinus tachycardia</fact9>. His blood cultures are pending, but <fact10>Gram stain demonstrated gram-negative bacilli</fact10>. Which of the following best describes the form of shock and the skin exam?

Answer: B) Distributive shock with warm skin. 

Explanation: The patient's presentation of <fact2>hemodynamic instability</fact2> with a low <fact6>blood pressure of 84/46 mmHg</fact6> and high <fact7>pulse of 104/min</fact7> indicates shock. The <fact4>painful redness spreading along his skin</fact4> and <fact5>fever of 101.8°F (38.8°C)</fact5> suggest an infectious cause, supported by the <fact10>Gram stain demonstrating gram-negative bacilli</fact10>. These findings, along with the patient's warm skin (implied by the context of infection and inflammation), are most consistent with distributive shock, which is characterized by vasodilation and a maldistribution of blood flow.

question:
A 60-year-old woman presents to the outpatient clinic complaining of severe vulvar itching that has been gradually worsening for the past year. She mentions that she has tried over-the-counter lubricants, but lubricants do not seem to provide substantial relief. Her medical history is remarkable for diet-controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension treated with hydrochlorothiazide. Menopause occurred at 52 years of age. She has been sexually active with her husband until recently and reports severe pain during vaginal intercourse. The physical examination reveals dry, thin, white plaque-like lesions in the vulvar area with atrophy of the labia minora. The clitoris appears retracted. The perianal skin appears pale and wrinkled. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
A) Squamous cell hyperplasia
B) Lichen sclerosus
C) Squamous cell carcinoma of the vulva
D) Lichen planus
E) Atrophic vaginitis
answer:
Reformatted Question:

A <fact1>60-year-old woman</fact1> presents to the outpatient clinic complaining of <fact2>severe vulvar itching</fact2> that has been gradually worsening for the past year. She mentions that she has tried over-the-counter <fact3>lubricants</fact3>, but <fact4>lubricants do not seem to provide substantial relief</fact4>. Her medical history is remarkable for <fact5>diet-controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus</fact5> and <fact6>hypertension treated with hydrochlorothiazide</fact6>. Menopause occurred at <fact7>52 years of age</fact7>. She has been sexually active with her husband until recently and reports <fact8>severe pain during vaginal intercourse</fact8>. The physical examination reveals <fact9>dry, thin, white plaque-like lesions in the vulvar area with atrophy of the labia minora</fact9>. The clitoris appears retracted. The perianal skin appears pale and wrinkled.

Answer: Based on the information provided, the most likely diagnosis is {B}. The patient's symptoms of <fact2>severe vulvar itching</fact2> and <fact8>severe pain during vaginal intercourse</fact8>, along with the physical examination findings of <fact9>dry, thin, white plaque-like lesions in the vulvar area with atrophy of the labia minora</fact9>, are characteristic of lichen sclerosus. Additionally, the patient's history of <fact7>menopause at 52 years of age</fact7> and the presence of atrophy in the vulvar area further support this diagnosis. Lichen sclerosus is a chronic inflammatory skin condition that primarily affects the anogenital region and is more common in postmenopausal women.

question:
A 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of facial swelling that started 5 days ago. Two weeks ago, he had a sore throat that resolved spontaneously. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 107/min, and blood pressure is 94/67 mm Hg. Examination shows pitting edema of the upper and lower extremities as well as periorbital edema. The abdomen is mildly distended. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 13.1 g/dL
Serum
Albumin 2.1 g/dL
Total cholesterol 270 mg/dL
Triglycerides 175 mg/dL
Urine
Blood negative
Glucose negative
Protein 4+
Leukocyte esterase negative
A renal biopsy of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?"
A) Mesangial proliferation on light microscopy
B) Subepithelial dense deposits on electron microscopy
C) Deposits of IgG and C3 at the glomerular basement membrane on immunofluoresence
D) Normal light microscopy findings
E) Effacement of foot processes of podocytes on light microscopy
answer:
Reformatted Question:
A <fact1>5-year-old boy</fact1> is brought to the physician because of <fact2>facial swelling that started 5 days ago</fact2>. Two weeks ago, he had a <fact3>sore throat that resolved spontaneously</fact3>. His <fact4>temperature is 37°C (98.6°F)</fact4>, <fact5>pulse is 107/min</fact5>, and <fact6>blood pressure is 94/67 mm Hg</fact6>. Examination shows <fact7>pitting edema of the upper and lower extremities as well as periorbital edema</fact7>. The abdomen is mildly distended. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 13.1 g/dL
Serum
Albumin <fact8>2.1 g/dL</fact8>
Total cholesterol <fact9>270 mg/dL</fact9>
Triglycerides <fact10>175 mg/dL</fact10>
Urine
Blood negative
Glucose negative
Protein <fact11>4+</fact11>
Leukocyte esterase negative
A renal biopsy of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's presentation with <fact2>facial swelling</fact2> and <fact7>pitting edema</fact7>, along with laboratory findings of <fact8>low serum albumin</fact8>, <fact9>high total cholesterol</fact9>, and <fact10>high triglycerides</fact10>, as well as <fact11>significant proteinuria</fact11>, the patient's condition is highly suggestive of nephrotic syndrome. Among the provided options, choice B describes subepithelial dense deposits on electron microscopy, which is characteristic of minimal change disease, the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children. Therefore, the answer is {B}.

question:
An otherwise healthy 49-year-old woman has a routine full blood count complete prior her elective cholecystectomy. The lab test results are as follows:
Laboratory test
Hemoglobin
12.1 g/dL
Mean corpuscular volume (MCV)
85 μm3
Mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration (MCHC)
47%
Reticulocyte count
3.4 %
White blood cell count
9700/mm3
Platelet count
229,000/mm3
A peripheral blood smear reveals spherocytes. The Coombs test is negative. The physical examination is remarkable for scleral icterus and moderate splenomegaly. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic test of this patient’s underlying disorder?
A) Eosin-5-maleimide binding test
B) Flow cytometry for CD55/CD59
C) Anti parvovirus B19 antibodies
D) Bone marrow biopsy
E) Liver function tests
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
An otherwise healthy <fact1>49-year-old woman</fact1> has a routine full blood count complete prior her elective cholecystectomy. The lab test results are as follows:
Laboratory test
Hemoglobin
<fact2>12.1 g/dL</fact2>
Mean corpuscular volume (MCV)
<fact3>85 μm3</fact3>
Mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration (MCHC)
<fact4>47%</fact4>
Reticulocyte count
<fact5>3.4 %</fact5>
White blood cell count
<fact6>9700/mm3</fact6>
Platelet count
<fact7>229,000/mm3</fact7>
A peripheral blood smear reveals <fact8>spherocytes</fact8>. The <fact9>Coombs test is negative</fact9>. The physical examination is remarkable for <fact10>scleral icterus</fact10> and <fact11>moderate splenomegaly</fact11>. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic test of this patient’s underlying disorder?

Answer: 
Given the patient's lab results, including a low <fact2>hemoglobin level of 12.1 g/dL</fact2>, a normal <fact3>MCV of 85 μm3</fact3>, a high <fact4>MCHC of 47%</fact4>, an elevated <fact5>reticulocyte count of 3.4 %</fact5>, and the presence of <fact8>spherocytes</fact8> on the peripheral blood smear, along with a negative <fact9>Coombs test</fact9>, these findings are suggestive of hereditary spherocytosis. This condition is characterized by the production of abnormal, sphere-shaped red blood cells that are prone to premature destruction, leading to hemolytic anemia. The patient's physical examination findings of <fact10>scleral icterus</fact10> and <fact11>moderate splenomegaly</fact11> further support this diagnosis, as they are indicative of jaundice and splenic enlargement, respectively, which are common in hereditary spherocytosis. To confirm the diagnosis, the most appropriate diagnostic test would be the <fact12>Eosin-5-maleimide binding test</fact12>, which is a flow cytometric test that detects the amount of eosin-5-maleimide (EMA) bound to red blood cells. In hereditary spherocytosis, there is a deficiency of the band 3 protein on the red blood cell membrane, leading to reduced EMA binding. Therefore, the answer is {A}.

question:
A 54-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. He was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 1 year ago. His only medication is metformin. His serum glucose is 186 mg/dL and his hemoglobin A1c is 7.6%. The physician prescribes an additional antidiabetic drug and counsels the patient on its delayed onset of action. At a follow-up appointment 4 weeks later, the patient reports that his home blood glucose readings have improved. He also mentions that he has had a weight gain of 4 kg (8.8 lb). The patient has most likely been treated with which of the following drugs?
A) Empagliflozin
B) Liraglutide
C) Rosiglitazone
D) Glyburide
E) Sitagliptin
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>54-year-old man</fact1> comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. He was diagnosed with <fact2>type 2 diabetes mellitus 1 year ago</fact2>. His only medication is <fact3>metformin</fact3>. His <fact4>serum glucose is 186 mg/dL</fact4> and his <fact5>hemoglobin A1c is 7.6%</fact5>. The physician prescribes an additional antidiabetic drug and counsels the patient on its <fact6>delayed onset of action</fact6>. At a follow-up appointment <fact7>4 weeks later</fact7>, the patient reports that his home blood glucose readings have improved. He also mentions that he has had a <fact8>weight gain of 4 kg (8.8 lb)</fact8>. The patient has most likely been treated with which of the following drugs?

Answer: Analyzing the situation, the <fact1>54-year-old man</fact1> with <fact2>type 2 diabetes mellitus</fact2> was initially on <fact3>metformin</fact3> but required additional medication due to a <fact4>serum glucose of 186 mg/dL</fact4> and <fact5>hemoglobin A1c of 7.6%</fact5>. The newly prescribed medication had a <fact6>delayed onset of action</fact6> and led to improved blood glucose readings within <fact7>4 weeks</fact7>. Notably, the patient experienced a <fact8>weight gain of 4 kg (8.8 lb)</fact8>. Considering these factors, the medication most likely prescribed is one that is known for its delayed onset of action and potential for weight gain. Among the options provided, thiazolidinediones like <fact9>Rosiglitazone</fact9> are known for these characteristics. Therefore, the answer is {C}.

question:
A 71-year-old woman comes to the physician for evaluation of a pigmented lesion on her left foot. She has had decreased appetite and a 6-kg (13-lb) weight loss in the past 2 months. Physical examination shows that on the left medial ankle there is a 2-cm reddish-black nodule with a verrucous surface. A full-thickness excisional biopsy of the lesion shows S100-protein-positive epithelioid cells. A subsequent CT scan of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis shows metastases to the liver; a diagnosis of metastatic melanoma is made. Chemotherapy with aldesleukin is initiated. Which of the following is the mechanism of action for this drug?
A) Stimulating release of acute-phase reactants
B) Stimulating antigen-processing cells
C) Inhibiting expression of MHC II and Th1 cytokines
D) Activating natural killer cells and cytotoxic T cells
E) Supporting growth of bone marrow stem cells
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>71-year-old woman</fact1> comes to the physician for evaluation of a <fact2>pigmented lesion on her left foot</fact2>. She has had <fact3>decreased appetite and a 6-kg (13-lb) weight loss in the past 2 months</fact3>. Physical examination shows that on the left medial ankle there is a <fact4>2-cm reddish-black nodule with a verrucous surface</fact4>. A full-thickness excisional biopsy of the lesion shows <fact5>S100-protein-positive epithelioid cells</fact5>. A subsequent <fact6>CT scan of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis shows metastases to the liver</fact6>; a diagnosis of <fact7>metastatic melanoma</fact7> is made. Chemotherapy with <fact8>aldesleukin</fact8> is initiated. Which of the following is the mechanism of action for this drug?
A) Stimulating release of acute-phase reactants
B) Stimulating antigen-processing cells
C) Inhibiting expression of MHC II and Th1 cytokines
D) Activating natural killer cells and cytotoxic T cells
E) Supporting growth of bone marrow stem cells

Answer: 
Considering the patient's diagnosis of <fact7>metastatic melanoma</fact7> and the initiation of chemotherapy with <fact8>aldesleukin</fact8>, it is essential to understand the mechanism of action of this drug. Aldesleukin, also known as interleukin-2 (IL-2), is an immunotherapy agent that plays a crucial role in the immune system. The correct answer is {D} Activating natural killer cells and cytotoxic T cells. This is because IL-2 stimulates the growth, proliferation, and survival of T cells, which are vital for the immune response against cancer cells. By activating natural killer cells and cytotoxic T cells, aldesleukin enhances the body's ability to recognize and destroy cancer cells, making it an effective treatment for metastatic melanoma.

question:
A 13-year-old boy is brought to his pediatrician due to a left breast lump under his nipple. He noticed it last month and felt that it has increased slightly in size. It is tender to touch but has no overlying skin changes. There is no breast discharge. The patient has cryptorchidism as an infant and underwent a successful orchiopexy. In addition, he was recently diagnosed with ADHD and is currently on methylphenidate with improvement in his symptoms. He has a family history of type I diabetes in his father and breast fibroadenoma in his mother. On exam, the patient is at the 82nd percentile for height, 79th percentile for weight, and 80th percentile for BMI. He has tanner IV pubic hair. Testicular volume is 7 mL on each side, and both testes are smooth and freely mobile. Breast exam shows a normal right breast and a 3-centimeter round, firm, and slightly tender discrete mass under the left nipple. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s condition?
A) Klinefelter syndrome
B) Glandular tissue enlargement
C) Lipomastia (pseudogynecomastia)
D) Testicular cancer
E) Medication side effect
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>13-year-old boy</fact1> is brought to his pediatrician due to a <fact2>left breast lump under his nipple</fact2>. He noticed it last month and felt that it has <fact3>increased slightly in size</fact3>. It is <fact4>tender to touch</fact4> but has no overlying skin changes. There is no breast discharge. The patient has <fact5>cryptorchidism as an infant</fact5> and underwent a successful <fact6>orchiopexy</fact6>. In addition, he was recently diagnosed with <fact7>ADHD</fact7> and is currently on <fact8>methylphenidate</fact8> with improvement in his symptoms. He has a family history of <fact9>type I diabetes in his father</fact9> and <fact10>breast fibroadenoma in his mother</fact10>. On exam, the patient is at the <fact11>82nd percentile for height</fact11>, <fact12>79th percentile for weight</fact12>, and <fact13>80th percentile for BMI</fact13>. He has <fact14>Tanner IV pubic hair</fact14>. Testicular volume is <fact15>7 mL on each side</fact15>, and both testes are smooth and freely mobile. Breast exam shows a normal right breast and a <fact16>3-centimeter round, firm, and slightly tender discrete mass under the left nipple</fact16>. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s condition?

Answer: Considering the patient's age and physical examination findings, particularly the presence of a <fact16>3-centimeter round, firm, and slightly tender discrete mass under the left nipple</fact16> and <fact14>Tanner IV pubic hair</fact14>, it is likely that the patient is experiencing a normal physiological change during puberty. The most common cause of a breast lump in a male during puberty is glandular tissue enlargement, also known as pubertal gynecomastia. This condition is usually self-limiting and resolves on its own within a few years. The patient's <fact11>height</fact11>, <fact12>weight</fact12>, and <fact13>BMI</fact13> percentiles are within a normal range, and there are no indications of hormonal imbalances or other underlying conditions that could cause gynecomastia. Therefore, the most likely etiology of this patient's condition is glandular tissue enlargement, also known as pubertal gynecomastia. The answer is {B}.

question:
A 39-year-old woman presents with headaches, constipation, increased thirst, and increased urinary frequency. Her blood pressure is 160/100 mm Hg and pulse is 67/min. Blood tests reveal high blood glucose and low potassium level. Abdominal CT scan shows a well-circumscribed homogeneous mass in the left adrenal gland. The hormone excess responsible for her symptoms uses which of the following pathways to exert its action?
A) Intracellular receptors
B) Tyrosine kinase receptors
C) cAMP pathway
D) cGMP pathway
E) JAK/STAT pathway
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>39-year-old woman</fact1> presents with <fact2>headaches, constipation, increased thirst, and increased urinary frequency</fact2>. Her <fact3>blood pressure is 160/100 mm Hg</fact3> and <fact4>pulse is 67/min</fact4>. Blood tests reveal <fact5>high blood glucose</fact5> and <fact6>low potassium level</fact6>. Abdominal CT scan shows a <fact7>well-circumscribed homogeneous mass in the left adrenal gland</fact7>. The hormone excess responsible for her symptoms uses which of the following pathways to exert its action?

Answer: 
Considering the <fact1>39-year-old woman's</fact1> symptoms of <fact2>headaches, constipation, increased thirst, and increased urinary frequency</fact2>, along with the findings of <fact3>high blood pressure</fact3>, <fact5>high blood glucose</fact5>, and <fact6>low potassium level</fact6>, these are indicative of excess aldosterone, a condition known as Conn's syndrome or primary aldosteronism. The <fact7>well-circumscribed homogeneous mass in the left adrenal gland</fact7> further supports this diagnosis, as it is likely an aldosterone-producing adenoma. Aldosterone acts through the <fact8>cAMP pathway</fact8> to exert its effects on electrolyte balance and blood pressure. Therefore, the correct answer is {C}.

question:
A 5-day-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of a 1-day history of poor feeding, irritability, and noisy breathing. The mother did not receive any prenatal care. His respirations are 26/min. Physical examination shows sunken fontanelles, tightly clenched fists, and erythema around the umbilical cord stump. Which of the following best describes the pathogenesis of the disease process in this patient?
A) Decreased release of acetylcholine
B) Inhibition of voltage-gated sodium channels
C) Destruction of Schwann cells
D) Decreased release of glycine
E) Destruction of anterior horn cells
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>5-day-old boy</fact1> is brought to the emergency department because of a <fact2>1-day history of poor feeding, irritability, and noisy breathing</fact2>. The mother did not receive any <fact3>prenatal care</fact3>. His <fact4>respirations are 26/min</fact4>. Physical examination shows <fact5>sunken fontanelles, tightly clenched fists, and erythema around the umbilical cord stump</fact5>. Which of the following best describes the pathogenesis of the disease process in this patient?

A) Decreased release of acetylcholine
B) Inhibition of voltage-gated sodium channels
C) Destruction of Schwann cells
D) Decreased release of glycine
