She adds that he vomited repeatedly  in the last couple of hours, his vomitus being brown/red in color. His temperature is 98.6°F (37°C), respiratory rate is 16/min, pulse is 97/min, and blood pressure is 100/68 mm Hg. A physical exam reveals a tense abdomen with a board like rigidity and positive rebound tenderness. An erect abdominal x-ray is ordered. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
A) Duodenal peptic ulcer
B) Gastric peptic ulcer
C) Pancreatitis
D) Perforated gastric peptic ulcer
E) Choledocholithiasis
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>55-year-old man</fact1> is brought to the emergency room by his wife for <fact2>severe abdominal pain</fact2> for the past <fact3>1 hour</fact3>. He is unable to give more information about the nature of his pain. His wife says that he has <fact4>peptic ulcer disease</fact4> and is being treated with antacids without a good response. She adds that he <fact5>vomited repeatedly</fact5> in the last couple of hours, his <fact6>vomitus being brown/red in color</fact6>. His <fact7>temperature is 98.6°F (37°C)</fact7>, <fact8>respiratory rate is 16/min</fact8>, <fact9>pulse is 97/min</fact9>, and <fact10>blood pressure is 100/68 mm Hg</fact10>. A physical exam reveals a <fact11>tense abdomen with a board like rigidity</fact11> and <fact12>positive rebound tenderness</fact12>. An erect abdominal x-ray is ordered. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
A) Duodenal peptic ulcer
B) Gastric peptic ulcer
C) Pancreatitis
D) Perforated gastric peptic ulcer
E) Choledocholithiasis

Answer: Considering the <fact1>55-year-old man's</fact1> presentation with <fact2>severe abdominal pain</fact2> that started <fact3>1 hour ago</fact3> and his history of <fact4>peptic ulcer disease</fact4>, the acute onset of symptoms and the physical exam findings of a <fact11>tense abdomen with a board like rigidity</fact11> and <fact12>positive rebound tenderness</fact12> suggest a perforation of the gastrointestinal tract. The fact that he <fact5>vomited repeatedly</fact5> with <fact6>brown/red vomitus</fact6> indicates that the bleeding is likely coming from the upper gastrointestinal tract. Among the options, a <fact4>peptic ulcer disease</fact4> complication that matches this presentation is a perforated gastric peptic ulcer, which would cause severe abdominal pain, tenderness, and rigidity due to peritonitis. Therefore, the most likely diagnosis is {D}.

question:
A 40-year-old man comes to the physician for the evaluation of a painless right-sided scrotal swelling. The patient reports that he first noticed the swelling several weeks ago, but it is not always present. He has hypertension treated with enalapril. His father was diagnosed with a seminoma at the age of 25 years. The patient has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 20 years. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a 10-cm, soft, cystic, nontender right scrotal mass that transilluminates. The mass does not increase in size on coughing and it is possible to palpate normal tissue above the mass. There are no bowel sounds in the mass, and it does not reduce when the patient is in a supine position. Examination of the testis shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the mass?
A) Patent processus vaginalis
B) Dilation of the pampiniform plexus
C) Twisting of the spermatic cord
D) Imbalance of fluid secretion and resorption by the tunica vaginalis
E) Impaired lymphatic drainage
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>40-year-old man</fact1> comes to the physician for the evaluation of a <fact2>painless right-sided scrotal swelling</fact2>. The patient reports that he first noticed the swelling several weeks ago, but it is not always present. He has <fact3>hypertension treated with enalapril</fact3>. His <fact4>father was diagnosed with a seminoma at the age of 25 years</fact4>. The patient has <fact5>smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 20 years</fact5>. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a <fact6>10-cm, soft, cystic, nontender right scrotal mass that transilluminates</fact6>. The mass does not increase in size on coughing and it is possible to palpate normal tissue above the mass. There are no bowel sounds in the mass, and it does not reduce when the patient is in a supine position. Examination of the testis shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the mass?
A) Patent processus vaginalis
B) Dilation of the pampiniform plexus
C) Twisting of the spermatic cord
D) Imbalance of fluid secretion and resorption by the tunica vaginalis
E) Impaired lymphatic drainage

Answer: 
Considering the <fact1>40-year-old man's</fact1> presentation with a <fact2>painless right-sided scrotal swelling</fact2> that is <fact6>soft, cystic, and nontender</fact6>, and <fact6>transilluminates</fact6>, the most likely diagnosis is a hydrocele. A hydrocele is caused by an <fact7>imbalance of fluid secretion and resorption by the tunica vaginalis</fact7>, which surrounds the testis. This condition is characterized by the accumulation of fluid around the testis, resulting in scrotal swelling. The fact that the mass does not increase in size on coughing and it is possible to palpate normal tissue above the mass further supports this diagnosis. Additionally, the absence of bowel sounds in the mass and the lack of reduction in size when the patient is in a supine position rule out other possible causes such as a hernia. Therefore, the most likely cause of the mass is {D}.

question:
A 4-year-old boy with acute lymphoblastic leukemia is admitted to the hospital to undergo allogeneic bone marrow transplantation. Two weeks after the conditioning regimen is started, he develops a temperature of 38.5°C (101.3°F). Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 8 g/dL
Leukocyte count 1400/mm3
Segmented neutrophils 20%
Eosinophils 0.5%
Lymphocytes 87%
Monocytes 1%
Platelet count 110,000/mm3
Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient?"
A) Alkylating chemotherapeutic agent
B) Transforming growth factor-β
C) Erythropoietin
D) Interleukin-5
E) Granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>4-year-old boy</fact1> with <fact2>acute lymphoblastic leukemia</fact2> is admitted to the hospital to undergo <fact3>allogeneic bone marrow transplantation</fact3>. Two weeks after the <fact4>conditioning regimen</fact4> is started, he develops a <fact5>temperature of 38.5°C (101.3°F)</fact5>. Laboratory studies show: 
Hemoglobin 8 g/dL
Leukocyte count 1400/mm3
Segmented neutrophils 20%
Eosinophils 0.5%
<fact6>Lymphocytes 87%</fact6>
<fact7>Monocytes 1%</fact7>
<fact8>Platelet count 110,000/mm3</fact8>
Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this patient?

Answer: 
Given the patient's condition, specifically the <fact5>fever of 38.5°C (101.3°F)</fact5> and laboratory results showing a <fact6>high percentage of lymphocytes</fact6> but a low count of <fact7>monocytes</fact7> and <fact8>platelet count of 110,000/mm3</fact8>, it is clear that the patient is immunocompromised and at risk of infection. The most appropriate pharmacotherapy in this scenario would be to stimulate the production of white blood cells, particularly granulocytes and macrophages, to help fight off infections. Among the options provided, the best answer is {E}, Granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor, as it promotes the proliferation and differentiation of hematopoietic progenitor cells into granulocytes and macrophages, which are essential for combating infections.

question:
A 63-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of fatigue and shortness of breath on exertion in addition to a 1-month history of ankle swelling. She has a history of sleep apnea. Examination of the lower extremities shows bilateral pitting pedal and ankle edema. Cardiac examination shows a widely split S2 that varies with respiration. An ECG shows right bundle branch block. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of the patient's lower extremity edema?
A) Localized lymphatic obstruction
B) Dermal accumulation of glycosaminoglycans
C) Thrombus formation in a deep vein
D) Increased capillary hydrostatic pressure
E) Decreased plasma oncotic pressure
"
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>63-year-old woman</fact1> comes to the physician because of a <fact2>6-month history of fatigue and shortness of breath on exertion</fact2> in addition to a <fact3>1-month history of ankle swelling</fact3>. She has a <fact4>history of sleep apnea</fact4>. Examination of the lower extremities shows <fact5>bilateral pitting pedal and ankle edema</fact5>. Cardiac examination shows a <fact6>widely split S2 that varies with respiration</fact6>. An ECG shows <fact7>right bundle branch block</fact7>. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of the patient's lower extremity edema?
A) Localized lymphatic obstruction
B) Dermal accumulation of glycosaminoglycans
C) Thrombus formation in a deep vein
D) Increased capillary hydrostatic pressure
E) Decreased plasma oncotic pressure

Answer: D) Increased capillary hydrostatic pressure

Explanation: The patient's presentation of <fact5>bilateral pitting pedal and ankle edema</fact5> along with a <fact6>widely split S2 that varies with respiration</fact6> and a history of <fact2>fatigue and shortness of breath on exertion</fact2> is suggestive of heart failure or a condition leading to increased pressure in the heart. The presence of <fact7>right bundle branch block</fact7> on ECG further supports this, as it can be a sign of heart failure or pulmonary hypertension. Given these findings, the most likely etiology of the patient's lower extremity edema is <fact8>increased capillary hydrostatic pressure</fact8>, which occurs when there is increased pressure within the capillaries, causing fluid to leak into the interstitial space and resulting in edema.

question:
A 26-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up vaccination 1 week after being bitten by a rodent while camping. She received appropriate post-exposure prophylaxis in the emergency department and has already received 2 doses of the rabies vaccine. The same physician has been managing the post-exposure care regimen. After the physician administers the third dose of the rabies vaccine, the patient asks him if he would like to join her for a movie and dinner. The physician is interested in going on a date with her. Which of the following is the most appropriate reaction for the physician to have to the patient's invitation?
A) Inform the patient that romantic relationships with current patients are unethical.
B) Inform the patient that he will go on a date with her because her case is uncomplicated and does not require decision-making on his part.
C) Inform the patient that dating her will never be appropriate even once the physician-patient relationship has been terminated.
D) Inform the patient that he will go on a date with her, but that she will have to transfer her care to a different physician.
E) Inform the patient that he will go on a date with her because she no longer requires his service as a physician.
"
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>26-year-old woman</fact1> comes to the physician for a follow-up vaccination 1 week after being bitten by a rodent while camping. She received appropriate post-exposure prophylaxis in the emergency department and has already received <fact2>2 doses of the rabies vaccine</fact2>. The same physician has been managing the post-exposure care regimen. After the physician administers the <fact3>third dose of the rabies vaccine</fact3>, the patient asks him if he would like to join her for a movie and dinner. The physician is interested in going on a date with her. Which of the following is the most appropriate reaction for the physician to have to the patient's invitation?

Answer: 
Considering the physician-patient relationship established between the <fact1>26-year-old woman</fact1> and the physician, with the physician managing her post-exposure care regimen and administering <fact2>2 doses of the rabies vaccine</fact2> and the <fact3>third dose of the rabies vaccine</fact3>, it is essential to prioritize professional boundaries. The most appropriate reaction for the physician to have to the patient's invitation is to inform the patient that romantic relationships with current patients are unethical. This is because the power dynamic in the physician-patient relationship can create an unequal and potentially exploitative situation. Therefore, the answer is {A}.

question:
A 34-year-old woman is assaulted and suffers a number of stab wounds to her abdomen. Bystanders call paramedics and she is subsequently taken to the nearest hospital. On arrival to the emergency department, her vitals are T: 36 deg C, HR: 110 bpm, BP: 100/60, RR: 12, SaO2: 99%. A FAST and abdominal CT are promptly obtained which are demonstrated in Figures A and B, respectively. Her chart demonstrates no other medical problems and vaccinations/boosters up to date. The patient is diagnosed with a Grade V splenic laceration and is immediately brought to the OR for emergent splenectomy. The splenectomy is successfully performed with removal of the damaged spleen (Figure C). Following the operation, the patient should receive which of the following vaccines: (I) H. influenzae (II) Tetanus (III) N. meningitidis (IV) S. pneumoniae (V) Hepatitis B
A) I, II
B) I, III, IV
C) I, V
D) II only
E) III, IV
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>34-year-old woman</fact1> is assaulted and suffers a number of <fact2>stab wounds to her abdomen</fact2>. Bystanders call paramedics and she is subsequently taken to the nearest hospital. On arrival to the emergency department, her vitals are <fact3>T: 36 deg C, HR: 110 bpm, BP: 100/60, RR: 12, SaO2: 99%</fact3>. A <fact4>FAST and abdominal CT</fact4> are promptly obtained. Her chart demonstrates <fact5>no other medical problems</fact5> and <fact6>vaccinations/boosters up to date</fact6>. The patient is diagnosed with a <fact7>Grade V splenic laceration</fact7> and is immediately brought to the OR for emergent <fact8>splenectomy</fact8>. The <fact8>splenectomy</fact8> is successfully performed with removal of the damaged spleen. Following the operation, the patient should receive which of the following vaccines: (I) H. influenzae (II) Tetanus (III) N. meningitidis (IV) S. pneumoniae (V) Hepatitis B

Answer: B) I, III, IV

question:
A 36-year-old woman comes to the physician for intermittent stabbing face pain. The pain typically occurs in waves of several individual episodes lasting about one second. It is bilateral, but rarely occurs on both sides simultaneously. Touching her face or brushing her teeth can trigger an attack. Four months ago, she had an episode of weakness in her right arm that lasted for about a week. Family history is notable for migrainous headaches in her mother and brother. Vital signs are within normal limits. There is decreased sensation in the V2 and V3 distribution of her face bilaterally. Muscle strength is 3/5 in the left upper extremity and 5/5 in the right upper extremity. There is spasticity of the lower extremities with sustained clonus. Further evaluation is most likely going to reveal which of the following findings?
A) Gingival swelling, erythema, and pus drainage
B) Multiple periventricular sclerotic plaques
C) Erythematous papules in the V2/V3 nerve distribution
D) Photophobia and phonophobia
E) Rhinorrhea, lacrimination, and ptosis
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>36-year-old woman</fact1> comes to the physician for <fact2>intermittent stabbing face pain</fact2>. The pain typically occurs in <fact3>waves of several individual episodes lasting about one second</fact3>. It is <fact4>bilateral, but rarely occurs on both sides simultaneously</fact4>. <fact5>Touching her face or brushing her teeth can trigger an attack</fact5>. Four months ago, she had an <fact6>episode of weakness in her right arm that lasted for about a week</fact6>. Family history is notable for <fact7>migrainous headaches in her mother and brother</fact7>. Vital signs are within normal limits. There is <fact8>decreased sensation in the V2 and V3 distribution of her face bilaterally</fact8>. Muscle strength is <fact9>3/5 in the left upper extremity and 5/5 in the right upper extremity</fact9>. There is <fact10>spasticity of the lower extremities with sustained clonus</fact10>. Further evaluation is most likely going to reveal which of the following findings?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's symptoms of <fact2>intermittent stabbing face pain</fact2> that is <fact4>bilateral, but rarely occurs on both sides simultaneously</fact4> and can be triggered by <fact5>touching her face or brushing her teeth</fact5>, along with the presence of <fact8>decreased sensation in the V2 and V3 distribution of her face bilaterally</fact8>, this presentation is suggestive of trigeminal neuralgia. Additionally, the patient's history of <fact6>an episode of weakness in her right arm</fact6> and the current findings of <fact9>muscle strength 3/5 in the left upper extremity</fact9> and <fact10>spasticity of the lower extremities with sustained clonus</fact10> indicate the possibility of a demyelinating disease. Among the options provided, the finding of <fact11>multiple periventricular sclerotic plaques</fact11> is most consistent with Multiple Sclerosis (MS), a condition known to cause both trigeminal neuralgia and demyelinating lesions in the central nervous system. Therefore, the correct answer is {B}.

question:
A 72-year-old man with hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus is admitted to the hospital for the evaluation of breathlessness and fatigue. His pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. Further evaluation shows a systemic vascular resistance of 35 mm Hg × min/L with an end-systolic volume of 80 mL. Which of the following describes the ejection fraction in this patient?
A) 30%
B) 15%
C) 35%
D) 25%
E) 20%
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>72-year-old man</fact1> with <fact2>hypertension</fact2> and <fact3>type 2 diabetes mellitus</fact3> is admitted to the hospital for the evaluation of <fact4>breathlessness and fatigue</fact4>. His <fact5>pulse is 100/min</fact5>, and <fact6>blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg</fact6>. Further evaluation shows a <fact7>systemic vascular resistance of 35 mm Hg × min/L</fact7> with an <fact8>end-systolic volume of 80 mL</fact8>. Which of the following describes the <fact9>ejection fraction</fact9> in this patient?

Answer: To determine the ejection fraction, we need to understand that it is the fraction of the end-diastolic volume (EDV) that is ejected out of the left ventricle during systole. The formula for ejection fraction (EF) is EF = (EDV - ESV) / EDV. However, we are given the end-systolic volume (ESV) as 80 mL but not the end-diastolic volume (EDV). Nonetheless, we can infer the ejection fraction based on the provided information and typical values for a healthy heart. A normal ejection fraction is around 55-70%. Given the patient's symptoms of <fact4>breathlessness and fatigue</fact4> and the low <fact6>blood pressure of 90/60 mm Hg</fact6>, indicating possible heart failure, an ejection fraction of 25% is a reasonable estimate for this scenario, as it suggests significant impairment of the heart's pumping ability. Therefore, the answer is {D}.

question:
A 3-day-old male is evaluated in the hospital nursery for delayed passage of meconium. His mother is breastfeeding and has started to produce milk. The patient has been feeding well every two hours and is urinating over eight times per day. The patient was born at 35 weeks gestation to a 27-year-old gravida 4. The patient is of Ashkenazi Jewish descent, and the patient’s parents denied all prenatal genetic testing. The pregnancy was uncomplicated until the patient’s mother had spontaneous rupture of membranes at 35 weeks gestation. The patient’s three older siblings are all healthy. In the hospital nursery, the patient’s temperature is 98.2°F (36.8°C), blood pressure is 48/32 mmHg, pulse is 164/min, and respirations are 48/min. On physical exam, he appears to be in moderate distress. He has no dysmorphic features, and his abdomen is distended and non-tender. Bowel sounds are absent.

Which of the following is the best next step in management?
A) Abdominal CT
B) Abdominal radiograph
C) Contrast enema
D) Upper gastrointestinal series
E) Sweat testing
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>3-day-old male</fact1> is evaluated in the hospital nursery for <fact2>delayed passage of meconium</fact2>. His mother is breastfeeding and has started to produce milk. The patient has been feeding well every two hours and is urinating over eight times per day. The patient was born at <fact3>35 weeks gestation</fact3> to a 27-year-old gravida 4. The patient is of <fact4>Ashkenazi Jewish descent</fact4>, and the patient’s parents denied all prenatal genetic testing. The pregnancy was uncomplicated until the patient’s mother had spontaneous rupture of membranes at <fact3>35 weeks gestation</fact3>. The patient’s three older siblings are all healthy. In the hospital nursery, the patient’s temperature is 98.2°F (36.8°C), blood pressure is 48/32 mmHg, pulse is 164/min, and respirations are 48/min. On physical exam, he appears to be in moderate distress. He has no dysmorphic features, and his abdomen is <fact5>distended and non-tender</fact5>. Bowel sounds are absent.

Which of the following is the best next step in management?
A) Abdominal CT
B) Abdominal radiograph
C) Contrast enema
D) Upper gastrointestinal series
E) Sweat testing

Answer: Considering the <fact1>3-day-old male</fact1> with <fact2>delayed passage of meconium</fact2>, a <fact5>distended and non-tender abdomen</fact5>, and absent bowel sounds, an initial imaging study is necessary to evaluate for potential intestinal obstruction. Given the patient's age and clinical presentation, an <fact3>abdominal radiograph</fact3> is a reasonable first step to assess for signs of obstruction or other abdominal abnormalities. This non-invasive test can provide valuable information to guide further management. Therefore, the best answer is {B}.

question:
A 25-year-old woman comes to the physician because of an acute, painful swelling of the left labia that she first noticed that morning. She also reports some pain while sitting and walking. She is sexually active with her boyfriend and states that she has been having pain during vaginal intercourse lately. She has no history of serious illness. She appears uncomfortable. Her temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure 120/80 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows a left-sided, tender mass surrounded by edema and erythema in the left inner labia. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
A) Sitz baths
B) Cryotherapy
C) Incision and drainage
D) Biopsy
E) Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>25-year-old woman</fact1> comes to the physician because of an <fact2>acute, painful swelling of the left labia</fact2> that she first noticed that morning. She also reports some <fact3>pain while sitting and walking</fact3>. She is sexually active with her boyfriend and states that she has been having <fact4>pain during vaginal intercourse lately</fact4>. She has no history of serious illness. She appears uncomfortable. Her <fact5>temperature is 38°C (100.4°F)</fact5>, <fact6>pulse is 90/min</fact6>, and <fact7>blood pressure 120/80 mm Hg</fact7>. Pelvic examination shows a <fact8>left-sided, tender mass surrounded by edema and erythema in the left inner labia</fact8>. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

Answer: Considering the patient's <fact2>acute, painful swelling of the left labia</fact2> and <fact8>left-sided, tender mass surrounded by edema and erythema in the left inner labia</fact8>, along with her <fact5>fever of 38°C (100.4°F)</fact5> and <fact6>elevated pulse of 90/min</fact6>, the clinical presentation is highly suggestive of a Bartholin gland abscess. Given the presence of an abscess, the most appropriate next step in management would be to perform an incision and drainage to alleviate the patient's symptoms and prevent further complications. Therefore, the correct answer is {C}.

question:
A 37-year-old-woman presents to her primary care physician requesting a new form of birth control. She has been utilizing oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) for the past 8 years, but asks to switch to an intrauterine device (IUD). Her vital signs are: blood pressure 118/78 mm Hg, pulse 73/min and respiratory rate 16/min. She is afebrile. Physical examination is within normal limits. Which of the following past medical history statements would make copper IUD placement contraindicated in this patient?
A) A history of stroke or venous thromboembolism
B) Current tobacco use
C) Active or recurrent pelvic inflammatory disease (PID)
D) Past medical history of breast cancer
E) Known liver neoplasm
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>37-year-old-woman</fact1> presents to her primary care physician requesting a new form of birth control. She has been utilizing <fact2>oral contraceptive pills (OCPs)</fact2> for the past <fact3>8 years</fact3>, but asks to switch to an <fact4>intrauterine device (IUD)</fact4>. Her vital signs are: <fact5>blood pressure 118/78 mm Hg</fact5>, <fact6>pulse 73/min</fact6> and <fact7>respiratory rate 16/min</fact7>. She is <fact8>afebrile</fact8>. Physical examination is within normal limits. Which of the following past medical history statements would make <fact9>copper IUD placement</fact9> contraindicated in this patient?
A) A history of <fact10>stroke or venous thromboembolism</fact10>
B) Current <fact11>tobacco use</fact11>
C) Active or recurrent <fact12>pelvic inflammatory disease (PID)</fact12>
D) Past medical history of <fact13>breast cancer</fact13>
E) Known <fact14>liver neoplasm</fact14>

Answer: The correct answer is C) Active or recurrent pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). The placement of a copper IUD is contraindicated in patients with a history of active or recurrent PID, as the insertion of the device can exacerbate the infection and lead to serious complications. This is a concern because the patient is requesting a copper IUD, and PID is a relevant contraindication for this type of device.

question:
A 40-year-old obese man with a history of diabetes and chronic kidney disease presents with one day of excruciating pain, swelling, and redness in his greater toe. He denies any inciting trauma or similar prior episodes. Vital signs are stable. On examination, the right first toe is grossly erythematous and edematous, with range of motion limited due to pain. Deposition of which of the following is associated with the most likely underlying joint disorder?
A) Cholesterol
B) Calcium phosphate
C) Calcium oxalate
D) Monosodium urate
E) Copper
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>40-year-old obese man</fact1> with a <fact2>history of diabetes and chronic kidney disease</fact2> presents with <fact3>one day of excruciating pain, swelling, and redness in his greater toe</fact3>. He <fact4>denies any inciting trauma or similar prior episodes</fact4>. Vital signs are stable. On examination, the <fact5>right first toe is grossly erythematous and edematous, with range of motion limited due to pain</fact5>. Deposition of which of the following is associated with the most likely underlying joint disorder?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's presentation with <fact3>excruciating pain, swelling, and redness in his greater toe</fact3> without any <fact4>inciting trauma or similar prior episodes</fact4>, and the examination findings of a <fact5>grossly erythematous and edematous right first toe</fact5>, the clinical picture is suggestive of gout. Gout is a form of inflammatory arthritis characterized by sudden, severe attacks of pain, swelling, redness, and tenderness in the joints, often occurring at the base of the big toe. It is associated with the deposition of monosodium urate crystals within the joint. The patient's <fact1>obesity</fact1> and <fact2>history of diabetes and chronic kidney disease</fact2> are also risk factors for developing gout. Therefore, the correct answer is {D}.

question:
A 78-year-old man comes to the physician because of progressively worsening fatigue and headache for 6 months and occasional abdominal pain. He has not had any changes in his weight. He has a history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and chronic shoulder pain. Current daily medications include hydrochlorothiazide, metformin, and ibuprofen. He does not drink alcohol and does not smoke. His diet has mostly consisted of potatoes and lean meats since his wife passed away 1 year ago. His pulse is 92/min and blood pressure is 135/80 mm Hg. Examination shows conjunctival and mucosal pallor. Abdominal and rectal examination shows no abnormalities. Neurological exam shows mild postural tremor. Peripheral blood smear shows red blood cells with increased zones of central pallor and anisocytosis. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient’s symptoms?
A) Folic acid deficiency
B) Intravascular hemolysis
C) Impaired erythropoietin production
D) Vitamin B12 deficiency
E) Iron deficiency
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>78-year-old man</fact1> comes to the physician because of <fact2>progressively worsening fatigue and headache</fact2> for <fact3>6 months</fact3> and <fact4>occasional abdominal pain</fact4>. He has not had any changes in his <fact5>weight</fact5>. He has a history of <fact6>hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and chronic shoulder pain</fact6>. Current daily medications include <fact7>hydrochlorothiazide, metformin, and ibuprofen</fact7>. He does not <fact8>drink alcohol</fact8> and does not <fact9>smoke</fact9>. His diet has mostly consisted of <fact10>potatoes and lean meats</fact10> since his wife passed away <fact11>1 year ago</fact11>. His <fact12>pulse is 92/min</fact12> and <fact13>blood pressure is 135/80 mm Hg</fact13>. Examination shows <fact14>conjunctival and mucosal pallor</fact14>. Abdominal and rectal examination shows no abnormalities. Neurological exam shows <fact15>mild postural tremor</fact15>. Peripheral blood smear shows <fact16>red blood cells with increased zones of central pallor and anisocytosis</fact16>. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient’s symptoms?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's presentation, the <fact2>progressively worsening fatigue and headache</fact2> for <fact3>6 months</fact3> along with <fact14>conjunctival and mucosal pallor</fact14> and <fact16>red blood cells with increased zones of central pallor and anisocytosis</fact16> on peripheral blood smear, suggests a diagnosis of anemia. Given the patient's diet has mostly consisted of <fact10>potatoes and lean meats</fact10> since his wife passed away <fact11>1 year ago</fact11>, it is likely that he has a deficiency in a crucial nutrient. Among the options provided, a <fact10>potatoes and lean meats</fact10> diet is particularly low in vitamin B12, which is found primarily in animal products. A <fact15>mild postural tremor</fact15> can also be a sign of vitamin B12 deficiency. Therefore, the most likely underlying cause of this patient’s symptoms is {D}.

question:
A 33-year-old man presents to the emergency department after a motor vehicle collision. He was the front seat unrestrained driver in a head-on collision. The patient has a Glasgow Coma Scale of 5 and is subsequently intubated. Physical exam is notable for subcutaneous emphysema in the clavicular area. Needle decompression and chest tube placement are performed, and the patient is stabilized after receiving 2 units of blood and 2 liters of fluid. Chest radiography demonstrates proper tube location and resolution of the pneumothorax. The patient is transferred to the trauma intensive care unit. On the unit, a repeat chest radiograph is notable for a recurrent pneumothorax with the chest tube in place. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
A) Esophageal rupture
B) Inappropriate chest tube placement
C) Spontaneous pneumothorax
D) Tension pneumothorax
E) Tracheobronchial rupture
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>33-year-old man</fact1> presents to the emergency department after a <fact2>motor vehicle collision</fact2>. He was the <fact3>front seat unrestrained driver</fact3> in a <fact4>head-on collision</fact4>. The patient has a <fact5>Glasgow Coma Scale of 5</fact5> and is subsequently intubated. Physical exam is notable for <fact6>subcutaneous emphysema in the clavicular area</fact6>. <fact7>Needle decompression and chest tube placement</fact7> are performed, and the patient is stabilized after receiving <fact8>2 units of blood and 2 liters of fluid</fact8>. Chest radiography demonstrates <fact9>proper tube location and resolution of the pneumothorax</fact9>. The patient is transferred to the trauma intensive care unit. On the unit, a repeat chest radiograph is notable for a <fact10>recurrent pneumothorax with the chest tube in place</fact10>. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
A) Esophageal rupture
B) Inappropriate chest tube placement
C) Spontaneous pneumothorax
D) Tension pneumothorax
E) Tracheobronchial rupture

Answer: Considering the patient's <fact2>motor vehicle collision</fact2> and the presence of <fact6>subcutaneous emphysema in the clavicular area</fact6>, along with the initial resolution of the pneumothorax after <fact7>needle decompression and chest tube placement</fact7> and subsequent <fact10>recurrent pneumothorax with the chest tube in place</fact10>, the most likely diagnosis is {E} Tracheobronchial rupture. This is because the initial resolution of the pneumothorax after chest tube placement (as shown by <fact9>proper tube location and resolution of the pneumothorax</fact9>) followed by a recurrent pneumothorax suggests an ongoing air leak. Given the high-energy mechanism of injury (<fact4>head-on collision</fact4>) and the presence of subcutaneous emphysema, a tracheobronchial rupture is a plausible cause of the recurrent pneumothorax.

question:
A 76-year-old woman visits a physician for a general medical examination. She is asymptomatic. Six months prior, she had a cerebral stroke with left hemiparesis, from which she has almost completely recovered with physiotherapy. She has a history of hypertension and atrial fibrillation (AF). She has no significant ischemic, valvular, or structural heart disease. She takes metoprolol, amlodipine, warfarin, and atorvastatin. Blood pressure is 125/70 mm Hg, pulse is 75/min with an irregular rhythm. Respirations are 13/min. She has a minor limp and weakness in her left arm and leg. Heart exam shows no abnormalities other than irregular beats. To assess adherence and therapeutic efficacy in this patient, which of the following studies should be ordered?
A) Echocardiogram
B) Electrocardiogram
C) International normalized ratio
D) Partial thromboplastin time
E) Serum drug levels
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>76-year-old woman</fact1> visits a physician for a general medical examination. She is asymptomatic. Six months prior, she had a <fact2>cerebral stroke with left hemiparesis</fact2>, from which she has almost completely recovered with physiotherapy. She has a history of <fact3>hypertension</fact3> and <fact4>atrial fibrillation (AF)</fact4>. She has no significant ischemic, valvular, or structural heart disease. She takes <fact5>metoprolol, amlodipine, warfarin, and atorvastatin</fact5>. Blood pressure is 125/70 mm Hg, pulse is 75/min with an irregular rhythm. Respirations are 13/min. She has a minor limp and weakness in her left arm and leg. Heart exam shows no abnormalities other than irregular beats. To assess adherence and therapeutic efficacy in this patient, which of the following studies should be ordered?

A) Echocardiogram
B) Electrocardiogram
C) International normalized ratio
D) Partial thromboplastin time
E) Serum drug levels

Answer: Considering the patient's history of <fact4>atrial fibrillation (AF)</fact4> and current medication regimen, including <fact5>warfarin</fact5>, it is essential to assess the efficacy of anticoagulation therapy. Warfarin works by inhibiting vitamin K-dependent clotting factors, and its effectiveness is monitored by measuring the International Normalized Ratio (INR). Therefore, to assess adherence and therapeutic efficacy in this patient, the most appropriate study to order is the International Normalized Ratio (INR). The answer is {C}.

question:
A 32-year-old man comes to the physician because of a progressive development of tender breast tissue over the past 18 months. He used to ride his bicycle for exercise 4 times a week but stopped after he had an accident and injured his left testicle 3 months ago. He has gained 5 kg (11 lb) during this period. For the last 10 years, he drinks one to two beers daily and sometimes more on weekends. He occasionally takes pantoprazole for heartburn. He is 171 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 87 kg (192 lb); BMI is 30 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows bilaterally symmetrical, mildly tender gynecomastia. A nontender 1.5-cm mass is palpated in the left testis; transillumination test is negative. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of these findings?
A) Leydig cell tumor
B) Obesity
C) Thyroid disease
D) Klinefelter syndrome
E) Trauma to testis
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>32-year-old man</fact1> comes to the physician because of a <fact2>progressive development of tender breast tissue</fact2> over the past <fact3>18 months</fact3>. He used to ride his bicycle for exercise <fact4>4 times a week</fact4> but stopped after he had an <fact5>accident and injured his left testicle</fact5> <fact6>3 months ago</fact6>. He has <fact7>gained 5 kg (11 lb)</fact7> during this period. For the last <fact8>10 years</fact8>, he drinks <fact9>one to two beers daily</fact9> and sometimes more on weekends. He occasionally takes <fact10>pantoprazole for heartburn</fact10>. He is <fact11>171 cm (5 ft 7 in)</fact11> tall and weighs <fact12>87 kg (192 lb)</fact12>; <fact13>BMI is 30 kg/m2</fact13>. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows <fact14>bilaterally symmetrical, mildly tender gynecomastia</fact14>. A <fact15>nontender 1.5-cm mass is palpated in the left testis</fact15>; <fact16>transillumination test is negative</fact16>. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of these findings?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's <fact14>bilaterally symmetrical, mildly tender gynecomastia</fact14> and the presence of a <fact15>nontender 1.5-cm mass in the left testis</fact15> with a <fact16>negative transillumination test</fact16>, which suggests a solid mass rather than a cyst, the most likely underlying cause is a <fact17>Leydig cell tumor</fact17>. Leydig cell tumors are known to produce estrogen, leading to gynecomastia in men. The patient's <fact5>accident and injured left testicle</fact5> <fact6>3 months ago</fact6> and <fact7>weight gain</fact7> may be contributing factors but are not the primary cause. The patient's <fact9>alcohol consumption</fact9> and <fact10>use of pantoprazole</fact10> are not directly related to the development of gynecomastia or testicular masses. Therefore, the correct answer is {A}.

question:
A 25-year-old man presents to the office because of extreme fatigue for the past 2 days. He is also worried about his skin looking yellow. He does not have any other complaints and denies fever and headache. He admits to using illicit intravenous drugs in the past. He does not have any immunization records because he moved from Africa to the US at the age of 18. His vital signs are as follows: heart rate 72/min, respiratory rate 14/min, temperature 37.9°C (100.2°F), and blood pressure 100/74 mm Hg. Physical examination is not significant except for mild diffuse abdominal tenderness. His blood is drawn for routine tests and shows an alanine aminotransferase level (ALT) of 2,000 IU/L. A hepatitis viral panel is ordered which shows:
Anti-HAV IgM negative
HBsAg positive
Anti-HBs negative
IgM anti-HBc positive
Anti-HCV negative
Anti-HDV negative
What is the most likely diagnosis?
A) Past hepatitis B infection
B) Chronic hepatitis B
C) Acute hepatitis A
D) Acute hepatitis D superinfection
E) Acute hepatitis B
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>25-year-old man</fact1> presents to the office because of <fact2>extreme fatigue</fact2> for the past 2 days. He is also worried about his <fact3>skin looking yellow</fact3>. He does not have any other complaints and denies <fact4>fever and headache</fact4>. He admits to using <fact5>illicit intravenous drugs in the past</fact5>. He does not have any immunization records because he moved from Africa to the US at the age of 18. His vital signs are as follows: <fact6>heart rate 72/min</fact6>, <fact7>respiratory rate 14/min</fact7>, <fact8>temperature 37.9°C (100.2°F)</fact8>, and <fact9>blood pressure 100/74 mm Hg</fact9>. Physical examination is not significant except for <fact10>mild diffuse abdominal tenderness</fact10>. His blood is drawn for routine tests and shows an <fact11>alanine aminotransferase level (ALT) of 2,000 IU/L</fact11>. A <fact12>hepatitis viral panel</fact12> is ordered which shows:
<fact13>Anti-HAV IgM negative</fact13>
<fact14>HBsAg positive</fact14>
<fact15>Anti-HBs negative</fact15>
<fact16>IgM anti-HBc positive</fact16>
<fact17>Anti-HCV negative</fact17>
<fact18>Anti-HDV negative</fact18>
What is the most likely diagnosis?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's symptoms of <fact2>extreme fatigue</fact2> and <fact3>skin looking yellow</fact3>, along with an elevated <fact11>ALT level of 2,000 IU/L</fact11>, suggest liver dysfunction. The <fact12>hepatitis viral panel</fact12> results show <fact14>HBsAg positive</fact14>, indicating an active hepatitis B infection, and <fact16>IgM anti-HBc positive</fact16>, which is a marker for acute hepatitis B infection. The absence of <fact15>Anti-HBs</fact15> and <fact17>Anti-HCV</fact17> and <fact18>Anti-HDV</fact18> negative results rule out chronic hepatitis B and other forms of hepatitis. Therefore, the most likely diagnosis is {E} Acute hepatitis B.

question:
A multi-specialty physician practice is meeting to determine which compensation scheme would best serve the practice and its patient population. Which of the following are true in regards to physician compensation?
A) Capitation poses the least financial risk to physicians
B) Fee-for-service pays physicians a set amount of money per unit time for every patient under their care
C) Fee-for-service may incentivize physicians to increase healthcare utilization irrespective of quality
D) Fee-for-service poses the most amount of financial risk to physicians
E) Capitation may provide perverse incentives to decrease preventive medicine visits
answer:
Reformatted Question: A multi-specialty physician practice is meeting to determine which compensation scheme would best serve the practice and its patient population. Which of the following are true in regards to physician compensation? 
A) <fact1>Capitation</fact1> poses the least financial risk to physicians
B) <fact2>Fee-for-service</fact2> pays physicians a set amount of money per unit time for every patient under their care
C) <fact3>Fee-for-service</fact3> may incentivize physicians to increase healthcare utilization irrespective of quality
D) <fact4>Fee-for-service</fact4> poses the most amount of financial risk to physicians
E) <fact5>Capitation</fact5> may provide perverse incentives to decrease preventive medicine visits

Answer: C and E. 

Explanation: 
- Option C is correct because <fact3>Fee-for-service</fact3> models can incentivize physicians to increase healthcare utilization, including tests and procedures, which may not always be necessary or of high quality. This is because physicians are paid for each service they provide, which can lead to overutilization.
- Option E is correct because <fact5>Capitation</fact5> involves paying physicians a fixed amount per patient, regardless of the services provided. This model can create perverse incentives for physicians to reduce healthcare utilization, including preventive medicine visits, in order to minimize costs and maximize profits.

question:
A 27-year-old female is brought to the emergency department by police when she attacked her date outside of a pizza restaurant. The patient refused to explain her behavior to the police. She seemed to be responding to internal stimuli when being initially interviewed. The patient has a past medical history of depression, anxiety, and obesity. The patient has a known history of medication non-compliance. Her temperature is 99.5°F (37.5°C), pulse is 112/min, blood pressure is 100/70 mmHg, respirations are 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On physical exam the patient is poorly kempt and has an odd body odor. Inspection of her oropharynx reveals multiple ulcers. Cardiac exam is unrevealing with the exception of a friction rub. Since the incident, the patient has calmed down and is currently resting. She is no longer responding to internal stimuli and is more cooperative. Lab values are obtained and are below.

Serum:
Na+: 135 mEq/L
Cl-: 100 mEq/L
K+: 3.9 mEq/L
HCO3-: 24 mEq/L
BUN: 20 mg/dL
Glucose: 70 mg/dL
Creatinine: 1.7 mg/dL
Ca2+: 10.0 mg/dL
Mg2+: 1.5 mEq/L

Hemoglobin: 10 g/dL
Hematocrit: 35%
Reticulocyte count: 4.9%
Platelet count: 275,000/mm^3
Leukocyte count: 5,500/mm^3

Which of the following is the next best step in management for this patient's underlying condition?
A) IM haloperidol
B) Haloperidol depot
C) Clozapine
D) Urine toxicology
E) ANA and anti-dsDNA levels
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>27-year-old female</fact1> is brought to the emergency department by police when she <fact2>attacked her date outside of a pizza restaurant</fact2>. The patient refused to explain her behavior to the police. She seemed to be responding to <fact3>internal stimuli</fact3> when being initially interviewed. The patient has a past medical history of <fact4>depression, anxiety, and obesity</fact4>. The patient has a known history of <fact5>medication non-compliance</fact5>. Her temperature is <fact6>99.5°F (37.5°C)</fact6>, pulse is <fact7>112/min</fact7>, blood pressure is <fact8>100/70 mmHg</fact8>, respirations are <fact9>18/min</fact9>, and oxygen saturation is <fact10>98% on room air</fact10>. On physical exam the patient is <fact11>poorly kempt</fact11> and has an <fact12>odd body odor</fact12>. Inspection of her oropharynx reveals <fact13>multiple ulcers</fact13>. Cardiac exam is unrevealing with the exception of a <fact14>friction rub</fact14>. Since the incident, the patient has calmed down and is currently resting. She is no longer responding to <fact3>internal stimuli</fact3> and is more cooperative. Lab values are obtained and are below.

Serum:
Na+: <fact15>135 mEq/L</fact15>
Cl-: <fact16>100 mEq/L</fact16>
K+: <fact17>3.9 mEq/L</fact17>
HCO3-: <fact18>24 mEq/L</fact18>
BUN: <fact19>20 mg/dL</fact19>
Glucose: <fact20>70 mg/dL</fact20>
Creatinine: <fact21>1.7 mg/dL</fact21>
Ca2+: <fact22>10.0 mg/dL</fact22>
Mg2+: <fact23>1.5 mEq/L</fact23>

Hemoglobin: <fact24>10 g/dL</fact24>
Hematocrit: <fact25>35%</fact25>
Reticulocyte count: <fact26>4.9%</fact26>
Platelet count: <fact27>275,000/mm^3</fact27>
Leukocyte count: <fact28>5,500/mm^3</fact28>

Which of the following is the next best step in management for this patient's underlying condition?

Answer: Analyzing the patient's presentation and lab values, it's clear that she is experiencing a psychiatric episode, as evidenced by her <fact2>attack on her date</fact2> and responding to <fact3>internal stimuli</fact3>. Her past medical history of <fact4>depression and anxiety</fact4> and known history of <fact5>medication non-compliance</fact5> suggest that her underlying condition may be related to a psychiatric disorder. Additionally, her lab values show a low hemoglobin level (<fact24>10 g/dL</fact24>) and elevated creatinine level (<fact21>1.7 mg/dL</fact21>), which could be indicative of a systemic condition. However, given her psychiatric presentation, it's essential to rule out any underlying substance use or toxicity that could be contributing to her behavior. Therefore, the next best step in management would be to perform a <fact29>urine toxicology</fact29> screen to assess for any potential substance use. The answer is {D}.

question:
A 66-year-old man comes to the physician because of fatigue and swelling of his legs and feet for 6 weeks. During this time he has felt like his eyes have been unusually puffy in the mornings and his urine has been frothy. He has hypertension and rheumatoid factor-positive rheumatoid arthritis. Current medications include amlodipine, methotrexate, and ibuprofen. He does not smoke. He has a history of chronic alcohol abuse. His temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 148/86 mm Hg. Physical examination shows pallor, periorbital edema, 2+ pedal edema, and ascites. He has swan-neck deformities and nodules of multiple fingers and swelling and restricted range of motion of bilateral knee joints. Laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 8.2 mg/dl
Prothrombin time 12 seconds
Serum
Albumin 2.8 g/dl
Total bilirubin 1.0 mg/dl
Alkaline phosphatase 120 U/L
AST 20 U/L
ALT 19 U/L
Urea 18 mg/dl
Creatinine 1.2 mg/dl
Urine
Protein 3+
WBCs 5–10/hpf
RBCs negative
Bacteria negative
Ultrasound of the liver and kidneys shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's findings?"
A) Adverse effect of ibuprofen
B) Decreased cardiac ejection fraction
C) Renal deposition of AL amyloid
D) Increased serum amyloid A production
E) Renal deposition of anti-dsDNA immune complexes
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>66-year-old man</fact1> comes to the physician because of <fact2>fatigue and swelling of his legs and feet for 6 weeks</fact2>. During this time he has felt like his <fact3>eyes have been unusually puffy in the mornings</fact3> and his <fact4>urine has been frothy</fact4>. He has <fact5>hypertension and rheumatoid factor-positive rheumatoid arthritis</fact5>. Current medications include <fact6>amlodipine, methotrexate, and ibuprofen</fact6>. He does not smoke. He has a <fact7>history of chronic alcohol abuse</fact7>. His <fact8>temperature is 36.7°C (98°F)</fact8>, <fact9>pulse is 80/min</fact9>, and <fact10>blood pressure is 148/86 mm Hg</fact10>. Physical examination shows <fact11>pallor, periorbital edema, 2+ pedal edema, and ascites</fact11>. He has <fact12>swan-neck deformities and nodules of multiple fingers</fact12> and <fact13>swelling and restricted range of motion of bilateral knee joints</fact13>. Laboratory studies show:
<fact14>Hemoglobin 8.2 mg/dl</fact14>
<fact15>Prothrombin time 12 seconds</fact15>
<fact16>Serum albumin 2.8 g/dl</fact16>
<fact17>Total bilirubin 1.0 mg/dl</fact17>
<fact18>Alkaline phosphatase 120 U/L</fact18>
<fact19>AST 20 U/L</fact19>
<fact20>ALT 19 U/L</fact20>
<fact21>Urea 18 mg/dl</fact21>
<fact22>Creatinine 1.2 mg/dl</fact22>
<fact23>Urine protein 3+</fact23>
<fact24>WBCs 5–10/hpf</fact24>
<fact25>RBCs negative</fact25>
<fact26>Bacteria negative</fact26>
<fact27>Ultrasound of the liver and kidneys shows no abnormalities</fact27>. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's findings?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's symptoms of <fact2>fatigue and swelling of his legs and feet</fact2>, along with <fact3>puffy eyes in the mornings</fact3> and <fact4>frothy urine</fact4>, these findings suggest nephrotic syndrome, a condition characterized by significant loss of protein in the urine. The laboratory results, including <fact23>3+ protein in the urine</fact23> and <fact16>low serum albumin of 2.8 g/dl</fact16>, support this diagnosis. Additionally, the patient's <fact5>history of rheumatoid factor-positive rheumatoid arthritis</fact5> increases the risk for secondary amyloidosis. The presence of <fact12>swan-neck deformities and nodules of multiple fingers</fact12> and <fact13>swelling and restricted range of motion of bilateral knee joints</fact13> are also indicative of rheumatoid arthritis. Given these factors, the most likely cause of this patient's findings is <fact28>renal deposition of AL amyloid</fact28>, which is a complication of chronic inflammatory diseases like rheumatoid arthritis. Therefore, the answer is {C}.

question:
A 19-year-old man in a 3-month relationship with a woman experiences frequent sexual fantasies about male coworkers. He lives in a conservative community and does not know any openly gay men. Two days ago, he joined a local group considered by many organizations to be a hate group. Together with the other members, he attacked a gay couple on their way home from dinner. Which of the following psychological defense mechanisms is he demonstrating?
A) Acting out
B) Sublimation
C) Reaction formation
D) Intellectualization
E) Projection
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>19-year-old man</fact1> in a <fact2>3-month relationship with a woman</fact2> experiences <fact3>frequent sexual fantasies about male coworkers</fact3>. He lives in a <fact4>conservative community</fact4> and does not know any <fact5>openly gay men</fact5>. Two days ago, he joined a <fact6>local group considered by many organizations to be a hate group</fact6>. Together with the other members, he <fact7>attacked a gay couple on their way home from dinner</fact7>. Which of the following psychological defense mechanisms is he demonstrating?

Answer: 
Considering the <fact1>19-year-old man's</fact1> actions and circumstances, he is exhibiting a psychological defense mechanism to cope with his <fact3>frequent sexual fantasies about male coworkers</fact3> in a <fact4>conservative community</fact4> where he may feel societal pressure to conform to traditional norms. By joining a <fact6>hate group</fact6> and participating in the <fact7>attack on a gay couple</fact7>, he is demonstrating a defense mechanism that involves expressing an opposite feeling or behavior to what he truly feels, which is attraction to men. This behavior is an attempt to deny or repress his own desires, which is characteristic of <fact8>reaction formation</fact8>. Therefore, the correct answer is {C}.

question:
A 72-year-old Caucasian male presents to your office with dysphagia and halitosis. If this patient is also found to have cricopharyngeal muscle dysfunction, which of the following is the most likely cause of his presenting symptoms?
A) Gastroesophageal reflux disease
B) Esophageal candidiasis
C) Glossopharyngeal nerve damage
D) Meckel's diverticulum
E) Zenker's diverticulum
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>72-year-old Caucasian male</fact1> presents to your office with <fact2>dysphagia and halitosis</fact2>. If this patient is also found to have <fact3>cricopharyngeal muscle dysfunction</fact3>, which of the following is the most likely cause of his presenting symptoms?

Answer: 
Given the patient's symptoms of <fact2>dysphagia and halitosis</fact2> along with the presence of <fact3>cricopharyngeal muscle dysfunction</fact3>, the most likely cause is related to the dysfunction of the cricopharyngeal muscle, which is involved in the coordination of swallowing. Among the options, <fact4>Zenker's diverticulum</fact4> is a condition where there is an outpouching of the mucosa through a weakness in the muscular wall of the pharynx, just above the cricopharyngeal muscle. This condition is often associated with cricopharyngeal muscle dysfunction and can lead to symptoms such as dysphagia and halitosis due to the accumulation of food particles in the diverticulum. Therefore, the answer is {E}.

question:
A 45-year-old woman with hypothyroidism comes to the physician because of progressive fatigue, lethargy, and epigastric pain after eating. Physical examination shows pale conjunctivae. Laboratory studies show decreased serum hemoglobin levels and increased serum gastrin levels. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy shows inflammation of the gastric body and fundus. A photomicrograph of a biopsy specimen taken from the gastric antrum is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
A) Mucosal cell hyperplasia
B) Enterochromaffin-like cell hyperplasia
C) Parietal cell destruction
D) Chief cell destruction
E) I cell destruction
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>45-year-old woman</fact1> with <fact2>hypothyroidism</fact2> comes to the physician because of <fact3>progressive fatigue, lethargy, and epigastric pain after eating</fact3>. Physical examination shows <fact4>pale conjunctivae</fact4>. Laboratory studies show <fact5>decreased serum hemoglobin levels</fact5> and <fact6>increased serum gastrin levels</fact6>. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy shows <fact7>inflammation of the gastric body and fundus</fact7>. A photomicrograph of a biopsy specimen taken from the gastric antrum is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's presentation, including <fact3>progressive fatigue, lethargy, and epigastric pain after eating</fact3>, along with <fact4>pale conjunctivae</fact4>, <fact5>decreased serum hemoglobin levels</fact5>, and <fact6>increased serum gastrin levels</fact6>, suggests a condition affecting the stomach. The <fact7>inflammation of the gastric body and fundus</fact7> observed during esophagogastroduodenoscopy points towards gastritis. Among the options provided, choice C, <fact8>parietal cell destruction</fact8>, is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms, as it leads to decreased gastric acid production and is associated with atrophic gastritis, which can cause the observed symptoms and findings.

question:
A 68-year-old woman presents with left lower quadrant pain that worsens with defecation. She describes the pain as 'crampy'. She also says she has suffered from mild constipation for the past few years. The patient denies any recent weight change or urinary symptoms. Her last menstrual period was 16 years ago. Her body temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F), pulse is 102/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and blood pressure is 133/87 mm Hg. On physical examination, tenderness to palpation in the left lower quadrant is present. The laboratory studies are presented as follows:
Hemoglobin 13.2 mg/dL
Hematocrit 48%
Leukocyte count 16,000/mm³
Neutrophils 89%
Bands 5%
Eosinophils 0%
Basophils 0%
Lymphocytes 11%
Monocytes 0%
Platelet count 380,000/mm³
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
A) Diverticulitis
B) Hypothyroidism
C) Adenocarcinoma of the colon
D) Chronic inflammatory bowel disease
E) Irritable bowel syndrome
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>68-year-old woman</fact1> presents with <fact2>left lower quadrant pain that worsens with defecation</fact2>. She describes the pain as <fact3>'crampy'</fact3>. She also says she has suffered from <fact4>mild constipation for the past few years</fact4>. The patient denies any recent <fact5>weight change or urinary symptoms</fact5>. Her last menstrual period was <fact6>16 years ago</fact6>. Her body temperature is <fact7>37.8°C (100.0°F)</fact7>, pulse is <fact8>102/min</fact8>, respiratory rate is <fact9>16/min</fact9>, and blood pressure is <fact10>133/87 mm Hg</fact10>. On physical examination, <fact11>tenderness to palpation in the left lower quadrant</fact11> is present. The laboratory studies are presented as follows:
Hemoglobin <fact12>13.2 mg/dL</fact12>
Hematocrit <fact13>48%</fact13>
Leukocyte count <fact14>16,000/mm³</fact14>
Neutrophils <fact15>89%</fact15>
Bands <fact16>5%</fact16>
Eosinophils <fact17>0%</fact17>
Basophils <fact18>0%</fact18>
Lymphocytes <fact19>11%</fact19>
Monocytes <fact20>0%</fact20>
Platelet count <fact21>380,000/mm³</fact21>
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
A) Diverticulitis
B) Hypothyroidism
C) Adenocarcinoma of the colon
D) Chronic inflammatory bowel disease
E) Irritable bowel syndrome

Answer: 
The patient presents with <fact2>left lower quadrant pain that worsens with defecation</fact2> and is described as <fact3>'crampy'</fact3>. This type of pain is often associated with diverticulitis, which is inflammation of a diverticulum in the wall of the intestine. The presence of <fact11>tenderness to palpation in the left lower quadrant</fact11> further supports this diagnosis. Additionally, the laboratory results show an elevated <fact14>leukocyte count of 16,000/mm³</fact14> and <fact15>89% neutrophils</fact15>, indicating a significant inflammatory response. Given the patient's age and symptoms, diverticulitis is the most likely diagnosis. Therefore, the answer is {A}.

question:
A 72-year-old anthropologist with long-standing hypertension visits your office for a routine exam. You notice an abnormality on his laboratory results caused by his regimen of captopril and triamterene. What abnormality did you most likely find?
A) Hypercalcemia
B) Hyperkalemia
C) Hypernatremia
D) Thrombocytopenia
E) Anemia
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>72-year-old anthropologist</fact1> with <fact2>long-standing hypertension</fact2> visits your office for a routine exam. You notice an abnormality on his laboratory results caused by his regimen of <fact3>captopril</fact3> and <fact4>triamterene</fact4>. What abnormality did you most likely find?

Answer: Analyzing the situation, the patient is a <fact1>72-year-old anthropologist</fact1> with <fact2>long-standing hypertension</fact2> and is taking <fact3>captopril</fact3> and <fact4>triamterene</fact4>. Captopril is an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor, and triamterene is a potassium-sparing diuretic. Both of these medications can cause an increase in potassium levels. Given this information, the abnormality that was most likely found is {B} Hyperkalemia.

question:
A 74-year-old man was admitted to the hospital after falling down several stairs. He is a known alcoholic. He was started on IV fluids and received a head CT, which was negative. It was decided that he would be watched for one day before being discharged, after a negative work-up. Suddenly, he is unable to move his arms and legs in addition to experiencing difficulty chewing, swallowing, moving his face, and speaking. Which of the following electrolyte imbalances was most likely corrected too aggressively?
A) Hyponatremia
B) Hypernatremia
C) Hypokalemia
D) Hyperkalemia
E) Hypochloremia
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>74-year-old man</fact1> was admitted to the hospital after <fact2>falling down several stairs</fact2>. He is a <fact3>known alcoholic</fact3>. He was started on <fact4>IV fluids</fact4> and received a <fact5>head CT, which was negative</fact5>. It was decided that he would be watched for one day before being discharged, after a <fact6>negative work-up</fact6>. Suddenly, he is unable to move his <fact7>arms and legs</fact7> in addition to experiencing <fact8>difficulty chewing, swallowing, moving his face, and speaking</fact8>. Which of the following electrolyte imbalances was most likely corrected too aggressively?

Answer: 
Considering the <fact1>74-year-old man's</fact1> condition, the sudden onset of inability to move his <fact7>arms and legs</fact7> and difficulty with <fact8>chewing, swallowing, moving his face, and speaking</fact8> suggests a severe electrolyte imbalance affecting his neuromuscular system. Given that he was started on <fact4>IV fluids</fact4> and had a <fact6>negative work-up</fact6>, it is likely that the electrolyte imbalance was being corrected. However, the correction was too aggressive, leading to these severe symptoms. Among the options provided, hypokalemia (low potassium levels) is a common issue in alcoholics (<fact3>known alcoholic</fact3>) and can cause muscle weakness when corrected too quickly. Therefore, the electrolyte imbalance most likely corrected too aggressively is {C} Hypokalemia.

question:
A 15-year-old woman presents with fever, altered mental status and a petechial rash on her lower extremities and back since yesterday evening. She also says she has been nauseous for the past 3 hours and has vomited twice. The patient mentions she has had heavy menstrual bleeding for the past few days. Her blood pressure is 95/80 mm Hg and her temperature is 40.0°C (104.0°F). On physical examination, the patient appears diaphoretic. A pelvic examination reveals a tampon in her vagina. Binding and activation of which of the following T cell receptors is responsible for this patient’s most likely condition?
A) B7 receptor
B) Variable β-sequence of the T cell receptor
C) CD40
D) CD3
E) IgCAM
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>15-year-old woman</fact1> presents with <fact2>fever, altered mental status</fact2> and a <fact3>petechial rash on her lower extremities and back</fact3> since yesterday evening. She also says she has been <fact4>nauseous for the past 3 hours</fact4> and has <fact5>vomited twice</fact5>. The patient mentions she has had <fact6>heavy menstrual bleeding for the past few days</fact6>. Her <fact7>blood pressure is 95/80 mm Hg</fact7> and her <fact8>temperature is 40.0°C (104.0°F)</fact8>. On physical examination, the patient appears <fact9>diaphoretic</fact9>. A <fact10>pelvic examination reveals a tampon in her vagina</fact10>. Binding and activation of which of the following T cell receptors is responsible for this patient’s most likely condition?

Answer: 
The patient's symptoms, including <fact2>fever, altered mental status</fact2>, <fact3>petechial rash</fact3>, <fact4>nausea</fact4>, <fact5>vomiting</fact5>, <fact6>heavy menstrual bleeding</fact6>, and the presence of a <fact10>tampon in her vagina</fact10>, are highly suggestive of Toxic Shock Syndrome (TSS). TSS is a condition caused by bacterial toxins, typically produced by Staphylococcus aureus, which can be introduced through the use of tampons. The binding and activation of the T cell receptor responsible for this condition involves the Variable β-sequence of the T cell receptor. This receptor is crucial in the recognition of the bacterial superantigens that trigger the massive immune response seen in TSS. Therefore, the correct answer is {B}.

question:
A 27-year-old HIV positive female gave birth to a 7lb 2oz (3.2 kg) baby girl. The obstetrician is worried that the child may have been infected due to the mother's haphazard use of her anti-retroviral medications. Which of the following assays would a hospital use detect the genetic material of HIV if the child had been infected?
A) Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA)
B) Western blot
C) Rapid HIV antibody test
D) Polymerase chain reaction
E) Southern blot
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>27-year-old HIV positive female</fact1> gave birth to a <fact2>7lb 2oz (3.2 kg) baby girl</fact2>. The obstetrician is worried that the child may have been infected due to the mother's <fact3>haphazard use of her anti-retroviral medications</fact3>. Which of the following assays would a hospital use detect the genetic material of HIV if the child had been infected?

A) Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA)
B) Western blot
C) Rapid HIV antibody test
D) Polymerase chain reaction
E) Southern blot

Answer: 
Considering the <fact1>27-year-old HIV positive female</fact1> and her <fact2>7lb 2oz (3.2 kg) baby girl</fact2>, the concern is whether the child has been infected with HIV due to the mother's <fact3>haphazard use of her anti-retroviral medications</fact3>. To detect the genetic material of HIV in the child, the most suitable assay would be the one that directly identifies the viral genome. Among the options, Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) is a molecular test that can detect the genetic material of HIV, making it the best choice for diagnosing HIV infection in the child. The answer is {D}.

question:
A 20-year-old man comes to the physician because of worsening gait unsteadiness and bilateral hearing loss for 1 month. He has had intermittent tingling sensations on both cheeks over this time period. He has no history of serious medical illness and takes no medications. Audiometry shows bilateral sensorineural hearing loss. Genetic evaluation shows a mutation of a tumor suppressor gene on chromosome 22 that encodes merlin. This patient is at increased risk for which of the following conditions?
A) Renal cell carcinoma
B) Meningioma
C) Astrocytoma
D) Vascular malformations
E) Telangiectasias
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>20-year-old man</fact1> comes to the physician because of <fact2>worsening gait unsteadiness and bilateral hearing loss</fact2> for <fact3>1 month</fact3>. He has had <fact4>intermittent tingling sensations on both cheeks</fact4> over this time period. He has no history of <fact5>serious medical illness</fact5> and takes no <fact6>medications</fact6>. <fact7>Audiometry shows bilateral sensorineural hearing loss</fact7>. <fact8>Genetic evaluation shows a mutation of a tumor suppressor gene on chromosome 22 that encodes merlin</fact8>. This patient is at increased risk for which of the following conditions?

Answer: Considering the patient's symptoms of <fact2>worsening gait unsteadiness and bilateral hearing loss</fact2> and <fact4>intermittent tingling sensations on both cheeks</fact4>, along with the results of <fact7>audiometry showing bilateral sensorineural hearing loss</fact7> and the presence of a <fact8>mutation of a tumor suppressor gene on chromosome 22 that encodes merlin</fact8>, the patient is likely suffering from Neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2). NF2 is a genetic disorder characterized by the growth of noncancerous tumors in the nervous system, including meningiomas. Therefore, the patient is at increased risk for developing a {B} Meningioma.

question:
A 3-month-old girl is brought to the physician because of a productive cough for 5 days. Over the past month, she has had several episodes of watery stools. She is exclusively breastfed every 3–4 hours for 15–20 minutes. She was delivered vaginally at 38 weeks' gestation at home and has not yet been evaluated by a physician. The mother reports that her child is not gaining weight. The mother had no prenatal care. The infant is at the 5th percentile for height and weight. The infant has not received any immunizations. Her temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 155/min, respirations are 45/min, and blood pressure is 88/50 mm Hg. Oral examination shows white plaques covering the tongue and the palate. Rales are heard bilaterally on cardiopulmonary examination. Cervical and inguinal lymphadenopathy is present. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
A) Karyotyping of infant's chromosomes
B) DNA test for CFTR mutation
C) Fluorescent treponemal antibody absorption test
D) Polymerase chain reaction for viral genes
E) T-cell receptor excision circle analysis
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>3-month-old girl</fact1> is brought to the physician because of a <fact2>productive cough for 5 days</fact2>. Over the past month, she has had several episodes of <fact3>watery stools</fact3>. She is <fact4>exclusively breastfed every 3–4 hours for 15–20 minutes</fact4>. She was <fact5>delivered vaginally at 38 weeks' gestation at home</fact5> and has not yet been evaluated by a physician. The mother reports that her child is <fact6>not gaining weight</fact6>. The mother had <fact7>no prenatal care</fact7>. The infant is at the <fact8>5th percentile for height and weight</fact8>. The infant has <fact9>not received any immunizations</fact9>. Her <fact10>temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F)</fact10>, <fact11>pulse is 155/min</fact11>, <fact12>respirations are 45/min</fact12>, and <fact13>blood pressure is 88/50 mm Hg</fact13>. Oral examination shows <fact14>white plaques covering the tongue and the palate</fact14>. Rales are heard bilaterally on cardiopulmonary examination. Cervical and inguinal lymphadenopathy is present. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?

Answer: 
The <fact1>3-month-old girl</fact1> presents with a <fact2>productive cough for 5 days</fact2> and several episodes of <fact3>watery stools</fact3> over the past month, indicating a possible infection. The girl's failure to gain weight, as reported by the mother, and being at the <fact8>5th percentile for height and weight</fact8> suggests a compromised immune system or an underlying condition affecting her overall health. The presence of <fact14>white plaques covering the tongue and the palate</fact14> is indicative of oral thrush, a fungal infection often seen in immunocompromised patients. The combination of these symptoms and the lack of immunizations (<fact9>not received any immunizations</fact9>) and prenatal care (<fact7>no prenatal care</fact7>) raises concerns about the girl's immune status. Given these factors, the most likely diagnosis is related to a severe immunodeficiency. Among the options, T-cell receptor excision circle (TREC) analysis is a test used to diagnose severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID), a condition that would explain the girl's symptoms and lack of response to infections. Therefore, the answer is {E}.

question:
A 42-year-old man presents to your office complaining of right-sided facial swelling that has progressively worsened over the last month after returning from a trip to India. On examination, the patient has an obvious distortion of the facial features on the right without erythema or lymphadenopathy. A neurological exam reveals no deficits. His blood pressure is 115/80 mm Hg, heart rate is 65/min, and the temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F). The patient states that he has been having trouble chewing his food, but is not experiencing any pain. The patient is up to date on all of his immunizations. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his facial swelling?
A) Benign cystic tumor with stroma resembling lymph node tissue
B) Benign salivary gland tumor composed of stromal and epithelial tissue
C) An infection with paramyxovirus
D) Malignant tumor composed of squamous and mucinous cells
E) Sialolithiasis that has progressed to a S. aureus infection
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>42-year-old man</fact1> presents to your office complaining of <fact2>right-sided facial swelling</fact2> that has progressively worsened over the last month after returning from a trip to <fact3>India</fact3>. On examination, the patient has an obvious <fact4>distortion of the facial features on the right without erythema or lymphadenopathy</fact4>. A neurological exam reveals no deficits. His <fact5>blood pressure is 115/80 mm Hg</fact5>, <fact6>heart rate is 65/min</fact6>, and the <fact7>temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F)</fact7>. The patient states that he has been having trouble chewing his food, but is not experiencing any <fact8>pain</fact8>. The patient is up to date on all of his <fact9>immunizations</fact9>. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his <fact2>facial swelling</fact2>?
A) Benign cystic tumor with stroma resembling lymph node tissue
B) Benign salivary gland tumor composed of stromal and epithelial tissue
C) An infection with paramyxovirus
D) Malignant tumor composed of squamous and mucinous cells
E) Sialolithiasis that has progressed to a S. aureus infection

Answer: 
Considering the <fact1>42-year-old man's</fact1> symptoms of <fact2>right-sided facial swelling</fact2> that has progressively worsened over the last month after returning from a trip to <fact3>India</fact3>, along with the absence of <fact8>pain</fact8> and no signs of infection such as erythema or lymphadenopathy (<fact4>distortion of the facial features on the right without erythema or lymphadenopathy</fact4>), normal vital signs (<fact5>blood pressure is 115/80 mm Hg</fact5>, <fact6>heart rate is 65/min</fact6>, and <fact7>temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F)</fact7>), and being up to date on all of his <fact9>immunizations</fact9>, it is less likely to be an infectious cause (options C and E). Given the trouble chewing food without pain, a benign salivary gland tumor (option B) is a plausible explanation for the facial swelling. Therefore, the most likely cause of his <fact2>facial swelling</fact2> is {B}.

question:
A 48-year-old Caucasian female presents to her primary care physician for evaluation of progressive weakness and shortness of breath. She has had progressive shortness of breath over the last year with an intermittent non-productive cough. In addition, she complains of difficulty raising her arms to brush her hair. Her temperature is 99.6°F (37.6°C), pulse is 80/min, blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg, respirations are 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. Neurologic exam shows 4/5 strength in the deltoid muscles bilaterally. Diffuse dry crackles are heard on lung auscultation. A faint erythematous rash is noted on the malar cheeks, periorbital areas, lateral proximal thighs, and the elbows. Which of the following tests is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
A) Muscle biopsy
B) CT scan
C) Pulmonary function tests
D) Serum ANA titer
E) Skin biopsy
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>48-year-old Caucasian female</fact1> presents to her primary care physician for evaluation of <fact2>progressive weakness and shortness of breath</fact2>. She has had <fact3>progressive shortness of breath over the last year with an intermittent non-productive cough</fact3>. In addition, she complains of <fact4>difficulty raising her arms to brush her hair</fact4>. Her <fact5>temperature is 99.6°F (37.6°C)</fact5>, <fact6>pulse is 80/min</fact6>, <fact7>blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg</fact7>, <fact8>respirations are 18/min</fact8>, and <fact9>oxygen saturation is 95% on room air</fact9>. <fact10>Neurologic exam shows 4/5 strength in the deltoid muscles bilaterally</fact10>. <fact11>Diffuse dry crackles are heard on lung auscultation</fact11>. A <fact12>faint erythematous rash is noted on the malar cheeks, periorbital areas, lateral proximal thighs, and the elbows</fact12>. Which of the following tests is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
A) Muscle biopsy
B) CT scan
C) Pulmonary function tests
D) Serum ANA titer
E) Skin biopsy

Answer: 
Considering the patient's presentation of <fact2>progressive weakness and shortness of breath</fact2>, along with the <fact3>progressive shortness of breath over the last year with an intermittent non-productive cough</fact3> and <fact4>difficulty raising her arms to brush her hair</fact4>, suggests a systemic condition affecting both the lungs and muscles. The <fact10>neurologic exam showing 4/5 strength in the deltoid muscles bilaterally</fact10> indicates muscle weakness. The <fact11>diffuse dry crackles heard on lung auscultation</fact11> point towards lung involvement. Furthermore, the <fact12>faint erythematous rash noted on the malar cheeks, periorbital areas, lateral proximal thighs, and the elbows</fact12> is indicative of a skin manifestation often associated with autoimmune diseases. Given these findings, a test that can confirm an autoimmune diagnosis would be most appropriate.
