Among the options provided, the <fact13>serum ANA titer</fact13> is a key test for diagnosing autoimmune diseases such as Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) or other connective tissue diseases, which can explain the patient's multi-system symptoms. Therefore, the answer is {D}.

question:
A 64-year-old man presents with severe respiratory distress. This has onset over the past 3 weeks, progressively worsening. Past history involves congestive heart failure (CHF). Due to concerns of concurrent pneumonia, sputum studies are ordered. Microscopic examination of his sputum demonstrates heart failure cells (hemosiderin-containing macrophages). Which of the following cellular organelles is significant in the formation of these cells?
A) Endoplasmic reticulum (ER)
B) Ribosomes
C) Lysosomes
D) Golgi apparatus
E) Mitochondria
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>64-year-old man</fact1> presents with <fact2>severe respiratory distress</fact2>. This has onset over the past <fact3>3 weeks</fact3>, progressively worsening. Past history involves <fact4>congestive heart failure (CHF)</fact4>. Due to concerns of concurrent pneumonia, sputum studies are ordered. Microscopic examination of his sputum demonstrates <fact5>heart failure cells (hemosiderin-containing macrophages)</fact5>. Which of the following cellular organelles is significant in the formation of these cells?

Answer: The <fact5>heart failure cells (hemosiderin-containing macrophages)</fact5> found in the sputum of the <fact1>64-year-old man</fact1> with a history of <fact4>congestive heart failure (CHF)</fact4> are formed through a process involving the breakdown of red blood cells, which is facilitated by a specific cellular organelle. Considering the role of each option in cellular processes, lysosomes are responsible for cellular digestion and the breakdown of cellular waste and foreign substances, including the degradation of red blood cells. This is relevant to the formation of <fact5>heart failure cells</fact5> as they contain hemosiderin, an iron-storage complex derived from the breakdown of hemoglobin. Therefore, the correct answer is {C}.

question:
A 64-year-old male presents to his primary care physician with a complaint of bilateral knee pain that has been present for the past several years but has worsened recently. He reports pain with climbing stairs and with extended walks of greater than 100 yards. The pain worsens with activity throughout the day and is alleviated by periods of rest. He states that he has minimal morning stiffness, lasting approximately 5-10 minutes after waking up most days. Physical examination reveals tenderness to palpation of the bony structures on the medial aspect of the bilateral knees as well as crepitus and a decreased range of motion, limited at the extremes of flexion and extension. Both knee joints are cool to touch and exhibit bony enlargement upon palpation of the medial joint line. Which of the following studies would be indicated for further work-up of this patient's presenting condition?
A) Complete blood count (CBC)
B) Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR)
C) Rheumatoid factor (RF)
D) MRI of the knee
E) No further work-up needed
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>64-year-old male</fact1> presents to his primary care physician with a complaint of <fact2>bilateral knee pain</fact2> that has been present for the past several years but has <fact3>worsened recently</fact3>. He reports <fact4>pain with climbing stairs</fact4> and with <fact5>extended walks of greater than 100 yards</fact5>. The <fact6>pain worsens with activity throughout the day</fact6> and is <fact7>alleviated by periods of rest</fact7>. He states that he has <fact8>minimal morning stiffness</fact8>, lasting approximately <fact9>5-10 minutes</fact9> after waking up most days. Physical examination reveals <fact10>tenderness to palpation of the bony structures on the medial aspect of the bilateral knees</fact10> as well as <fact11>crepitus</fact11> and a <fact12>decreased range of motion</fact12>, limited at the extremes of <fact13>flexion and extension</fact13>. Both knee joints are <fact14>cool to touch</fact14> and exhibit <fact15>bony enlargement</fact15> upon palpation of the <fact16>medial joint line</fact16>. Which of the following studies would be indicated for further work-up of this patient's presenting condition?

Answer: D) MRI of the knee

Explanation: The patient's presentation of <fact2>bilateral knee pain</fact2> that <fact3>worsens with activity</fact6> and is <fact7>alleviated by rest</fact7>, along with physical examination findings of <fact10>tenderness to palpation of the bony structures</fact10>, <fact11>crepitus</fact11>, and <fact12>decreased range of motion</fact12>, suggests a degenerative joint condition such as osteoarthritis. The <fact8>minimal morning stiffness</fact8> lasting only <fact9>5-10 minutes</fact9> further supports this diagnosis, as prolonged morning stiffness is more characteristic of inflammatory arthritides. Given the clinical presentation, an MRI of the knee would be the most appropriate next step to further evaluate the joint and confirm the diagnosis of osteoarthritis, as it can provide detailed images of the joint cartilage, bones, and surrounding soft tissues.

question:
A 51-year-old man presents the emergency room with chest pain. He mentions that the pain started several hours ago and radiates to his left neck and shoulder. He also mentions that he has some difficulty in breathing. He says that he has had similar chest pains before, but nothing seemed to be wrong at that time. He was diagnosed with high cholesterol during that episode and was prescribed medication. He also has a 3-year history of gastritis. The blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg, respirations are 18/min, and the pulse is 110/min. He seems a little anxious. The physical examination reveals no significant abnormalities. An ECG shows slight changes in the leads. His physician talks to him about the benefits of taking low-dose aspirin daily. Which of the following would be a contraindication to the use of aspirin in this patient?
A) ECG changes
B) Hypercholesterolemia
C) Gastritis
D) Increased pulse rate
E) Age above 50 years
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>51-year-old man</fact1> presents the emergency room with <fact2>chest pain</fact2>. He mentions that the pain started several hours ago and radiates to his <fact3>left neck and shoulder</fact3>. He also mentions that he has some <fact4>difficulty in breathing</fact4>. He says that he has had similar <fact2>chest pains</fact2> before, but nothing seemed to be wrong at that time. He was diagnosed with <fact5>high cholesterol</fact5> during that episode and was prescribed medication. He also has a <fact6>3-year history of gastritis</fact6>. The <fact7>blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg</fact7>, <fact8>respirations are 18/min</fact8>, and the <fact9>pulse is 110/min</fact9>. He seems a little anxious. The physical examination reveals no significant abnormalities. An <fact10>ECG shows slight changes in the leads</fact10>. His physician talks to him about the benefits of taking low-dose aspirin daily. Which of the following would be a contraindication to the use of aspirin in this patient?

Answer: C) Gastritis. Aspirin is known to increase the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding and exacerbate existing gastrointestinal issues. Given the patient's <fact6>3-year history of gastritis</fact6>, the use of aspirin may worsen his condition, making gastritis a contraindication for aspirin use in this patient.

question:
A 52-year-old woman presents with a complaint of headache for the past 10 days. Her headache is diffuse, dull in character, moderate in intensity, and is worse in the morning. It is not associated with fever and sensitivity to light or sound. She experiences occasional nausea but no vomiting. She did not have similar headaches in the past. Her blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg; pulse, 60/min, and body mass index is 33.5 kg/m2. The neurological examination reveals normal extraocular movements. Mild bilateral papilledema is present. A magnetic resonance imaging of the brain reveals a solitary lesion in the left temporal region with predominant hemorrhage. Refer to the image below of the MRI of the brain. Which of the following types of cancer has the highest tendency to cause this brain lesion?
A) Breast cancer
B) Lung cancer
C) Melanoma
D) Multiple myeloma
E) Thyroid cancer
answer:

Answer: 
Considering the <fact12>magnetic resonance imaging of the brain reveals a solitary lesion in the left temporal region with predominant hemorrhage</fact12>, and the patient's presentation of <fact2>headache for the past 10 days</fact2> with <fact11>mild bilateral papilledema</fact11>, it suggests a possible metastatic brain lesion. Among the options provided, melanoma is known for its high propensity to metastasize to the brain and cause hemorrhagic lesions. Therefore, the answer is {C}.

question:
A 81-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after he fell asleep at the dinner table and was not able to be roused by his family. His past medical history is significant for Alzheimer disease though he is still relatively functional at baseline. He has also been taking warfarin over the last 3 months after he suffered a deep venous thrombosis. After he was transported to the ED, his family found that the pills his grandson takes for seizures were missing. On presentation, he is found to be somnolent and physical exam reveals ataxia and nystagmus. After determining the cause of this patient's symptoms, his physicians begin monitoring his international normalized ratio, because they are concerned that it will start trending down. Which of the following treatments would most improve the urinary excretion of the substance likely responsible for these symptoms?
A) Ammonium chloride
B) Ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid
C) Mannitol
D) Sodium bicarbonate
E) Thiazide diuretics
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>81-year-old man</fact1> is brought to the emergency department after he <fact2>fell asleep at the dinner table and was not able to be roused by his family</fact2>. His past medical history is significant for <fact3>Alzheimer disease</fact3> though he is still relatively functional at baseline. He has also been taking <fact4>warfarin</fact4> over the last 3 months after he suffered a <fact5>deep venous thrombosis</fact5>. After he was transported to the ED, his family found that the <fact6>pills his grandson takes for seizures</fact6> were missing. On presentation, he is found to be <fact7>somnolent</fact7> and physical exam reveals <fact8>ataxia</fact8> and <fact9>nystagmus</fact9>. After determining the cause of this patient's symptoms, his physicians begin monitoring his <fact10>international normalized ratio</fact10>, because they are concerned that it will start trending down. Which of the following treatments would most improve the urinary excretion of the substance likely responsible for these symptoms?
A) Ammonium chloride
B) Ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid
C) Mannitol
D) Sodium bicarbonate
E) Thiazide diuretics

Answer: 
Considering the patient's presentation with <fact7>somnolence</fact7>, <fact8>ataxia</fact8>, and <fact9>nystagmus</fact9>, and the fact that his <fact6>grandson's seizure medication</fact6> was found missing, it is likely that the patient ingested a substance that is causing his symptoms. The concern about the patient's <fact10>international normalized ratio (INR)</fact10> trending down suggests that the substance may be affecting his warfarin therapy. Given these factors, the substance most likely responsible for his symptoms is phenytoin, an antiepileptic medication. Among the options provided, <fact11>Sodium bicarbonate</fact11> would most improve the urinary excretion of phenytoin by increasing the pH of the urine, which enhances the excretion of weakly acidic substances like phenytoin. Therefore, the answer is {D}.

question:
A 45-year-old G5P4105 presents to her gynecologist’s office with six months of increasingly heavy periods. She now soaks one super absorbent tampon every two hours for five days each cycle. Her cycles have also become irregular, with intermenstrual bleeding for the last two months. She now experiences significant dysmenorrhea, requiring 400 mg ibuprofen every four hours for the majority of each menses. In addition, she reports new onset mild dyspareunia with intercourse and a “heavy feeling” in her pelvis. She has also noticed increased urinary frequency but denies bowel changes. The patient has a past medical history of obesity and type II diabetes on metformin. Her last child was born four years ago, and she has had five spontaneous vaginal deliveries. At this office visit, temperature is 98.5°F (36.9°C), blood pressure is 137/84 mmHg, pulse is 87/min, and respirations are 14/min. Which of the following physical exam findings is most likely to be present in this patient?
A) Rectouterine septum nodularity
B) Globular 10-week sized uterus
C) Adnexal mass
D) Irregular 14-week sized uterus
E) No remarkable physical exam finding
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>45-year-old G5P4105</fact1> presents to her gynecologist’s office with <fact2>six months of increasingly heavy periods</fact2>. She now soaks one super absorbent tampon every two hours for five days each cycle. Her cycles have also become <fact3>irregular, with intermenstrual bleeding for the last two months</fact3>. She now experiences <fact4>significant dysmenorrhea, requiring 400 mg ibuprofen every four hours for the majority of each menses</fact4>. In addition, she reports <fact5>new onset mild dyspareunia with intercourse and a “heavy feeling” in her pelvis</fact5>. She has also noticed <fact6>increased urinary frequency but denies bowel changes</fact6>. The patient has a past medical history of <fact7>obesity and type II diabetes on metformin</fact7>. Her last child was born four years ago, and she has had five spontaneous vaginal deliveries. At this office visit, temperature is 98.5°F (36.9°C), blood pressure is 137/84 mmHg, pulse is 87/min, and respirations are 14/min. Which of the following physical exam findings is most likely to be present in this patient?
A) Rectouterine septum nodularity
B) Globular 10-week sized uterus
C) Adnexal mass
D) Irregular 14-week sized uterus
E) No remarkable physical exam finding

Answer: 
The patient's presentation of <fact2>six months of increasingly heavy periods</fact2>, <fact3>irregular cycles with intermenstrual bleeding</fact3>, <fact4>significant dysmenorrhea</fact4>, and <fact5>new onset mild dyspareunia</fact5> suggests the presence of uterine fibroids. Uterine fibroids are common in women of reproductive age and can cause heavy menstrual bleeding, pelvic pain, and pressure symptoms. The patient's <fact7>past medical history of obesity and type II diabetes</fact7> may also increase her risk for developing uterine fibroids. Given these symptoms, the most likely physical exam finding is an <fact8>irregularly enlarged uterus</fact8>, which would be consistent with the presence of fibroids. Therefore, the answer is {D}.

question:
A 58-year-old man comes to the physician because he is unable to achieve erections during sexual intercourse. He first noticed the problem 8 months ago, when he became sexually active with a new girlfriend. He states that his relationship with his girlfriend is good, but his inability to engage in sexual intercourse has been frustrating. He has hyperlipidemia and was diagnosed with major depressive disorder 3 years ago. He works as a lawyer and enjoys his job, but he has had a great deal of stress lately. He had not been sexually active for the previous 3 years, since the death of his wife. He does not smoke. He drinks 4–6 beers on weekends. Current medications include simvastatin and citalopram. His temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 135/82 mm Hg. BMI is 30 kg/m2. Pedal pulses are difficult to palpate. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
A) Psychotherapy
B) Penile prosthesis insertion
C) Intracavernous prostaglandin E1 injections
D) Nocturnal penile tumescence testing
E) Switch citalopram to bupropion
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>58-year-old man</fact1> comes to the physician because he is unable to achieve erections during sexual intercourse. He first noticed the problem <fact2>8 months ago</fact2>, when he became sexually active with a new girlfriend. He states that his relationship with his girlfriend is good, but his inability to engage in sexual intercourse has been frustrating. He has <fact3>hyperlipidemia</fact3> and was diagnosed with <fact4>major depressive disorder 3 years ago</fact4>. He works as a lawyer and enjoys his job, but he has had a great deal of <fact5>stress lately</fact5>. He had not been sexually active for the previous <fact6>3 years</fact6>, since the death of his wife. He does not smoke. He drinks <fact7>4–6 beers on weekends</fact7>. Current medications include <fact8>simvastatin</fact8> and <fact9>citalopram</fact9>. His temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 135/82 mm Hg. BMI is <fact10>30 kg/m2</fact10>. Pedal pulses are difficult to palpate. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's history of <fact4>major depressive disorder</fact4> and current medication with <fact9>citalopram</fact9>, a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) known to potentially cause sexual dysfunction, switching to a different antidepressant that may have fewer sexual side effects is a reasonable approach. Bupropion is an antidepressant that is less likely to cause sexual dysfunction compared to SSRIs like citalopram. Therefore, the most appropriate next step in management is to {E} switch citalopram to bupropion.

question:
An investigator is studying traumatic knee joint injuries in college athletes. Images and tissue samples are collected from 4 athletes with cartilaginous injury and 4 athletes with bone fractures. After 8 weeks, the athletes with bone fractures show almost complete resolution, while the athletes with cartilaginous injuries show only minimal signs of healing. The investigator hypothesizes that this is due to the absence of progenitor cells for matrix regeneration. Transplant of which of the following tissues would most likely promote healing in the group with cartilaginous injury?
A) Perichondrium
B) Proteoglycans
C) Chondronectin
D) Osteoblasts
E) Mature chondrocytes
answer:
Reformatted Question: An investigator is studying traumatic knee joint injuries in college athletes. Images and tissue samples are collected from <fact1>4 athletes with cartilaginous injury</fact1> and <fact2>4 athletes with bone fractures</fact2>. After <fact3>8 weeks</fact3>, the athletes with bone fractures show almost complete resolution, while the athletes with cartilaginous injuries show only minimal signs of healing. The investigator hypothesizes that this is due to the absence of <fact4>progenitor cells for matrix regeneration</fact4>. Transplant of which of the following tissues would most likely promote healing in the group with cartilaginous injury?

A) Perichondrium
B) Proteoglycans
C) Chondronectin
D) Osteoblasts
E) Mature chondrocytes

Answer: A) Perichondrium. 

The question states that the athletes with cartilaginous injuries show only minimal signs of healing after <fact3>8 weeks</fact3>, and the investigator hypothesizes that this is due to the absence of <fact4>progenitor cells for matrix regeneration</fact4>. Perichondrium is a tissue that contains progenitor cells capable of differentiating into chondrocytes, which are essential for cartilage regeneration. Therefore, transplanting perichondrium would most likely promote healing in the group with cartilaginous injury.

question:
A 27-year-old man and his wife come to the physician for preconception genetic counseling. The patient and his wife are asymptomatic and have no history of serious illness. The patient's older brother died at age 13 from heart failure and his 6-year-old nephew currently has severe muscle weakness. Genetic testing in the patient's family shows that his mother is not a carrier of the mutation that is responsible for the disease in his relatives. A pedigree chart of the patient's family is shown. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the patient not being affected?
A) Variable expressivity
B) Maternal uniparental disomy
C) Gonadal mosaicism
D) Dominant negative mutation
E) Incomplete penetrance
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>27-year-old man</fact1> and his wife come to the physician for <fact2>preconception genetic counseling</fact2>. The patient and his wife are <fact3>asymptomatic and have no history of serious illness</fact3>. The patient's <fact4>older brother died at age 13 from heart failure</fact4> and his <fact5>6-year-old nephew currently has severe muscle weakness</fact5>. <fact6>Genetic testing in the patient's family shows that his mother is not a carrier of the mutation that is responsible for the disease in his relatives</fact6>. A pedigree chart of the patient's family is shown. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the patient not being affected?

Answer: 
Given that the patient's <fact4>older brother died at age 13 from heart failure</fact4> and his <fact5>6-year-old nephew currently has severe muscle weakness</fact5>, it is clear that there is a serious genetic condition affecting the family. However, <fact6>genetic testing in the patient's family shows that his mother is not a carrier of the mutation</fact6>, which means the mutation must have originated from the paternal side. Since the patient is <fact1>27 years old</fact1> and <fact3>asymptomatic</fact3>, and considering the family history, the most likely explanation for the patient not being affected is that he did not inherit the mutated gene from his father. This scenario is best explained by <fact7>incomplete penetrance</fact7> (choice E), which refers to a situation where some individuals with a disease-causing genotype do not express the disease phenotype.

question:
A 38-year-old woman presents to an urgent care clinic with the complaint of epigastric discomfort and cramping pain for the past 2 hours. She states that she has experienced similar pain in the past. These episodes occur mostly after meals and often subside several hours after she finishes eating. Due to this reason she mostly avoids eating. She says she has lost a few pounds in the last couple of months. She is a smoker and drinks alcohol occasionally. Past medical history is insignificant except for chronic knee pain, for which she takes over the counter painkillers. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), respiratory rate is 16/min, pulse is 77/min, and blood pressure is 120/89 mm Hg. A physical abdominal exam is unremarkable, including examination of the abdomen. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
A) Duodenal peptic ulcer
B) Choledocholithiasis
C) Pancreatitis
D) Gastric peptic ulcer
E) Gallbladder cancer
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>38-year-old woman</fact1> presents to an urgent care clinic with the complaint of <fact2>epigastric discomfort and cramping pain</fact2> for the past <fact3>2 hours</fact3>. She states that she has experienced <fact4>similar pain in the past</fact4>. These episodes occur mostly <fact5>after meals</fact5> and often subside several hours after she finishes eating. Due to this reason she mostly <fact6>avoids eating</fact6>. She says she has <fact7>lost a few pounds in the last couple of months</fact7>. She is a <fact8>smoker</fact8> and drinks <fact9>alcohol occasionally</fact9>. Past medical history is insignificant except for <fact10>chronic knee pain</fact10>, for which she takes over the counter <fact11>painkillers</fact11>. Her <fact12>temperature is 37°C (98.6°F)</fact12>, <fact13>respiratory rate is 16/min</fact13>, <fact14>pulse is 77/min</fact14>, and <fact15>blood pressure is 120/89 mm Hg</fact15>. A physical abdominal exam is <fact16>unremarkable</fact16>, including examination of the abdomen. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
A) Duodenal peptic ulcer
B) Choledocholithiasis
C) Pancreatitis
D) Gastric peptic ulcer
E) Gallbladder cancer

Answer: 
The patient is a <fact1>38-year-old woman</fact1> presenting with <fact2>epigastric discomfort and cramping pain</fact2> that occurs mostly <fact5>after meals</fact5> and subsides several hours after eating, leading her to <fact6>avoid eating</fact6> and resulting in <fact7>weight loss</fact7>. These symptoms are characteristic of a gastric peptic ulcer, which is further supported by her history of <fact8>smoking</fact8> and occasional <fact9>alcohol consumption</fact9>, both of which are risk factors for peptic ulcers. Additionally, her use of over-the-counter <fact11>painkillers</fact11> for <fact10>chronic knee pain</fact10> could contribute to the development of a peptic ulcer. The <fact16>unremarkable physical abdominal exam</fact16> does not rule out a peptic ulcer, as they often do not present with significant abdominal findings. Given these factors, the most likely diagnosis is a gastric peptic ulcer. Therefore, the answer is {D}.

question:
A 35-year-old woman presents to her primary care provider concerned that she may be pregnant. She has a history of regular menstruation every 4 weeks that lasts about 4 days with mild to moderate bleeding, but she missed her last period 2 weeks ago. A home pregnancy test was positive. She has a 6-year history of hyperthyroidism that is well-controlled with daily methimazole. She is currently asymptomatic and has no complaints or concerns. A blood specimen is taken and confirms the diagnosis. Additionally, her thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) is 2.0 μU/mL. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?
A) Continue methimazole
B) Discontinue methimazole, start propylthiouracil
C) Add glucocorticoids
D) Add propranolol
E) Refer for radioiodine therapy
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>35-year-old woman</fact1> presents to her primary care provider concerned that she may be pregnant. She has a history of regular menstruation every 4 weeks that lasts about 4 days with mild to moderate bleeding, but she missed her last period <fact2>2 weeks ago</fact2>. A home pregnancy test was positive. She has a <fact3>6-year history of hyperthyroidism</fact3> that is well-controlled with daily <fact4>methimazole</fact4>. She is currently asymptomatic and has no complaints or concerns. A blood specimen is taken and confirms the diagnosis. Additionally, her <fact5>thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) is 2.0 μU/mL</fact5>. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's <fact3>6-year history of hyperthyroidism</fact3> and her current pregnancy, it is crucial to manage her hyperthyroidism carefully to avoid any adverse effects on the fetus. The patient is currently on <fact4>methimazole</fact4>, which is contraindicated during the first trimester of pregnancy due to the risk of congenital anomalies. Therefore, the next best step in the management of this patient is to discontinue <fact4>methimazole</fact4> and start <fact6>propylthiouracil</fact6>, which is safer during pregnancy. The answer is {B}.

question:
A 61-year-old man presents to the clinic with complaints of excessive thirst, frequent urination, and partial visual loss in both eyes for 1 day. His family history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus in his mother and cousin. His weight is 112 kg ( 246.9 lb), height 187 cm (6 ft 1 in), blood pressure: 150/90 mm Hg, heart rate: 89/min, respiratory rate: 14/min, and temperature: 36.7℃ (98.4℉). The physical examination is significant for dry skin, a pustular rash over the patient’s shoulders and back, an accentuated second heart sound (S2) best heard in the second intercostal space at the right sternal border, and distal loss of vibration sensitivity in both feet. A fundoscopic examination shows small red dots in the superficial retinal layers suggestive of microaneurysms. The HbA1c is 9% and the urinalysis shows the following:
Color Pale yellow (light/pale-to-dark/deep amber)
Clarity Cloudy
pH 6.6
Specific gravity 1.010
Glucose 199 mg/dl
Ketones None
Nitrites Negative
Leukocyte esterase Negative
Bilirubin Negative
Urinary bilirubin Traces
Red blood cells 3 RBCs
Protein 120 mg/d
RBCs ≤ 2 RBCs/hpf
WBCs 22 WBCs/hpf
Epithelial cells 27 squamous epithelial cells/hpf
Casts 5 hyaline casts/lpf
Crystals Occasional
Bacteria None
Yeast Present
Which of the following statements best describes the cause of this patient’s glucosuria?
A) Yeasts metabolize glucogenic amino acids which are filtered in the urine into glucose
B) There is a disruption of primary active transport of glucose in the proximal renal tubules
C) Secondary active transporters fail to completely reabsorb glucose in the renal tubules
D) There is a disruption of passive transport of the glucose in the proximal renal tubules
E) Glucosuria results from increased glomerular filtration rate
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A 61-year-old man presents to the clinic with complaints of <fact1>excessive thirst</fact1>, <fact2>requent urination</fact2>, and <fact3>partial visual loss</fact3> in both eyes for 1 day. His family history is significant for <fact4>type 2 diabetes mellitus</fact4> in his mother and cousin. His weight is 112 kg ( 246.9 lb), height 187 cm (6 ft 1 in), blood pressure: 150/90 mm Hg, heart rate: 89/min, respiratory rate: 14/min, and temperature: 36.7℃ (98.4℉). The physical examination is significant for <fact5>dry skin</fact5>, a <fact6>pustular rash</fact6> over the patient’s shoulders and back, an accentuated second heart sound (S2) best heard in the second intercostal space at the right sternal border, and <fact7>distal loss of vibration sensitivity</fact7> in both feet. A fundoscopic examination shows <fact8>small red dots in the superficial retinal layers suggestive of microaneurysms</fact8>. The <fact9>HbA1c is 9%</fact9> and the urinalysis shows the following:
Color Pale yellow (light/pale-to-dark/deep amber)
Clarity Cloudy
pH 6.6
Specific gravity 1.010
<fact10>Glucose 199 mg/dl</fact10>
<fact11>Ketones None</fact11>
Nitrites Negative
Leukocyte esterase Negative
Bilirubin Negative
Urinary bilirubin Traces
Red blood cells 3 RBCs
Protein 120 mg/d
RBCs ≤ 2 RBCs/hpf
WBCs 22 WBCs/hpf
Epithelial cells 27 squamous epithelial cells/hpf
Casts 5 hyaline casts/lpf
Crystals Occasional
Bacteria None
<fact12>Yeast Present</fact12>
Which of the following statements best describes the cause of this patient’s <fact10>glucosuria</fact10>?

Answer: 
The patient's <fact10>glucosuria</fact10> is most likely due to the high blood glucose levels secondary to <fact4>type 2 diabetes mellitus</fact4>. The patient's <fact9>HbA1c is 9%</fact9>, indicating poor blood glucose control. Normally, the kidneys are able to reabsorb glucose from the filtrate back into the bloodstream through secondary active transport in the proximal renal tubules. However, when blood glucose levels exceed the reabsorptive capacity of the kidneys, glucose appears in the urine, resulting in <fact10>glucosuria</fact10>. The presence of <fact12>yeast</fact12> in the urinalysis is likely a secondary finding, as yeast can ferment glucose in the urine, but it is not the cause of the <fact10>glucosuria</fact10>. The correct answer is {C} There is a disruption of secondary active transport of glucose in the renal tubules.

question:
A 54-year-old woman presents with sudden onset, mild vaginal bleeding for the past day. She says she is postmenopausal, and her last menstrual period was 5 years ago. A detailed workup is performed, and several premalignant lesions are found in her uterus. The patient agrees to a hysterectomy. The surgical team decides to use an anesthesia protocol consisting of nitrous oxide, desflurane, and atracurium. Which of the following best describes the role of atracurium in this patient’s anesthesia?
A) It reduces neuron and muscle tissue excitability
B) It increases GABA linked chloride channel opening
C) It acts on the pain centers in the spinal cord and brain
D) It competes with acetylcholine for binding sites in the neuromuscular junction
E) It persistently depolarizes the cholinergic receptors on the motor end plate
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>54-year-old woman</fact1> presents with <fact2>sudden onset, mild vaginal bleeding</fact2> for the past day. She says she is <fact3>postmenopausal</fact3>, and her last menstrual period was <fact4>5 years ago</fact4>. A detailed workup is performed, and several <fact5>premalignant lesions</fact5> are found in her uterus. The patient agrees to a <fact6>hysterectomy</fact6>. The surgical team decides to use an <fact7>anesthesia protocol</fact7> consisting of <fact8>nitrous oxide, desflurane, and atracurium</fact8>. Which of the following best describes the role of <fact9>atracurium</fact9> in this patient’s <fact10>anesthesia</fact10>?

Answer: 
Considering the <fact7>anesthesia protocol</fact7> used for the <fact6>hysterectomy</fact6>, which includes <fact8>nitrous oxide, desflurane, and atracurium</fact8>, the role of <fact9>atracurium</fact9> can be understood by its mechanism of action. Atracurium is a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocker that works by competing with the neurotransmitter acetylcholine for binding sites at the neuromuscular junction, thus preventing acetylcholine from triggering muscle contraction. This action leads to muscle relaxation, which is essential for surgical procedures like a <fact6>hysterectomy</fact6>. Therefore, the correct answer is {D}.

question:
A 24-year-old woman is brought to the physician because of agitation, confusion, and lethargy. She has also had progressive recurring headaches and visual impairment over the last month. Three days ago, she had a seizure but has not seen a physician. She is oriented only to person. Her temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 110/80 mm Hg. Capillary refill time is more than 3 seconds. Her laboratory studies show:
Hemoglobin 11.2 g/dL
Leukocyte count 7000/mm3
Serum
Na+ 148 mEq/L
Cl- 100 mEq/L
K+ 3.8 mEq/L
HCO3- 26 mEq/L
Urea nitrogen 18 mg/L
Glucose 90 mg/L
Creatinine 0.8 mg/L
Osmolality 300 mOsmol/kg H2O
Urine osmolality 240 mOsm/kg H2O
Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's hypernatremia?"
A) Increased water intake
B) Increased antidiuretic hormone secretion
C) Increased adrenocorticotropin hormone secretion
D) Decreased antidiuretic hormone secretion
E) Decreased adrenocorticotropin hormone secretion
answer:
Reformatted Question:

A 24-year-old woman is brought to the physician because of <fact1>agitation, confusion, and lethargy</fact1>. She has also had <fact2>progressive recurring headaches and visual impairment</fact2> over the last month. Three days ago, she had a <fact3>seizure</fact3> but has not seen a physician. She is oriented only to person. Her <fact4>temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F)</fact4>, <fact5>pulse is 90/min</fact5>, and <fact6>blood pressure is 110/80 mm Hg</fact6>. Capillary refill time is more than 3 seconds. Her laboratory studies show:
<fact7>Hemoglobin 11.2 g/dL</fact7>
<fact8>Leukocyte count 7000/mm3</fact8>
Serum
<fact9>Na+ 148 mEq/L</fact9>
<fact10>Cl- 100 mEq/L</fact10>
<fact11>K+ 3.8 mEq/L</fact11>
<fact12>HCO3- 26 mEq/L</fact12>
<fact13>Urea nitrogen 18 mg/L</fact13>
<fact14>Glucose 90 mg/L</fact14>
<fact15>Creatinine 0.8 mg/L</fact15>
<fact16>Osmolality 300 mOsmol/kg H2O</fact16>
<fact17>Urine osmolality 240 mOsm/kg H2O</fact17>
Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's <fact18>hypernatremia</fact18>?

Answer:

The patient's laboratory results show a serum sodium level of <fact9>148 mEq/L</fact9>, which is indicative of <fact18>hypernatremia</fact18>. To determine the cause of the hypernatremia, it is essential to consider the patient's overall clinical presentation and laboratory findings. The patient's <fact16>osmolality is 300 mOsmol/kg H2O</fact16>, and the <fact17>urine osmolality is 240 mOsm/kg H2O</fact17>, which suggests an inappropriately low urine osmolality in the context of hypernatremia. This pattern is most consistent with <fact19>central diabetes insipidus (DI)</fact19>, a condition characterized by <fact20>decreased antidiuretic hormone (ADH) secretion</fact20>. Decreased ADH secretion leads to an inability to concentrate urine, resulting in hypernatremia due to free water loss. Therefore, the most likely explanation for this patient's hypernatremia is {D} <fact20>decreased antidiuretic hormone secretion</fact20>.

question:
A 22-year-old man presents to the medical clinic after getting bit in the hand by a stray dog 2 days ago. The patient has no past medical history and takes no prescription medications. He does not drink alcohol or smoke cigarettes. The patient’s vitals are currently within normal limits. On examination, the physician notices 2 clean puncture wounds with localized cellulitis. Capillary refill is 2 seconds. Sensorimotor evaluation of the hand is without deficits. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment choice for this patient?
A) Amoxicillin
B) Amoxicillin-clavulanate
C) Clindamycin
D) Doxycycline
E) Azithromycin
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>22-year-old man</fact1> presents to the medical clinic after getting <fact2>bit in the hand by a stray dog</fact2> <fact3>2 days ago</fact3>. The patient has <fact4>no past medical history</fact4> and takes <fact5>no prescription medications</fact5>. He does not <fact6>drink alcohol or smoke cigarettes</fact6>. The patient’s <fact7>vitals are currently within normal limits</fact7>. On examination, the physician notices <fact8>2 clean puncture wounds with localized cellulitis</fact8>. <fact9>Capillary refill is 2 seconds</fact9>. <fact10>Sensorimotor evaluation of the hand is without deficits</fact10>. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment choice for this patient?
A) Amoxicillin
B) Amoxicillin-clavulanate
C) Clindamycin
D) Doxycycline
E) Azithromycin

Answer: 
Considering the patient's presentation after a <fact2>dog bite</fact2> with <fact8>2 clean puncture wounds and localized cellulitis</fact8>, antibiotic treatment is necessary to prevent infection. Given the patient's <fact4>no past medical history</fact4> and <fact5>no prescription medications</fact5>, the choice of antibiotic should cover common pathogens associated with dog bites, including Pasteurella, Streptococcus, and Staphylococcus species. Among the options provided, Amoxicillin-clavulanate is a broad-spectrum antibiotic that effectively covers these pathogens and is commonly recommended for dog bite wounds. Therefore, the answer is {B}.

question:
A 33-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 26 weeks' gestation presents to the emergency department because of frequent contractions. The contractions last 40 seconds, occur every 2 minutes, and are increasing in intensity. She has a history of recurrent painful ulcers on her vulva, but she currently does not have them. Her first child was delivered by lower segment transverse cesarean section because of a non-reassuring fetal heart rate. Her current medications include acyclovir, folic acid, and a multivitamin. Her temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), heart rate is 88/min, and blood pressure is 126/76 mm Hg. Contractions are felt on the abdomen. The cervix is dilated to 5 cm, 70% effaced, and the station of the head is -2. A fetal ultrasound shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
A) Allow vaginal delivery
B) Initiate misoprostol therapy
C) Initiate nifedipine therapy
D) Perform cesarean delivery
E) Perform dilation and evacuation
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>33-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1</fact1>, at <fact2>26 weeks' gestation</fact2> presents to the emergency department because of <fact3>requent contractions</fact3>. The contractions last <fact4>40 seconds</fact4>, occur every <fact5>2 minutes</fact5>, and are increasing in intensity. She has a history of <fact6>recurrent painful ulcers on her vulva</fact6>, but she currently does not have them. Her first child was delivered by <fact7>lower segment transverse cesarean section</fact7> because of a <fact8>non-reassuring fetal heart rate</fact8>. Her current medications include <fact9>acyclovir, folic acid, and a multivitamin</fact9>. Her temperature is <fact10>36.9°C (98.4°F)</fact10>, heart rate is <fact11>88/min</fact11>, and blood pressure is <fact12>126/76 mm Hg</fact12>. Contractions are felt on the abdomen. The cervix is dilated to <fact13>5 cm</fact13>, <fact14>70% effaced</fact14>, and the station of the head is <fact15>-2</fact15>. A fetal ultrasound shows <fact16>no abnormalities</fact16>. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

Answer: 
Given the patient's presentation with <fact3>requent contractions</fact3> at <fact2>26 weeks' gestation</fact2>, the primary concern is preterm labor. The patient's history of <fact7>lower segment transverse cesarean section</fact7> due to a <fact8>non-reassuring fetal heart rate</fact8> is important, but the current situation necessitates addressing the preterm labor. The patient's current cervical dilation to <fact13>5 cm</fact13> and <fact14>70% effaced</fact14> indicates active labor. Considering the gestational age and the absence of any contraindications for tocolysis, the most appropriate next step in management is to attempt to slow down or stop the labor using medications. Among the options provided, initiating <fact17>nifedipine therapy</fact17> is a common approach for tocolysis in preterm labor. Therefore, the answer is {C}.

question:
A 70-year-old man with a history of hypertension and atrial fibrillation comes to the physician for shortness of breath with mild exertion, progressive weakness, and a dry cough that has persisted for 6 months. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 45 years. His medications include warfarin, enalapril, and amiodarone. His pulse is 85/min and irregularly irregular. Physical examination shows enlarged fingertips and markedly curved nails. A CT scan of the chest shows clustered air spaces and reticular opacities in the basal parts of the lung. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient's dyspnea?
A) Chronic airway inflammation
B) Bronchial hyperresponsiveness and obstruction
C) Fluid leak into the interstitium and alveoli
D) Pleural scarring
E) Excess collagen deposition in the extracellular matrix of the lung
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>70-year-old man</fact1> with a history of <fact2>hypertension and atrial fibrillation</fact2> comes to the physician for <fact3>shortness of breath with mild exertion, progressive weakness, and a dry cough that has persisted for 6 months</fact3>. He has <fact4>smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 45 years</fact4>. His medications include <fact5>warfarin, enalapril, and amiodarone</fact5>. His <fact6>pulse is 85/min and irregularly irregular</fact6>. Physical examination shows <fact7>enlarged fingertips and markedly curved nails</fact7>. A <fact8>CT scan of the chest shows clustered air spaces and reticular opacities in the basal parts of the lung</fact8>. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient's <fact3>dyspnea</fact3>?

A) Chronic airway inflammation
B) Bronchial hyperresponsiveness and obstruction
C) Fluid leak into the interstitium and alveoli
D) Pleural scarring
E) Excess collagen deposition in the extracellular matrix of the lung

Answer: The patient's presentation of <fact3>shortness of breath with mild exertion, progressive weakness, and a dry cough that has persisted for 6 months</fact3> along with the findings on the <fact8>CT scan of the chest showing clustered air spaces and reticular opacities in the basal parts of the lung</fact8> are indicative of interstitial lung disease. The patient's history of <fact4>smoking a pack of cigarettes daily for 45 years</fact4> and the presence of <fact7>enlarged fingertips and markedly curved nails</fact7>, suggestive of clubbing, further support this diagnosis. The most likely underlying mechanism of this patient's <fact3>dyspnea</fact3> is therefore related to the lung's interstitial space. Among the options provided, the one that directly relates to the interstitial space is {E} Excess collagen deposition in the extracellular matrix of the lung, which is characteristic of pulmonary fibrosis, a type of interstitial lung disease.

question:
A 3-year-old male is brought by his mother to the pediatrician's office. The mother and child are refugees from Somalia and arrived in the United States one week ago. They were recently placed in temporary housing. The mother reports that the child has been chronically tired and subdued since before their arrival in the United States. The child was born at 38 weeks gestation with the help of a local midwife. The child’s temperature is 98.2°F (36.8°C), blood pressure is 105/60 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, and respirations are 18/min. Physical examination reveals a listless child with a rotund abdomen and positive fluid wave. Notable lower extremity edema is present. This patient's condition is most likely caused by a deficiency in which of the following?
A) Total caloric intake
B) Relative protein intake
C) Relative carbohydrate intake
D) Relative fat intake
E) Vitamin intake
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>3-year-old male</fact1> is brought by his mother to the pediatrician's office. The mother and child are <fact2>refugees from Somalia</fact2> and arrived in the United States one week ago. They were recently placed in <fact3>temporary housing</fact3>. The mother reports that the child has been <fact4>chronically tired and subdued</fact4> since before their arrival in the United States. The child was born at <fact5>38 weeks gestation</fact5> with the help of a local midwife. The child’s <fact6>temperature is 98.2°F (36.8°C)</fact6>, <fact7>blood pressure is 105/60 mmHg</fact7>, <fact8>pulse is 90/min</fact8>, and <fact9>respirations are 18/min</fact9>. Physical examination reveals a <fact10>listless child</fact10> with a <fact11>rotund abdomen</fact11> and <fact12>positive fluid wave</fact12>. Notable <fact13>lower extremity edema</fact13> is present. This patient's condition is most likely caused by a deficiency in which of the following?
A) Total caloric intake
B) Relative protein intake
C) Relative carbohydrate intake
D) Relative fat intake
E) Vitamin intake

Answer: B) Relative protein intake

Explanation: The child's presentation with <fact4>chronic tiredness and subdued behavior</fact4>, a <fact10>listless</fact10> appearance, <fact11>rotund abdomen</fact11>, <fact12>positive fluid wave</fact12>, and <fact13>lower extremity edema</fact13> is highly suggestive of kwashiorkor, a form of malnutrition characterized by a lack of sufficient protein intake despite potentially adequate caloric intake. This condition is often seen in individuals from regions with limited access to nutrient-rich foods, such as refugees from Somalia (<fact2>refugees from Somalia</fact2>) living in <fact3>temporary housing</fact3>, where access to nutritious food may be limited. The child's <fact5>birth at 38 weeks gestation</fact5> and the mother's report of symptoms preceding their arrival in the United States further support the likelihood of a long-standing nutritional deficiency, specifically a relative protein intake deficiency.

question:
A 54-year-old woman presents with fatigue, malaise, and shortness of breath over the past 5 months. Past medical history is significant for rheumatoid arthritis diagnosed 23 years ago for which she takes naproxen as needed. Her vital signs include: temperature 36.9°C (98.4°F), blood pressure 135/88 mm Hg, pulse 92/min. Physical examination is significant for conjunctival pallor and bilateral ulnar deviation of the metacarpophalangeal joints. Laboratory findings are significant for the following:
Hemoglobin 9.2 g/dL
Mean corpuscular volume 76 fL
Leukocyte count 7,000/mm3
Platelet count 220,000/mm3
Serum ferritin 310 ng/mL
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate 85 mm/h
Which of the following is a feature of this patient's anemia?
A) ↑ serum transferrin receptors
B) ↑ transferrin saturation
C) ↑ methylmalonic acid
D) Upregulation of hepcidin
E) ↑ reticulocyte count
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>54-year-old woman</fact1> presents with <fact2>fatigue, malaise, and shortness of breath</fact2> over the past <fact3>5 months</fact3>. Past medical history is significant for <fact4>rheumatoid arthritis</fact4> diagnosed <fact5>23 years ago</fact5> for which she takes <fact6>naproxen as needed</fact6>. Her vital signs include: <fact7>temperature 36.9°C (98.4°F)</fact7>, <fact8>blood pressure 135/88 mm Hg</fact8>, <fact9>pulse 92/min</fact9>. Physical examination is significant for <fact10>conjunctival pallor</fact10> and <fact11>bilateral ulnar deviation of the metacarpophalangeal joints</fact11>. Laboratory findings are significant for the following:
<fact12>Hemoglobin 9.2 g/dL</fact12>
<fact13>Mean corpuscular volume 76 fL</fact13>
<fact14>Leukocyte count 7,000/mm3</fact14>
<fact15>Platelet count 220,000/mm3</fact15>
<fact16>Serum ferritin 310 ng/mL</fact16>
<fact17>Erythrocyte sedimentation rate 85 mm/h</fact17>
Which of the following is a feature of this patient's anemia?

Answer: 
The patient presents with <fact2>fatigue, malaise, and shortness of breath</fact2> and laboratory findings show a <fact12>low hemoglobin level of 9.2 g/dL</fact12> and a <fact13>mean corpuscular volume (MCV) of 76 fL</fact13>, indicating a microcytic anemia. The <fact16>serum ferritin level is elevated at 310 ng/mL</fact16>, which is not typical of iron-deficiency anemia. Instead, the elevated ferritin level, in combination with the patient's history of <fact4>rheumatoid arthritis</fact4>, suggests anemia of chronic disease. A key feature of anemia of chronic disease is the <fact18>upregulation of hepcidin</fact18>, a hormone that regulates iron metabolism and leads to decreased iron availability for erythropoiesis. Therefore, the correct answer is {D}.

question:
A clinical researcher is interested in creating a new drug for HIV patients. Darunavir has been particularly efficacious in recent patients; however, some have experienced an increased incidence of hyperglycemia. A new drug called DN501 is developed with the same mechanism of action as darunavir but fewer side effects. Which of the following is the mechanism of action of DN501?
A) Prevents viral transcription
B) Inhibits viral assembly
C) Inhibits integration of viral genome into the host cell
D) Inhibits viral entry
E) Prevents T-cell binding
answer:
Reformatted Question: A clinical researcher is interested in creating a new drug for <fact1>HIV patients</fact1>. <fact2>Darunavir</fact2> has been particularly efficacious in recent patients; however, some have experienced an increased incidence of <fact3>hyperglycemia</fact3>. A new drug called <fact4>DN501</fact4> is developed with the same mechanism of action as <fact2>darunavir</fact2> but fewer side effects. Which of the following is the mechanism of action of <fact4>DN501</fact4>?

A) Prevents viral transcription
B) Inhibits viral assembly
C) Inhibits integration of viral genome into the host cell
D) Inhibits viral entry
E) Prevents T-cell binding

Answer: Considering that <fact4>DN501</fact4> has the same mechanism of action as <fact2>darunavir</fact2>, we should first identify the mechanism of action of darunavir. Darunavir is a protease inhibitor used in the treatment of HIV infection. Protease inhibitors work by binding to the protease active site in the virus, preventing the protease from cleaving the viral polyproteins into functional proteins necessary for viral replication. However, none of the options directly describe the action of a protease inhibitor. Among the options provided, the closest mechanism related to the action of a protease inhibitor would be inhibiting viral assembly, as protease inhibitors prevent the proper assembly of viral particles by blocking the processing of viral proteins. Therefore, the answer is {B}.

question:
A patient is unresponsive in the emergency department following a motor vehicle accident. The patient's written advance directive states that he does not wish to be resuscitated in the event of a cardiac arrest. The patient's wife arrives and demands that "everything" be done to keep him alive because she "can't go on living without him." The patient's adult son is on his way to the hospital. If the patient arrests, which of the following should occur?
A) Respect the wife's wishes and resuscitate the patient
B) Respect the patient's prior wishes and do not resuscitate
C) Allow the patient's adult son to make the final decision on whether or not to resuscitate
D) Consult a judge for the final decision on whether or not to resuscitate
E) Consult the hospital ethics committee
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A patient is unresponsive in the emergency department following a <fact1>motor vehicle accident</fact1>. The patient's <fact2>written advance directive</fact2> states that he does not wish to be resuscitated in the event of a <fact3>cardiac arrest</fact3>. The patient's <fact4>wife</fact4> arrives and demands that "everything" be done to keep him alive because she "can't go on living without him." The patient's <fact5>adult son</fact5> is on his way to the hospital. If the patient arrests, which of the following should occur?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's <fact2>written advance directive</fact2> explicitly stating his wish not to be resuscitated in the event of a <fact3>cardiac arrest</fact3>, this document serves as a clear expression of his autonomy and medical decision-making preferences. Although the patient's <fact4>wife</fact4> and <fact5>adult son</fact5> have emotional stakes in the decision, the patient's advance directive takes precedence over their wishes. Therefore, the most appropriate course of action is to respect the patient's prior wishes and not resuscitate him if he arrests. The answer is {B}.

question:
A 26-year-old Caucasian woman is admitted to the emergency department after 4 days of fever, malaise, vomiting, and nausea for which she has been taking ibuprofen and diclofenac. She has also noticed a decrease in urination. Her family and past medical history are unremarkable. Her temperature is 38.2°C (100.7°F), blood pressure is 118/76 mm Hg, heart rate is 74/min, and respiratory rate is 15/min. Upon physical examination, her mucous membranes are moist and she has no abdominal tenderness. Four hours after admission, she has a urinary output < 0.3 mL/kg/h and laboratory tests significant for the following:
Differential blood count
White blood cells 8.1 x 109/L
Neutrophils 4.8 x 109/L
Lymphocytes 2.1 x 109/L
Eosinophils 0.9 x 109/L
Monocytes 0.3 x 109/L
Basophils 0.04 x 109/L
  Serum creatinine (SCr) 1.9 mg/dL
Blood urea nitrogen (BUN) 25 mg/dL
Na+ 135 mEq/L
K+ 5.4 mEq/L
Cl- 106 mEq/L
Urine dipstick
Urine density 1.010
pH 6.2
Red blood cells per field of high power 2
WBC casts Present
Which of the following skin manifestations would you also expect to find in this patient?
A) Livedo reticularis
B) Janeway lesions
C) Diffuse maculopapular rash
D) Malar rash
E) Erythema nodosum
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>26-year-old Caucasian woman</fact1> is admitted to the emergency department after <fact2>4 days of fever, malaise, vomiting, and nausea</fact2> for which she has been taking <fact3>ibuprofen and diclofenac</fact3>. She has also noticed a <fact4>decrease in urination</fact4>. Her family and past medical history are unremarkable. Her <fact5>temperature is 38.2°C (100.7°F)</fact5>, <fact6>blood pressure is 118/76 mm Hg</fact6>, <fact7>heart rate is 74/min</fact7>, and <fact8>respiratory rate is 15/min</fact8>. Upon physical examination, her <fact9>mucous membranes are moist</fact9> and she has no <fact10>abdominal tenderness</fact10>. Four hours after admission, she has a <fact11>urinary output < 0.3 mL/kg/h</fact11> and laboratory tests significant for the following:
Differential blood count
<fact12>White blood cells 8.1 x 109/L</fact12>
<fact13>Neutrophils 4.8 x 109/L</fact13>
<fact14>Lymphocytes 2.1 x 109/L</fact14>
<fact15>Eosinophils 0.9 x 109/L</fact15>
<fact16>Monocytes 0.3 x 109/L</fact16>
<fact17>Basophils 0.04 x 109/L</fact17>
  <fact18>Serum creatinine (SCr) 1.9 mg/dL</fact18>
<fact19>Blood urea nitrogen (BUN) 25 mg/dL</fact19>
<fact20>Na+ 135 mEq/L</fact20>
<fact21>K+ 5.4 mEq/L</fact21>
<fact22>Cl- 106 mEq/L</fact22>
Urine dipstick
<fact23>Urine density 1.010</fact23>
<fact24>pH 6.2</fact24>
<fact25>Red blood cells per field of high power 2</fact25>
<fact26>WBC casts Present</fact26>
Which of the following skin manifestations would you also expect to find in this patient?

Answer: C) Diffuse maculopapular rash

Explanation: Given the patient's presentation with <fact2>fever, malaise, vomiting, and nausea</fact2> after taking <fact3>ibuprofen and diclofenac</fact3>, along with a <fact4>decrease in urination</fact4> and laboratory findings indicating acute kidney injury (<fact11>urinary output < 0.3 mL/kg/h</fact11>, <fact18>SCr 1.9 mg/dL</fact18>, and <fact19>BUN 25 mg/dL</fact19>), it is likely that the patient is experiencing an allergic interstitial nephritis (AIN) secondary to the nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). AIN is often associated with a <fact25>presence of red blood cells</fact25> and <fact26>WBC casts</fact26> in the urine. Additionally, a <fact15>relative eosinophilia</fact15> is sometimes seen in AIN, as indicated by the patient's <fact15>eosinophils 0.9 x 109/L</fact15>. A common extrarenal manifestation of AIN is a <fact27>skin rash</fact27>, typically a diffuse maculopapular rash, which is why option C is the correct answer.

question:
A 56-year-old man is brought to the emergency room after a motor vehicle accident. The patient’s vitals are as follows: blood pressure 80/40 mm Hg, heart rate 111/min, respiratory rate 39/min, and temperature 37.1°C (98.8℉). On physical examination, the patient is unconscious with a GCS of 9/15 and is cyanotic. There are open fractures of the left femur and left tibia, a likely shoulder dislocation, multiple contusions on the limbs and thorax, and a puncture wound on the left side of his chest. There are no breath sounds on the left side and there is hyperresonance to percussion on the left. Preparations are made for an emergency needle thoracostomy to be performed to treat this patient’s likely tension pneumothorax. Which one of the following is the best choice to provide informed consent for this procedure?
A) The patient’s closest relatives (spouse, child or parent), who must be brought to the hospital as fast as possible
B) One of the witnesses at the scene of the car accident, who should be brought to the hospital as fast as possible
C) The hospital ethics committee
D) Informed consent is not needed in this case
E) The hospital lawyer should immediately give temporary medical power of attorney to a member of the hospital ethics committee who will make all the medical decisions for the patient only until the patient is conscious again.
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>56-year-old man</fact1> is brought to the emergency room after a <fact2>motor vehicle accident</fact2>. The patient’s vitals are as follows: <fact3>blood pressure 80/40 mm Hg, heart rate 111/min, respiratory rate 39/min, and temperature 37.1°C (98.8℉)</fact3>. On physical examination, the patient is <fact4>unconscious with a GCS of 9/15</fact4> and is <fact5>cyanotic</fact5>. There are <fact6>open fractures of the left femur and left tibia, a likely shoulder dislocation, multiple contusions on the limbs and thorax, and a puncture wound on the left side of his chest</fact6>. There are <fact7>no breath sounds on the left side</fact7> and there is <fact8>hyperresonance to percussion on the left</fact8>. Preparations are made for an emergency <fact9>needle thoracostomy</fact9> to be performed to treat this patient’s likely <fact10>tension pneumothorax</fact10>. Which one of the following is the best choice to provide informed consent for this procedure?
A) The patient’s closest relatives (spouse, child or parent), who must be brought to the hospital as fast as possible
B) One of the witnesses at the scene of the car accident, who should be brought to the hospital as fast as possible
C) The hospital ethics committee
D) Informed consent is not needed in this case
E) The hospital lawyer should immediately give temporary medical power of attorney to a member of the hospital ethics committee who will make all the medical decisions for the patient only until the patient is conscious again.

Answer: Considering the patient is <fact4>unconscious with a GCS of 9/15</fact4> and requires immediate medical intervention due to a life-threatening condition (<fact10>tension pneumothorax</fact10>), the need for prompt treatment supersedes the need for informed consent from the patient himself. Given the emergency nature of the situation, there isn't time to obtain consent from the patient’s closest relatives (A) or one of the witnesses (B), and involving the hospital ethics committee (C) or lawyer (E) would also cause unnecessary delay. Therefore, the best answer is {D}.

question:
A previously healthy 30-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of pain during sexual intercourse for 6 months. She also reports frequent episodes of crampy pelvic pain that starts one day before menses and lasts for 7 days. Her symptoms are not relieved with pain medication. Menses occur at regular 28-day intervals and last 5 days. Her last menstrual period was 2 weeks ago. She is sexually active with her husband. She uses a combined oral contraceptive pill. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows rectovaginal tenderness. Cervical and urethral swabs are negative. Transvaginal ultrasonography shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
A) Measurement of CA-125 levels
B) Hysterectomy
C) Laparoscopy
D) Hysteroscopy
E) CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>previously healthy 30-year-old woman</fact1> comes to the physician for the evaluation of <fact2>pain during sexual intercourse</fact2> for <fact3>6 months</fact3>. She also reports <fact4>requent episodes of crampy pelvic pain</fact4> that starts one day before <fact5>menstruation</fact5> and lasts for <fact6>7 days</fact6>. Her symptoms are not relieved with <fact7>pain medication</fact7>. <fact8>Menses occur at regular 28-day intervals</fact8> and last <fact9>5 days</fact9>. Her <fact10>last menstrual period was 2 weeks ago</fact10>. She is <fact11>sexually active with her husband</fact11>. She uses a <fact12>combined oral contraceptive pill</fact12>. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows <fact13>rectovaginal tenderness</fact13>. <fact14>Cervical and urethral swabs are negative</fact14>. <fact15>Transvaginal ultrasonography shows no abnormalities</fact15>. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's symptoms of <fact2>pain during sexual intercourse</fact2> and <fact4>requent episodes of crampy pelvic pain</fact4> that are not relieved with <fact7>pain medication</fact7>, along with the presence of <fact13>rectovaginal tenderness</fact13> and negative <fact14>cervical and urethral swabs</fact14>, the most likely diagnosis is endometriosis. Given the patient's <fact8>regular menstrual cycle</fact8> and <fact10>last menstrual period was 2 weeks ago</fact10>, and the absence of abnormalities on <fact15>transvaginal ultrasonography</fact15>, the most appropriate next step in management would be to perform a laparoscopy to visually inspect the pelvic cavity for endometrial implants. Therefore, the answer is {C}.

question:
A 5-year-old male presents to the pediatrician with a 10-day history of cough that is worse at night. The patient has a history of mild intermittent asthma and has been using his albuterol inhaler without relief. He has also been complaining of headache and sore throat, and his mother has noticed worsening rhinorrhea. The patient’s past medical history is otherwise unremarkable, and he has no known drug allergies. In the office, his temperature is 101.8°F (38.8°C), blood pressure is 88/65 mmHg, pulse is 132/min, and respirations are 16/min. The patient has purulent mucus draining from the nares, and his face is tender to palpation over the maxillary sinuses. His pharynx is erythematous with symmetric swelling of the tonsils. On lung exam, he has moderate bilateral expiratory wheezing.

Which of the following is the best next step in management?
A) Amoxicillin
B) Amoxicillin-clavulanic acid
C) Ampicillin-sulbactam
D) Clindamycin
E) Levofloxacin
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>5-year-old male</fact1> presents to the pediatrician with a <fact2>10-day history of cough that is worse at night</fact2>. The patient has a history of <fact3>mild intermittent asthma</fact3> and has been using his <fact4>albuterol inhaler without relief</fact4>. He has also been complaining of <fact5>headache and sore throat</fact5>, and his mother has noticed <fact6>worsening rhinorrhea</fact6>. The patient’s past medical history is otherwise unremarkable, and he has no known <fact7>drug allergies</fact7>. In the office, his <fact8>temperature is 101.8°F (38.8°C)</fact8>, <fact9>blood pressure is 88/65 mmHg</fact9>, <fact10>pulse is 132/min</fact10>, and <fact11>respirations are 16/min</fact11>. The patient has <fact12>purulent mucus draining from the nares</fact12>, and his face is <fact13>tender to palpation over the maxillary sinuses</fact13>. His pharynx is <fact14>erythematous with symmetric swelling of the tonsils</fact14>. On lung exam, he has <fact15>moderate bilateral expiratory wheezing</fact15>.

Which of the following is the best next step in management?

Answer: Analyzing the patient's presentation, the <fact1>5-year-old male</fact1> has a prolonged <fact2>history of cough</fact2> that has not responded to his <fact4>albuterol inhaler</fact4>, indicating that his symptoms are not solely due to his <fact3>mild intermittent asthma</fact3>. The presence of <fact12>purulent mucus draining from the nares</fact12>, <fact13>tenderness over the maxillary sinuses</fact13>, and <fact14>erythematous pharynx with symmetric swelling of the tonsils</fact14> suggests a bacterial infection, likely bacterial sinusitis or pharyngitis. Given his age and symptoms, the best next step in management would be to initiate antibiotic therapy. Considering the common pathogens responsible for these infections and the need for coverage against both Streptococcus pneumoniae and Haemophilus influenzae, the most appropriate choice is Amoxicillin-clavulanic acid, which provides broad-spectrum coverage. Therefore, the answer is {B}.

question:
A 38-year-old nursing home worker presents to the clinic with complaints of fever, loss of appetite, fatigue, and productive cough for the past couple of months. His fever is low-grade and sputum is often blood-tinged. He has lost 6.8 kg (15.0 lb) during this period and complains of profound night sweats. A plain radiograph of the patient’s chest shows consolidation in the apical part of the right lung. Baseline investigations show the following:
Complete blood count
Hemoglobin 11 g/dL
White blood cells  
Total count 16,000/mm3
Differential count  
Neutrophils 35%
Lymphocytes 54%
Eosinophils 11%
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate 84 mm
The physician suspects that the patient is suffering from a chronic lung infection. Which of the following statements best describes the type of lung inflammation in this patient?
A) There are small granulomas with few epithelioid cells along with fibrosis.
B) It has a granuloma with Anitchov cells around a core of fibrinoid collagen necrosis.
C) It consists of a largely circumscribed granuloma with epithelioid cells with Langhans cells.
D) An ill-defined granuloma with macrophages and epithelioid cells is seen in this type of inflammation.
E) This type of granulomatous inflammation is also seen in histoplasmosis.
answer:
Reformatted Question:

A <fact1>38-year-old nursing home worker</fact1> presents to the clinic with complaints of <fact2>fever, loss of appetite, fatigue, and productive cough</fact2> for the past couple of months. His <fact3>fever is low-grade</fact3> and <fact4>sputum is often blood-tinged</fact4>. He has <fact5>lost 6.8 kg (15.0 lb)</fact5> during this period and complains of <fact6>profound night sweats</fact6>. A <fact7>plain radiograph of the patient’s chest</fact7> shows <fact8>consolidation in the apical part of the right lung</fact8>. Baseline investigations show the following:
Complete blood count
<fact9>Hemoglobin 11 g/dL</fact9>
<fact10>White blood cells</fact10>  
<fact11>Total count 16,000/mm3</fact11>
<fact12>Differential count</fact12>  
<fact13>Neutrophils 35%</fact13>
<fact14>Lymphocytes 54%</fact14>
<fact15>Eosinophils 11%</fact15>
<fact16>Erythrocyte sedimentation rate 84 mm</fact16>
The physician suspects that the patient is suffering from a <fact17>chronic lung infection</fact17>. Which of the following statements best describes the type of lung inflammation in this patient?

Answer: Considering the patient's presentation, including <fact2>fever, loss of appetite, fatigue, and productive cough</fact2> for months, <fact3>low-grade fever</fact3>, <fact4>blood-tinged sputum</fact4>, significant <fact5>weight loss</fact5>, and <fact6>profound night sweats</fact6>, along with the radiographic finding of <fact8>consolidation in the apical part of the right lung</fact8>, these symptoms are highly suggestive of tuberculosis (TB), a chronic lung infection. The patient's laboratory results, including <fact9>anemia</fact9> (Hemoglobin 11 g/dL), <fact11>elevated white blood cell count</fact11>, and <fact16>high erythrocyte sedimentation rate</fact16>, also support this diagnosis. TB is characterized by the formation of granulomas, specifically caseating granulomas, which are a hallmark of the disease. Among the options provided, the description of a <fact17>largely circumscribed granuloma with epithelioid cells with Langhans cells</fact17> best fits the type of lung inflammation seen in TB. Therefore, the correct answer is {C}.

question:
A 27-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician for a general checkup. She has been doing well in school and has no complaints. The patient has a past medical history of asthma which is controlled with albuterol. She is currently sexually active but states that she uses birth control. She has many friends and states that her mood is typically positive. The patient's last pap smear was 1 year ago. Her father died of colon cancer at the age of 68, and her mother was diagnosed with breast cancer at the age of 65. Her temperature is 98.7°F (37.1°C), blood pressure is 147/108 mmHg, pulse is 80/min, respirations are 15/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The patient's BMI is 19 kg/m^2. Physical exam demonstrates a normal S1 and S2, normal breath sounds, and an abdominal exam that is within normal limits. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
A) Colonoscopy
B) Discontinue birth control and place an intrauterine device
C) Pap smear
D) Pregnancy test
E) Recommend weight loss
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>27-year-old woman</fact1> presents to her primary care physician for a general checkup. She has been doing well in school and has no complaints. The patient has a <fact2>past medical history of asthma</fact2> which is controlled with albuterol. She is currently <fact3>sexually active</fact3> but states that she uses <fact4>birth control</fact4>. She has many friends and states that her mood is typically positive. The patient's <fact5>last pap smear was 1 year ago</fact5>. Her father died of <fact6>colon cancer</fact6> at the age of 68, and her mother was diagnosed with <fact7>breast cancer</fact7> at the age of 65. Her temperature is 98.7°F (37.1°C), <fact8>blood pressure is 147/108 mmHg</fact8>, pulse is 80/min, respirations are 15/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The patient's <fact9>BMI is 19 kg/m^2</fact9>. Physical exam demonstrates a normal S1 and S2, normal breath sounds, and an abdominal exam that is within normal limits. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's <fact1>age</fact1> and <fact3>sexually active status</fact3>, along with her <fact5>last pap smear being 1 year ago</fact5>, it is essential to maintain regular cervical cancer screening. However, given her <fact8>high blood pressure</fact8>, it is crucial to address this issue promptly. Hypertension can lead to severe complications, and managing it takes precedence over other routine check-ups. Among the provided options, none directly address the patient's high blood pressure. However, considering the available choices, option B is the most relevant to her current situation, as it involves her <fact4>birth control</fact4> method, which could potentially be related to her hypertension. Therefore, the best answer is {B}.

question:
A 3-year-old male is brought in to his pediatrician by his mother because she is concerned that he is not growing appropriately. Physical examination is notable for frontal bossing and shortened upper and lower extremities. His axial skeleton appears normal. He is at the 7th percentile for height and 95th percentile for head circumference. He demonstrates normal intelligence and is able to speak in three-word sentences. He first sat up without support at twelve months and started walking at 24 months. Genetic analysis reveals an activating mutation in a growth factor receptor. Which of the following physiologic processes is most likely disrupted in this patient’s condition?
A) Intramembranous ossification
B) Osteoblast maturation
C) Endochondral ossification
D) Production of type I collagen
E) Bone resorption
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>3-year-old male</fact1> is brought in to his pediatrician by his mother because she is concerned that he is not growing appropriately. Physical examination is notable for <fact2>frontal bossing and shortened upper and lower extremities</fact2>. His <fact3>axial skeleton appears normal</fact3>. He is at the <fact4>7th percentile for height</fact4> and <fact5>95th percentile for head circumference</fact5>. He demonstrates <fact6>normal intelligence</fact6> and is able to speak in three-word sentences. He first sat up without support at <fact7>twelve months</fact7> and started walking at <fact8>24 months</fact8>. Genetic analysis reveals an <fact9>activating mutation in a growth factor receptor</fact9>. Which of the following physiologic processes is most likely disrupted in this patient’s condition?

Answer: 
Considering the <fact1>3-year-old male's</fact1> physical examination findings, including <fact2>frontal bossing and shortened upper and lower extremities</fact2>, with a normal <fact3>axial skeleton</fact3>, suggests a condition affecting the appendicular skeleton. His growth percentile, at the <fact4>7th percentile for height</fact4> but <fact5>95th percentile for head circumference</fact5>, indicates a disproportionate growth pattern. Additionally, his developmental milestones, such as sitting up without support at <fact7>twelve months</fact7> and walking at <fact8>24 months</fact8>, are within normal limits, which suggests that his condition primarily affects bone growth rather than overall development or intelligence (<fact6>normal intelligence</fact6>). The presence of an <fact9>activating mutation in a growth factor receptor</fact9> points towards a disorder of bone growth regulation. Among the options provided, the process most likely disrupted is endochondral ossification, which is the process by which the appendicular skeleton grows in length. This process is regulated by various growth factors and is consistent with the patient's presentation of shortened limbs and normal axial skeleton. Therefore, the answer is {C}.

question:
A 55-year-old construction worker is struck by a high-voltage power line while on duty. According to bystanders, the cable struck him on his right arm, after which the man slumped to the ground with his arms and legs shaking. In the emergency department, the man is alert but in severe pain localizing bilaterally in the flanks as well as in his right arm where contact with the power line occurred. A 6 cm burn is present on the right arm. His vitals are within normal limits except for mild tachypnea at 21/min. Which of the following diagnostic tests should be conducted first to evaluate this patient?
A) FAST ultrasound assessment
B) Urine dipstick
C) Urinalysis
D) X-ray of the arm and shoulder
E) EEG
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>55-year-old construction worker</fact1> is struck by a <fact2>high-voltage power line</fact2> while on duty. According to bystanders, the cable struck him on his <fact3>right arm</fact3>, after which the man slumped to the ground with his <fact4>arms and legs shaking</fact4>. In the emergency department, the man is alert but in <fact5>severe pain localizing bilaterally in the flanks</fact5> as well as in his <fact6>right arm where contact with the power line occurred</fact6>. A <fact7>6 cm burn is present on the right arm</fact7>. His vitals are within normal limits except for <fact8>mild tachypnea at 21/min</fact8>. Which of the following diagnostic tests should be conducted first to evaluate this patient?
A) FAST ultrasound assessment
B) Urine dipstick
C) Urinalysis
D) X-ray of the arm and shoulder
E) EEG

Answer: 
Considering the patient's presentation, particularly the <fact5>severe pain localizing bilaterally in the flanks</fact5> and the presence of a <fact7>6 cm burn on the right arm</fact7> from the <fact2>high-voltage power line</fact2>, there is a high risk of internal injuries, including potential renal damage due to the electrical shock. Given these factors, the most appropriate first diagnostic test to evaluate for potential internal injuries, specifically renal damage, would be a <fact8>urine dipstick</fact8> to check for blood or other signs of urinary tract injury. Therefore, the answer is {B}.

question:
A 42-year-old man comes to the physician because of progressive fatigue and shortness of breath for 1 month. He has been unable to practice with his recreational soccer team and has had to rest frequently when walking to work. His only medication is ibuprofen for joint pain. Physical examination shows tanned skin. There is tenderness to palpation and stiffness of the metacarpophalangeal joints of both hands. Pulmonary examination shows coarse crackles in both lung fields. The liver is palpated 4 cm below the right costal margin. Human leukocyte antigen (HLA) testing is most likely to be positive for which of the following?
A) HLA-B27
B) HLA-DR3
C) HLA-DR4
D) HLA-B8
E) HLA-A3
answer:
Reformatted Question:
