A <fact1>42-year-old man</fact1> comes to the physician because of <fact2>progressive fatigue and shortness of breath for 1 month</fact2>. He has been unable to practice with his recreational soccer team and has had to rest frequently when walking to work. His only medication is <fact3>ibuprofen for joint pain</fact3>. Physical examination shows <fact4>tanned skin</fact4>. There is <fact5>tenderness to palpation and stiffness of the metacarpophalangeal joints of both hands</fact5>. Pulmonary examination shows <fact6>coarse crackles in both lung fields</fact6>. The liver is palpated <fact7>4 cm below the right costal margin</fact7>. Human leukocyte antigen (HLA) testing is most likely to be positive for which of the following?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's symptoms, including <fact2>progressive fatigue and shortness of breath</fact2>, <fact3>joint pain</fact3>, and <fact4>tanned skin</fact4>, along with the physical findings of <fact5>joint stiffness</fact5>, <fact6>coarse crackles in both lung fields</fact6>, and an enlarged liver (<fact7>4 cm below the right costal margin</fact7>), the patient's presentation is suggestive of hemochromatosis, a genetic disorder characterized by excessive iron absorption leading to multi-organ damage. Hemochromatosis is associated with HLA-A3. Therefore, the answer is {E}.

question:
A 30-year-old African American woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of a dry cough and chest discomfort for the past 3 days. During this period, the patient has had headaches, muscle aches, joint pain, fever, and chills. Ten days ago, she was hiking with her family in Mississippi. The patient has asthma that is treated with an albuterol inhaler. Her mother has a lung disease treated with methotrexate. The patient has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 10 years. Her temperature is 38°C (100.4°F). Physical examination shows slight wheezes throughout both lung fields. Laboratory studies and urinalysis are positive for polysaccharide antigen. Bronchoalveolar lavage using silver/PAS-staining shows macrophages filled with a dimorphic fungus with septate hyphae. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
A) Legionella pneumophila infection
B) Aspergillus fumigatus infection
C) Pneumocystis pneumonia
D) Histoplasma capsulatum infection
E) Blastomyces dermatitidis infection
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>30-year-old African American woman</fact1> comes to the physician for the evaluation of a <fact2>dry cough and chest discomfort</fact2> for the past <fact3>3 days</fact3>. During this period, the patient has had <fact4>headaches, muscle aches, joint pain, fever, and chills</fact4>. <fact5>Ten days ago, she was hiking with her family in Mississippi</fact5>. The patient has <fact6>asthma that is treated with an albuterol inhaler</fact6>. Her mother has a <fact7>lung disease treated with methotrexate</fact7>. The patient has <fact8>smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 10 years</fact8>. Her <fact9>temperature is 38°C (100.4°F)</fact9>. Physical examination shows <fact10>slight wheezes throughout both lung fields</fact10>. Laboratory studies and urinalysis are <fact11>positive for polysaccharide antigen</fact11>. Bronchoalveolar lavage using silver/PAS-staining shows <fact12>macrophages filled with a dimorphic fungus with septate hyphae</fact12>. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's presentation with <fact2>dry cough and chest discomfort</fact2>, <fact4>headaches, muscle aches, joint pain, fever, and chills</fact4>, and a history of <fact5>hiking in Mississippi</fact5>, along with laboratory findings of <fact11>polysaccharide antigen positivity</fact11> and <fact12>macrophages filled with a dimorphic fungus with septate hyphae</fact12> on bronchoalveolar lavage, the most likely cause of her symptoms is a fungal infection. Given the patient's exposure history and the specific laboratory findings, the most likely cause is <fact12>dimorphic fungus</fact12> consistent with Histoplasma capsulatum, which is commonly found in soil contaminated with bird droppings and is prevalent in the Mississippi region. Therefore, the answer is {D}.

question:
Two weeks after starting chemotherapy with etoposide, a 66-year-old man with small cell lung cancer comes to the physician because of persistent nausea and vomiting. His symptoms improve significantly after the administration of metoclopramide. This patient's symptoms were most likely due to the effect of chemotherapy on which of the following structures?
A) Vestibular nerve
B) Intestinal smooth muscle
C) Vagus nerve
D) Cerebral cortex
E) Area postrema
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>66-year-old man</fact1> with <fact2>small cell lung cancer</fact2> comes to the physician because of <fact3>persistent nausea and vomiting</fact3> two weeks after starting chemotherapy with <fact4>etoposide</fact4>. His symptoms improve significantly after the administration of <fact5>metoclopramide</fact5>. This patient's symptoms were most likely due to the effect of chemotherapy on which of the following structures?

Answer: Evaluating the patient's presentation, the <fact1>66-year-old man</fact1> with <fact2>small cell lung cancer</fact2> is experiencing <fact3>persistent nausea and vomiting</fact3> after starting chemotherapy with <fact4>etoposide</fact4>. The improvement of symptoms after the administration of <fact5>metoclopramide</fact5>, a dopamine antagonist with antiemetic properties, suggests that the chemotherapy affected a structure involved in nausea and vomiting that is responsive to dopamine antagonism. The area postrema is a part of the brain that is involved in the vomiting reflex and is sensitive to various chemicals, including those used in chemotherapy. This area is not protected by the blood-brain barrier, making it susceptible to the effects of chemotherapy agents like etoposide. Therefore, the structure most likely affected by chemotherapy in this case is the area postrema. The answer is {E}.

question:
A 57-year-old homeless man is brought to the emergency department because of several episodes of hematemesis in the past 24 hours. His vital signs include a temperature of 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse of 95/min, and blood pressure of 85/60 mm Hg. On physical examination, he appears confused and unable to give a complete history. He is noted to have jaundice, palpable firm liver, mild splenomegaly, and shifting dullness consistent with the presence of ascites. Liver function tests are as follows:
Serum aspartate aminotransferase (AST)  97 U/L
Serum alanine aminotransferase (ALT) 40 U/L
Serum albumin 2.5 g/dL
Total bilirubin 3 mg/dL
Prothrombin time 20 seconds
Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's illness?
A) Metabolic disorder
B) Autoimmune liver disease
C) Substance abuse
D) Obesity
E)  Hepatic venous outflow obstruction
answer:
Reformatted Question: 

A <fact1>57-year-old homeless man</fact1> is brought to the emergency department because of several episodes of <fact2>hematemesis in the past 24 hours</fact2>. His vital signs include a <fact3>temperature of 37.1°C (98.8°F)</fact3>, <fact4>pulse of 95/min</fact4>, and <fact5>blood pressure of 85/60 mm Hg</fact5>. On physical examination, he appears <fact6>confused and unable to give a complete history</fact6>. He is noted to have <fact7>jaundice</fact7>, <fact8>palpable firm liver</fact8>, <fact9>mild splenomegaly</fact9>, and <fact10>shifting dullness consistent with the presence of ascites</fact10>. Liver function tests are as follows:
<fact11>Serum aspartate aminotransferase (AST)  97 U/L</fact11>
<fact12>Serum alanine aminotransferase (ALT) 40 U/L</fact12>
<fact13>Serum albumin 2.5 g/dL</fact13>
<fact14>Total bilirubin 3 mg/dL</fact14>
<fact15>Prothrombin time 20 seconds</fact15>
Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's illness?

A) Metabolic disorder
B) Autoimmune liver disease
C) Substance abuse
D) Obesity
E)  Hepatic venous outflow obstruction

Answer: 

Considering the patient's presentation, the most relevant information includes the episodes of <fact2>hematemesis</fact2>, <fact7>jaundice</fact7>, <fact8>palpable firm liver</fact8>, <fact9>mild splenomegaly</fact9>, and <fact10>shifting dullness consistent with the presence of ascites</fact10>, along with abnormal liver function tests such as <fact11>AST</fact11>, <fact12>ALT</fact12>, <fact13>low serum albumin</fact13>, <fact14>total bilirubin</fact14>, and a prolonged <fact15>prothrombin time</fact15>. These findings are indicative of liver dysfunction and cirrhosis. Given the patient's status as a <fact1>57-year-old homeless man</fact1>, it is reasonable to suspect that <fact6>confusion and inability to give a complete history</fact6> might be related to alcohol consumption. The combination of these factors points towards liver disease secondary to <fact16>substance abuse</fact16>, which is a common cause of cirrhosis and liver dysfunction. Therefore, the answer is {C}.

question:
A 45-year-old man presents to the doctor’s office with shortness of breath, cough, and fatigue for 3 days. This has been progressively worsening. He has a medical history significant for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and osteoarthritis. He takes albuterol, ipratropium and aspirin. He smoked 2 and a half packs per day, and had done so for the past 26 years. After ceasing tobacco use for 1 year, he has recently begun smoking again. The blood pressure is 138/88 mm Hg, the respiratory rate is 12/min, the heart rate is 76/min, and the pulse oximetry is 87% on room air. On physical examination, the patient appears disoriented and is only somewhat comprehensible. The pupils are equal, round, and reactive to light with extraocular movements intact. Cranial nerves VII-XII also intact. The auscultation of the heart is absent of murmur, rubs, or gallops. The auscultation of the lungs demonstrate audible rales in the bases bilaterally. Which of the stages of change is the patient currently experiencing based on the clinical vignette?
A) Precontemplation
B) Contemplation
C) Preparation
D) Maintenance
E) Relapse
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>45-year-old man</fact1> presents to the doctor’s office with <fact2>shortness of breath, cough, and fatigue for 3 days</fact2>. This has been progressively worsening. He has a medical history significant for <fact3>chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and osteoarthritis</fact3>. He takes <fact4>albuterol, ipratropium and aspirin</fact4>. He <fact5>smoked 2 and a half packs per day, and had done so for the past 26 years</fact5>. After <fact6>ceasing tobacco use for 1 year</fact6>, he has recently begun <fact7>smoking again</fact7>. The <fact8>blood pressure is 138/88 mm Hg, the respiratory rate is 12/min, the heart rate is 76/min, and the pulse oximetry is 87% on room air</fact8>. On physical examination, the patient appears <fact9>disoriented and is only somewhat comprehensible</fact9>. The <fact10>pupils are equal, round, and reactive to light with extraocular movements intact</fact10>. <fact11>Cranial nerves VII-XII also intact</fact11>. The <fact12>auscultation of the heart is absent of murmur, rubs, or gallops</fact12>. The <fact13>auscultation of the lungs demonstrate audible rales in the bases bilaterally</fact13>. Which of the stages of change is the patient currently experiencing based on the clinical vignette?

Answer: E) Relapse

Explanation: The patient's history of <fact5>smoking 2 and a half packs per day for the past 26 years</fact5> and subsequent <fact6>ceasing tobacco use for 1 year</fact6> indicates that he had previously made an attempt to change his behavior. However, the fact that he has recently begun <fact7>smoking again</fact7> suggests that he has returned to his previous behavior, which is characteristic of the relapse stage.

question:
A 79-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of a 2-month history of a non-productive cough and fatigue. During this period, she also has had a 4.5-kg (10-lb) weight loss and has become increasingly short of breath with mild exertion. She has congestive heart failure and hypertension. Three months ago, she was in India for 3 weeks to attend a family wedding. She worked as a seamstress in a textile factory for 50 years. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 47 years. Her current medications include enalapril, digoxin, isosorbide, spironolactone, and metoprolol. She appears thin. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 94%. There is dullness to percussion and decreased breath sounds over the right lung base. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show a glucose level of 90 mg/dL, serum lactate dehydrogenase of 227 U/L, and serum protein of 6.3 g/dL. An x-ray of the chest shows nodular pleural lesions on the right side and a moderate-sized pleural effusion. Thoracentesis shows 250 ml of turbid fluid. Analysis of the pleural fluid aspirate shows:
Erythrocyte count 1/mm3
Leukocyte count 4,000/mm3
Glucose 59 mg/dl
Lactate dehydrogenase 248 U/L
Protein 3.8 g/dL
Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's effusion?"
A) Bronchial adenocarcinoma
B) Mesothelioma
C) Nephrotic syndrome
D) Tuberculosis
E) Congestive heart failure
answer:
Reformatted Question: 

A <fact1>79-year-old woman</fact1> comes to the physician for the evaluation of a <fact2>2-month history of a non-productive cough and fatigue</fact2>. During this period, she also has had a <fact3>4.5-kg (10-lb) weight loss</fact3> and has become increasingly <fact4>short of breath with mild exertion</fact4>. She has <fact5>congestive heart failure</fact5> and <fact6>hypertension</fact6>. Three months ago, she was in <fact7>India</fact7> for 3 weeks to attend a family wedding. She worked as a <fact8>seamstress in a textile factory</fact8> for 50 years. She has <fact9>smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 47 years</fact9>. Her current medications include <fact10>enalapril, digoxin, isosorbide, spironolactone, and metoprolol</fact10>. She appears thin. Her temperature is <fact11>37.0°C (98.6°F)</fact11>, pulse is <fact12>90/min</fact12>, respirations are <fact13>25/min</fact13>, and blood pressure is <fact14>110/70 mm Hg</fact14>. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of <fact15>94%</fact15>. There is <fact16>dullness to percussion and decreased breath sounds over the right lung base</fact16>. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show a glucose level of <fact17>90 mg/dL</fact17>, serum lactate dehydrogenase of <fact18>227 U/L</fact18>, and serum protein of <fact19>6.3 g/dL</fact19>. An x-ray of the chest shows <fact20>nodular pleural lesions on the right side and a moderate-sized pleural effusion</fact20>. Thoracentesis shows 250 ml of turbid fluid. Analysis of the pleural fluid aspirate shows:
Erythrocyte count <fact21>1/mm3</fact21>
Leukocyte count <fact22>4,000/mm3</fact22>
Glucose <fact23>59 mg/dl</fact23>
Lactate dehydrogenase <fact24>248 U/L</fact24>
Protein <fact25>3.8 g/dL</fact25>
Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's effusion?

Answer: 

Considering the patient's <fact2>2-month history of a non-productive cough and fatigue</fact2>, <fact3>4.5-kg (10-lb) weight loss</fact3>, and <fact4>shortness of breath with mild exertion</fact4>, along with her history of <fact9>smoking one pack of cigarettes daily for 47 years</fact9> and working as a <fact8>seamstress in a textile factory</fact8> for 50 years, the most likely underlying cause of her effusion is related to her occupational exposure and smoking history. The presence of <fact20>nodular pleural lesions on the right side and a moderate-sized pleural effusion</fact20> on the chest x-ray, along with the analysis of the pleural fluid aspirate showing a high lactate dehydrogenase level (<fact24>248 U/L</fact24>) and a high protein level (<fact25>3.8 g/dL</fact25>), suggests a diagnosis of mesothelioma. Mesothelioma is a type of cancer that is strongly associated with asbestos exposure, which is likely given her occupation as a seamstress in a textile factory. Therefore, the answer is {B}.

question:
A 21-year-old woman presents with sudden onset of high blood pressure. She is concerned about her health especially after her colleagues noticed that her face gets red at times while at work. She has even started to use blankets to cover her feet, even on the warmest days in the summer, even though her hands feel warm to the touch. She is a student who exercises and eats a well-balanced diet every day. There is no family history of hypertension or other metabolic syndromes. On examination, her blood pressure is 145/92 mm Hg, respirations are 19/min, pulse is 64/min, and temperature is 36.7°C (98.0°F). An echocardiogram is ordered for investigation. This patient is likely affected by a condition which is associated with which of the following options?
A) Fibromuscular dysplasia
B) Marfan syndrome
C) Turner syndrome
D) Pheochromocytoma
E) Takayasu's arteritis
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>21-year-old woman</fact1> presents with <fact2>sudden onset of high blood pressure</fact2>. She is concerned about her health especially after her colleagues noticed that her <fact3>face gets red at times</fact3> while at work. She has even started to use blankets to cover her feet, even on the <fact4>warmest days in the summer</fact4>, even though her hands feel warm to the touch. She is a student who <fact5>exercises and eats a well-balanced diet every day</fact5>. There is <fact6>no family history of hypertension or other metabolic syndromes</fact6>. On examination, her <fact7>blood pressure is 145/92 mm Hg</fact7>, <fact8>respirations are 19/min</fact8>, <fact9>pulse is 64/min</fact9>, and <fact10>temperature is 36.7°C (98.0°F)</fact10>. An <fact11>echocardiogram is ordered for investigation</fact11>. This patient is likely affected by a condition which is associated with which of the following options?

Answer: Considering the patient's <fact2>sudden onset of high blood pressure</fact2> and the fact that her <fact3>face gets red at times</fact3> while at work, along with the observation that she feels cold despite warm temperatures (<fact4>warmest days in the summer</fact4>), suggests a condition that affects blood pressure regulation and possibly catecholamine release. The absence of <fact6>family history of hypertension or other metabolic syndromes</fact6> and the fact that she <fact5>exercises and eats a well-balanced diet every day</fact5> makes a genetic or lifestyle-related cause less likely. Among the options provided, <fact12>pheochromocytoma</fact12> is a condition that fits these symptoms, as it is a catecholamine-secreting tumor that can cause episodic hypertension, sweating, tachycardia, and palpitations, which could explain the patient's symptoms, including the facial flushing and cold intolerance. Therefore, the answer is {D}.

question:
An investigator is studying the cell morphologies of the respiratory tract. He obtains a biopsy from the mainstem bronchus of a patient. On microscopic examination, the biopsy sample shows uniform squamous cells in layers. Which of the following best describes the histologic finding seen in this patient?
A) Metaplasia
B) Normal epithelium
C) Dysplasia
D) Hyperplasia
E) Anaplasia
"
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
An investigator is studying the cell morphologies of the <fact1>respiratory tract</fact1>. He obtains a biopsy from the <fact2>mainstem bronchus</fact2> of a patient. On microscopic examination, the biopsy sample shows <fact3>uniform squamous cells in layers</fact3>. Which of the following best describes the histologic finding seen in this patient?
A) Metaplasia
B) Normal epithelium
C) Dysplasia
D) Hyperplasia
E) Anaplasia

Answer: The histologic finding of <fact3>uniform squamous cells in layers</fact3> in a biopsy from the <fact2>mainstem bronchus</fact2> of the <fact1>respiratory tract</fact1> is most consistent with metaplasia. Normally, the mainstem bronchus is lined with ciliated pseudostratified columnar epithelium, but the presence of squamous cells in layers indicates a change from the normal epithelial type to a squamous type, which is characteristic of metaplasia. Therefore, the correct answer is {A}.

question:
A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because she feels depressed, has difficulty sleeping, a poor appetite, and low concentration for the past 3 months. During this time, she has also had low energy and lost interest in playing the guitar. During high school, the patient went through similar episodes of low mood and poor sleep. At that time, she would repeatedly engage in binge eating and purging behavior, for which she was referred to therapy. There is no evidence of suicidal ideation. The physician offers to prescribe a medication for her current symptoms. Treatment with which of the following drugs should most be avoided in this patient?
A) Duloxetine
B) Trazodone
C) Bupropion
D) Mirtazapine
E) Citalopram
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>32-year-old woman</fact1> comes to the physician because she feels <fact2>depressed</fact2>, has <fact3>difficulty sleeping</fact3>, a <fact4>poor appetite</fact4>, and <fact5>low concentration</fact5> for the past <fact6>3 months</fact6>. During this time, she has also had <fact7>low energy</fact7> and lost interest in playing the guitar. During high school, the patient went through similar episodes of <fact8>low mood and poor sleep</fact8>. At that time, she would repeatedly engage in <fact9>binge eating and purging behavior</fact9>, for which she was referred to therapy. There is no evidence of <fact10>suicidal ideation</fact10>. The physician offers to prescribe a medication for her current symptoms. Treatment with which of the following drugs should most be avoided in this patient?
A) Duloxetine
B) Trazodone
C) Bupropion
D) Mirtazapine
E) Citalopram

Answer: 
Considering the patient's history of <fact9>binge eating and purging behavior</fact9>, which is indicative of bulimia nervosa, it is essential to avoid medications that may lower the seizure threshold, as individuals with bulimia are at higher risk for seizures. Among the options, Bupropion is known to have a higher risk of inducing seizures, especially in patients with a history of eating disorders. Therefore, the correct answer is {C}.

question:
A 6-day-old male newborn is brought to the physician because he has become increasingly irritable and restless over the past 2 days. During this period, he has had 12 bowel movements. He feeds 10 to 12 times a day. He was born at 38 weeks' gestation and weighed 1800 g (3 lb 15 oz); he currently weighs 1700 g (3 lb 12 oz). His mother has Graves' disease and received propylthiouracil during the last trimester of pregnancy. She has a history of intravenous heroin use. His temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 180/min, and respirations are 50/min. Examination shows mild diaphoresis and a firm 2-cm midline neck swelling. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
A) Methimazole and propranolol therapy
B) Digoxin and furesomide therapy
C) Potassium iodide therapy
D) Naloxone therapy
E) Calcium gluconate therapy
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>6-day-old male newborn</fact1> is brought to the physician because he has become increasingly <fact2>irritable and restless</fact2> over the past <fact3>2 days</fact3>. During this period, he has had <fact4>12 bowel movements</fact4>. He feeds <fact5>10 to 12 times a day</fact5>. He was born at <fact6>38 weeks' gestation</fact6> and weighed <fact7>1800 g (3 lb 15 oz)</fact7>; he currently weighs <fact8>1700 g (3 lb 12 oz)</fact8>. His mother has <fact9>Graves' disease</fact9> and received <fact10>propylthiouracil</fact10> during the last trimester of pregnancy. She has a history of <fact11>intravenous heroin use</fact11>. His temperature is <fact12>36.9°C (98.4°F)</fact12>, pulse is <fact13>180/min</fact13>, and respirations are <fact14>50/min</fact14>. Examination shows <fact15>mild diaphoresis</fact15> and a <fact16>firm 2-cm midline neck swelling</fact16>. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

Answer: Considering the newborn's symptoms of <fact2>irritability and restlessness</fact2>, <fact4>increased bowel movements</fact4>, and <fact5>increased feeding frequency</fact5>, along with the physical examination findings of <fact15>mild diaphoresis</fact15> and a <fact16>firm 2-cm midline neck swelling</fact16>, suggests a diagnosis of neonatal hyperthyroidism. This is further supported by the mother's history of <fact9>Graves' disease</fact9> and treatment with <fact10>propylthiouracil</fact10> during pregnancy. The appropriate management for neonatal hyperthyroidism includes therapy to reduce thyroid hormone production and control symptoms. Therefore, the most appropriate next step in management is to initiate therapy with methimazole (to reduce thyroid hormone production) and propranolol (to control symptoms such as tachycardia). The answer is {A}.

question:
A 56-year-old man is brought to the emergency department. He was found unconscious on the street. The staff recognizes him as a local homeless man with a long history of alcoholism. At the hospital, his pulse is 95/min, the blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg, the respirations are 20/min, and the oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On physical exam, the unconscious man is covered in bloody vomit with small clots and food particles. He smells of alcohol. A digital exam reveals black tarry stool in the rectal vault. The patient is given oxygen, IV fluids, and an NG-tube is placed and set to intermittent suction. Labs are sent and the patient is prepared for a procedure. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in his management?
A) Undergo colonoscopy
B) Undergo upper GI endoscopy
C) Selective mesenteric angiography
D) Proton pump inhibitors with anti-H.pylori regimen
E) Surgery for peptic ulcer disease
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>56-year-old man</fact1> is brought to the emergency department. He was found <fact2>unconscious on the street</fact2>. The staff recognizes him as a local homeless man with a <fact3>long history of alcoholism</fact3>. At the hospital, his <fact4>pulse is 95/min</fact4>, the <fact5>blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg</fact5>, the <fact6>respirations are 20/min</fact6>, and the <fact7>oxygen saturation is 98% on room air</fact7>. On physical exam, the <fact8>unconscious man is covered in bloody vomit with small clots and food particles</fact8>. He <fact9>smells of alcohol</fact9>. A digital exam reveals <fact10>black tarry stool in the rectal vault</fact10>. The patient is given <fact11>oxygen, IV fluids, and an NG-tube is placed and set to intermittent suction</fact11>. Labs are sent and the patient is prepared for a procedure. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in his management?

Answer: Considering the patient's presentation, including being found <fact2>unconscious on the street</fact2> with a <fact3>long history of alcoholism</fact3>, the presence of <fact8>bloody vomit with small clots and food particles</fact8>, and <fact10>black tarry stool in the rectal vault</fact10>, these signs are highly suggestive of upper gastrointestinal bleeding. Given the patient's condition and the need for immediate intervention to stop the bleeding, the most appropriate next step in his management would be to undergo an <fact12>upper GI endoscopy</fact12> to identify and potentially treat the source of the bleeding. Therefore, the answer is {B}.

question:
A 2,300 g (5 lb) male newborn is delivered to a 29-year-old primigravid woman. The mother has HIV and received triple antiretroviral therapy during pregnancy. Her HIV viral load was 678 copies/mL 1 week prior to delivery. Labor was uncomplicated. Apgar scores were 7 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes respectively. Physical examination of the newborn shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this infant?
A) Administer zidovudine
B) HIV antibody testing
C) HIV DNA testing
D) HIV RNA testing
E) Reassurance and follow-up
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>2,300 g (5 lb) male newborn</fact1> is delivered to a <fact2>29-year-old primigravid woman</fact2>. The mother has <fact3>HIV</fact3> and received <fact4>triple antiretroviral therapy during pregnancy</fact4>. Her <fact5>HIV viral load was 678 copies/mL 1 week prior to delivery</fact5>. Labor was uncomplicated. <fact6>Apgar scores were 7 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes respectively</fact6>. Physical examination of the newborn shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this infant?
A) Administer zidovudine
B) HIV antibody testing
C) HIV DNA testing
D) HIV RNA testing
E) Reassurance and follow-up

Answer: 
Considering the <fact2>29-year-old primigravid woman</fact2> has <fact3>HIV</fact3> and received <fact4>triple antiretroviral therapy during pregnancy</fact4>, it is crucial to assess the risk of mother-to-child transmission of HIV to the <fact1>newborn</fact1>. Given the <fact5>HIV viral load was 678 copies/mL 1 week prior to delivery</fact5>, there is still a risk of transmission. The <fact6>Apgar scores were 7 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes respectively</fact6>, indicating the newborn is not in immediate distress, but further evaluation is necessary. Administering zidovudine to the newborn is a standard prophylactic measure to reduce the risk of HIV transmission. Therefore, the most appropriate next step in the management of this infant is {A}.

question:
A 65-year old man presents with gradually worsening rigidity of his arms and legs and slowness in performing tasks. He says he has also noticed hand tremors, which increase at rest and decrease with focused movements. On examination, the patient does not swing his arms while walking and has a shortened, shuffling gait. An antiviral drug is prescribed which alleviates the patient’s symptoms. Which of the following drugs was most likely prescribed to this patient?
A) Amantadine
B) Ribavirin
C) Acyclovir
D) Levodopa
E) Zidovudine
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>65-year-old man</fact1> presents with <fact2>gradually worsening rigidity of his arms and legs</fact2> and <fact3>slowness in performing tasks</fact3>. He says he has also noticed <fact4>hand tremors, which increase at rest and decrease with focused movements</fact4>. On examination, the patient does not <fact5>swing his arms while walking</fact5> and has a <fact6>shortened, shuffling gait</fact6>. An <fact7>antiviral drug</fact7> is prescribed which alleviates the patient’s symptoms. Which of the following drugs was most likely prescribed to this patient?
A) Amantadine
B) Ribavirin
C) Acyclovir
D) Levodopa
E) Zidovudine

Answer: 
Considering the patient's symptoms of <fact2>gradually worsening rigidity of his arms and legs</fact2>, <fact3>slowness in performing tasks</fact3>, <fact4>hand tremors that increase at rest and decrease with focused movements</fact4>, and a <fact6>shortened, shuffling gait</fact6>, along with the absence of arm swing while walking (<fact5>does not swing his arms while walking</fact5>), the patient is likely suffering from Parkinson's disease. Although the question refers to an <fact7>antiviral drug</fact7>, the most appropriate treatment for Parkinson's disease that matches the description is actually an antiviral drug with dopaminergic properties. Among the options provided, Amantadine is an antiviral drug that has been used in the treatment of Parkinson's disease, especially in the early stages or as an adjunct to other medications. Therefore, the most likely prescribed drug is {A}.

question:
A 19-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of severe right shoulder pain and inability to move the shoulder after a fall while climbing outdoors. Examination shows the right upper extremity is externally rotated and slightly abducted. There is loss of the the normal rounded appearance of the shoulder. The right humeral head is palpated below the coracoid process. Sensation to pinprick over which of the following skin areas is most likely to be reduced?
A) Medial aspect of the upper arm
B) Lateral aspect of the shoulder
C) Skin above the clavicle
D) Lateral aspect of forearm
E) Dorsal aspect of forearm and hand
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>19-year-old man</fact1> is brought to the emergency department because of <fact2>severe right shoulder pain</fact2> and <fact3>inability to move the shoulder</fact3> after a <fact4>fall while climbing outdoors</fact4>. Examination shows the <fact5>right upper extremity is externally rotated and slightly abducted</fact5>. There is <fact6>loss of the normal rounded appearance of the shoulder</fact6>. The <fact7>right humeral head is palpated below the coracoid process</fact7>. Sensation to pinprick over which of the following skin areas is most likely to be reduced?

Answer: Based on the patient's presentation, specifically the <fact5>externally rotated and slightly abducted right upper extremity</fact5> and the <fact7>palpation of the right humeral head below the coracoid process</fact7>, it suggests a shoulder dislocation, likely an anterior dislocation given the position of the humeral head. The axillary nerve, which provides sensation to the <fact8>lateral aspect of the shoulder</fact8> (also known as the regimental badge area), is at risk of injury in anterior shoulder dislocations due to its proximity to the shoulder joint. Therefore, sensation to pinprick over the <fact8>lateral aspect of the shoulder</fact8> is most likely to be reduced. The correct answer is {B}.

question:
A 23-year-old man comes to the clinic for yellowing of his eyes. The patient has been relatively healthy and just recently started “intermittent fasting” to try to lose weight. He recalls a similar episode 4 years ago when he was recovering from an emergency appendectomy. The patient denies smoking but endorses an episode of binge drinking 2 days ago. He is sexually active with both men and women. His physical examination is unremarkable besides scleral icterus. What is the most likely explanation for this patient’s symptoms?
A) Autoimmune-mediated fibrosis of biliary tract
B) Chronic viral infection of the liver
C) Decreased activity of UDP-glucuronosyltransferase
D) Defective bilirubin excretion
E) Macrovesicular steatosis
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>23-year-old man</fact1> comes to the clinic for <fact2>yellowing of his eyes</fact2>. The patient has been relatively healthy and just recently started <fact3>“intermittent fasting”</fact3> to try to lose weight. He recalls a <fact4>similar episode 4 years ago</fact4> when he was recovering from an emergency appendectomy. The patient denies smoking but endorses an <fact5>episode of binge drinking 2 days ago</fact5>. He is sexually active with both men and women. His physical examination is unremarkable besides <fact6>scleral icterus</fact6>. What is the most likely explanation for this patient’s symptoms?

Answer: 
Considering the <fact1>23-year-old man's</fact1> presentation with <fact2>yellowing of his eyes</fact2> and <fact6>scleral icterus</fact6>, which are indicative of jaundice, along with a history of a <fact4>similar episode 4 years ago</fact4> and recent <fact5>episode of binge drinking 2 days ago</fact5>, it is essential to evaluate for potential liver or bilirubin metabolism issues. The fact that he recently started <fact3>“intermittent fasting”</fact3> may also be relevant. Among the options provided, decreased activity of UDP-glucuronosyltransferase is associated with Gilbert's syndrome, a benign condition that affects bilirubin metabolism and can be exacerbated by fasting or stress, leading to episodes of jaundice. Therefore, the most likely explanation for this patient's symptoms is {C}.

question:
A 7-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother with increasing swelling of his right jaw for the past 2 months. She notes that he has been treated several times with different antibiotics, but that they have not helped. She reports no recent history of fever, chills, or night sweats. The boy has no significant medical history. He emigrated to the United States with his family from Nigeria 1 month ago. He is in the 85th percentile for height and weight, and he has been meeting all developmental milestones. His temperature is 37.8℃ (100.0℉). On physical examination, the patient has a prominent 8 × 8 cm mass over the right mandible. The mass has partially distorted the borders of the mandible and cheek. The overlying skin is erythematous. The mass is firm, immobile, and tender. The contralateral side of the face shows no abnormalities. An oral examination shows the disruption of the ipsilateral lower teeth and oral mucosa. The remainder of the physical exam is unremarkable. A biopsy of the mass is performed and a histopathologic analysis is seen in the image. Which of the following microorganisms is most likely associated with this patient’s condition?
A) Babesia microti
B) Bartonella henselae
C) Cytomegalovirus (CMV)
D) Epstein barr virus (EBV)
E) Yersinia pestis
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>7-year-old boy</fact1> is brought to the clinic by his mother with <fact2>increasing swelling of his right jaw for the past 2 months</fact2>. She notes that he has been treated several times with different <fact3>antibiotics</fact3>, but that they have not helped. She reports no recent history of <fact4>fever, chills, or night sweats</fact4>. The boy has no significant <fact5>medical history</fact5>. He <fact6>emigrated to the United States with his family from Nigeria 1 month ago</fact6>. He is in the <fact7>85th percentile for height and weight</fact7>, and he has been meeting all <fact8>developmental milestones</fact8>. His <fact9>temperature is 37.8℃ (100.0℉)</fact9>. On physical examination, the patient has a <fact10>prominent 8 × 8 cm mass over the right mandible</fact10>. The mass has partially distorted the borders of the mandible and cheek. The overlying skin is <fact11>erythematous</fact11>. The mass is <fact12>firm, immobile, and tender</fact12>. The contralateral side of the face shows no abnormalities. An oral examination shows the <fact13>disruption of the ipsilateral lower teeth and oral mucosa</fact13>. The remainder of the physical exam is unremarkable. A <fact14>biopsy of the mass</fact14> is performed and a <fact15>histopathologic analysis</fact15> is seen in the image. Which of the following microorganisms is most likely associated with this patient’s condition?

Answer: 
Considering the patient's presentation, particularly the <fact10>prominent 8 × 8 cm mass over the right mandible</fact10> that is <fact12>firm, immobile, and tender</fact12>, along with the <fact11>erythematous</fact11> overlying skin and <fact13>disruption of the ipsilateral lower teeth and oral mucosa</fact13>, suggests a severe and chronic infection that has not responded to <fact3>antibiotic treatments</fact3>. Given the patient's recent <fact6>emigration from Nigeria</fact6> and the lack of systemic symptoms such as <fact4>fever, chills, or night sweats</fact4>, along with the findings from the <fact14>biopsy</fact14> and <fact15>histopathologic analysis</fact15>, the most likely microorganism associated with this patient's condition is not explicitly listed among the provided options. However, the description points towards a condition that could be related to a chronic and severe infection such as Burkitt lymphoma, which is more common in equatorial Africa and can present with a jaw mass. Among the options given, none directly match the likely cause based on the provided information, but if we consider the context and the need to choose the closest match, we might lean towards viral causes that could lead to such a presentation in the context of immune system dysregulation or malignancy. Therefore, a possible answer could be related to viral infections that have a tropism for lymphoid tissues, but none of the options directly point to the most likely cause based on the scenario described.

question:
A 25-year-old zookeeper presents to the office complaining of a dry cough, fever, and chills for the past month. He states that the symptoms come in episodes at the end of the workday and last a few hours. He also mentions that he is fatigued all the time. His job includes taking care of various types of birds. He is otherwise fine and denies recent travel or trauma. Medical history is unremarkable and he does not take any medications. He does not smoke cigarettes or drinks alcohol. Allergies include peanuts, dust, and pollen. Childhood asthma runs in the family. Chest X-ray reveals diffuse haziness in both lower lung fields. A PPD skin test is negative. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
A) Thoracocentesis
B) Inhaled beclomethasone
C) Avoid exposure to birds
D) Isoniazid for 6 months
E) Reassurance
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>25-year-old zookeeper</fact1> presents to the office complaining of a <fact2>dry cough, fever, and chills</fact2> for the past month. He states that the symptoms come in <fact3>episodes at the end of the workday</fact3> and last a few hours. He also mentions that he is <fact4>fatigued all the time</fact4>. His job includes <fact5>taking care of various types of birds</fact5>. He is otherwise fine and denies recent travel or trauma. Medical history is unremarkable and he does not take any medications. He does not smoke cigarettes or drinks alcohol. Allergies include peanuts, dust, and pollen. Childhood asthma runs in the family. Chest X-ray reveals <fact6>diffuse haziness in both lower lung fields</fact6>. A <fact7>PPD skin test is negative</fact7>. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
A) Thoracocentesis
B) Inhaled beclomethasone
C) Avoid exposure to birds
D) Isoniazid for 6 months
E) Reassurance

Answer: 
Considering the <fact1>25-year-old zookeeper's</fact1> symptoms of <fact2>dry cough, fever, and chills</fact2> that occur in <fact3>episodes at the end of the workday</fact3> and his job involving <fact5>taking care of various types of birds</fact5>, it is likely that he has developed an occupational lung disease, specifically bird fancier's lung or hypersensitivity pneumonitis. This condition is caused by an immune system reaction to inhaled antigens from birds. The <fact6>diffuse haziness in both lower lung fields</fact6> on the chest X-ray and negative <fact7>PPD skin test</fact7> further support this diagnosis. The most appropriate treatment would be to avoid further exposure to the causative agent, in this case, birds. Therefore, the answer is {C}.

question:
A 60-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine physical examination. He lives in a group home and takes no medications. During the appointment, he frequently repeats the same information and needs to be reminded why he is at the doctor's office. He says that he is a famous poet and recently had a poem published in a national magazine. His vital signs are within normal limits. He has a constricted affect. Neurological examination shows no focal deficits. On mental status examination, he has no long-term memory deficits and is able to count in serial sevens without error. An MRI of the brain shows atrophy of the anterior thalami and small mamillary bodies. Which of the following is the most likely predisposing factor for this patient's condition?
A) Consumption of undercooked meat
B) Chronic hypertension
C) Intravenous heroin use
D) Alcohol use disorder
E) Spirochete infection
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>60-year-old man</fact1> comes to the physician for a routine physical examination. He lives in a <fact2>group home</fact2> and takes no medications. During the appointment, he frequently repeats the same information and needs to be reminded why he is at the doctor's office. He says that he is a famous poet and recently had a poem published in a national magazine. His vital signs are within normal limits. He has a <fact3>constricted affect</fact3>. Neurological examination shows no focal deficits. On mental status examination, he has no long-term memory deficits and is able to count in serial sevens without error. An MRI of the brain shows <fact4>atrophy of the anterior thalami and small mamillary bodies</fact4>. Which of the following is the most likely predisposing factor for this patient's condition?
A) Consumption of undercooked meat
B) Chronic hypertension
C) Intravenous heroin use
D) Alcohol use disorder
E) Spirochete infection

Answer: 
Considering the patient's presentation, including his <fact3>constricted affect</fact3> and the MRI findings of <fact4>atrophy of the anterior thalami and small mamillary bodies</fact4>, the most likely diagnosis is Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome. This condition is commonly associated with <fact5>chronic alcohol use</fact5>, which can lead to thiamine deficiency. The patient's residence in a <fact2>group home</fact2> may also suggest a history of social or economic challenges that could contribute to alcohol use disorder. Therefore, the most likely predisposing factor for this patient's condition is {D}.

question:
A 9-month-old boy is brought to his pediatrician by his mother for a routine health checkup. The boy was born at 39 weeks gestation via spontaneous vaginal delivery. He is up to date on all vaccines and is meeting all developmental milestones. He was breastfed for the first 3 months and then switched to cow’s milk and about two months ago she started giving him fruits and vegetables. Family history is noncontributory. Today, his heart rate is 120/min, respiratory rate is 40/min, blood pressure is 90/50 mm Hg, and temperature of 37.0°C (98.6°F). On examination, he has a heartbeat with a regular rate and rhythm and his lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. Generally, the boy looks pale. His weight and height fall within the expected range. A complete blood count (CBC) shows the following:
Hemoglobin (Hb): 9.1 g/dL
Mean corpuscular volume (MCV): 65 fL
Total iron binding capacity (TIBC): 550 μg/dL
Serum iron: 45 µg/dL
Serum lead: < 5 µg/dL
What is the best treatment for this patient?
A) Iron supplementation only
B) Proper diet and iron supplementation
C) Multivitamins
D) Proper diet only
E) Lead chelation therapy
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>9-month-old boy</fact1> is brought to his pediatrician by his mother for a routine health checkup. The boy was born at <fact2>39 weeks gestation</fact2> via <fact3>spontaneous vaginal delivery</fact3>. He is up to date on all vaccines and is meeting all developmental milestones. He was <fact4>breastfed for the first 3 months</fact4> and then switched to <fact5>cow’s milk</fact5> and about two months ago she started giving him <fact6>fruits and vegetables</fact6>. Family history is noncontributory. Today, his <fact7>heart rate is 120/min</fact7>, <fact8>respiratory rate is 40/min</fact8>, <fact9>blood pressure is 90/50 mm Hg</fact9>, and <fact10>temperature of 37.0°C (98.6°F)</fact10>. On examination, he has a <fact11>heartbeat with a regular rate and rhythm</fact11> and his <fact12>lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally</fact12>. Generally, the boy looks <fact13>pale</fact13>. His <fact14>weight and height fall within the expected range</fact14>. A complete blood count (CBC) shows the following:
<fact15>Hemoglobin (Hb): 9.1 g/dL</fact15>
<fact16>Mean corpuscular volume (MCV): 65 fL</fact16>
<fact17>Total iron binding capacity (TIBC): 550 μg/dL</fact17>
<fact18>Serum iron: 45 µg/dL</fact18>
<fact19>Serum lead: < 5 µg/dL</fact19>
What is the best treatment for this patient?

Answer: 
Considering the <fact1>9-month-old boy's</fact1> low <fact15>hemoglobin (Hb) of 9.1 g/dL</fact15> and <fact16>mean corpuscular volume (MCV) of 65 fL</fact16>, which is below the normal range, along with an elevated <fact17>total iron binding capacity (TIBC) of 550 μg/dL</fact17> and low <fact18>serum iron of 45 µg/dL</fact18>, it is clear that the boy is suffering from iron deficiency anemia. Additionally, the boy's diet, which recently started to include <fact6>fruits and vegetables</fact6> but still consists of <fact5>cow’s milk</fact5>, may not provide sufficient iron. Given these factors, the best treatment for this patient would be to address the iron deficiency through <fact20>proper diet and iron supplementation</fact20> to ensure adequate iron intake and prevent further complications. Therefore, the answer is {B}.

question:
A prominent male politician has secret homosexual desires. However, rather than engaging in homosexual behavior, he holds rallies against gay rights and regularly criticizes gay people. The politician is displaying which of the following defense mechanisms?
A) Repression
B) Reaction formation
C) Denial
D) Displacement
E) Sublimation
answer:
Reformatted Question: A prominent <fact1>male politician</fact1> has <fact2>secret homosexual desires</fact2>. However, rather than engaging in <fact3>homosexual behavior</fact3>, he holds <fact4>rallies against gay rights</fact4> and regularly <fact5>criticizes gay people</fact5>. The politician is displaying which of the following defense mechanisms?

Answer: B) Reaction formation

Explanation: The politician's behavior is an example of reaction formation, a defense mechanism in which an individual expresses an opposite feeling or attitude to conceal their true feelings. In this case, the politician has <fact2>secret homosexual desires</fact2> but instead of acknowledging or acting on them, he holds <fact4>rallies against gay rights</fact4> and <fact5>criticizes gay people</fact5>, thereby expressing an opposite attitude to his true feelings. This behavior is a classic example of reaction formation, as the politician is attempting to distract from his own desires by outwardly opposing them.

question:
A 67-year-old male is seen by neurology after he was noticed to be speaking strangely by his family. After acute treatment with tissue plasminogen activator (tPA), the patient is able to recover most of his speech. Subsequent neurologic exam finds that the patient is fluent while speaking and is able to comprehend both one and two step instructions. Noticeably the patient remains unable to complete tasks involving verbal repetition. Residual damage to which of the following structures is most likely responsible for this patient's syndrome?
A) Arcuate fasciculus
B) Inferior frontal gyrus
C) Superior temporal gyrus
D) Inferior frontal gyrus + superior temporal gyrus
E) Arcuate fasciculus + inferior frontal gyrus + superior temporal gyrus
answer:
Reformatted Question: A <fact1>67-year-old male</fact1> is seen by neurology after he was noticed to be <fact2>speaking strangely</fact2> by his family. After acute treatment with tissue plasminogen activator (tPA), the patient is able to recover most of his speech. Subsequent neurologic exam finds that the patient is <fact3>fluent while speaking</fact3> and is able to <fact4>comprehend both one and two step instructions</fact4>. Noticeably the patient remains <fact5>unable to complete tasks involving verbal repetition</fact5>. Residual damage to which of the following structures is most likely responsible for this patient's syndrome?

Answer: The patient's symptoms suggest a condition affecting the brain's language processing areas. Given that the patient is <fact3>fluent while speaking</fact3> and able to <fact4>comprehend both one and two step instructions</fact4>, but struggles with <fact5>verbal repetition</fact5>, points towards an issue with the structure responsible for connecting the language comprehension and production areas. The arcuate fasciculus is a bundle of axons that connects the superior temporal gyrus (Wernicke's area) to the inferior frontal gyrus (Broca's area), playing a crucial role in verbal repetition. Therefore, residual damage to the <fact6>arcuate fasciculus</fact6> is most likely responsible for this patient's syndrome.

question:
A 34-year-old woman comes to the physician requesting prenatal care. For the past 2 months, she has had increasing breast tenderness, nausea, 3-kg (6.6-lb) weight gain, and urinary frequency. She is not sure about the date of her last menstrual period. She has been trying to conceive with her husband since she stopped taking oral contraceptives 6 months ago; she was happy to tell him last week that she is pregnant. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg. Physical examination shows mild, nontender abdominal enlargement. The cervical os is closed. Urine β-hCG is negative. Transvaginal ultrasonography shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
A) Delusion of pregnancy
B) Pseudocyesis
C) Pregnancy
D) Incomplete abortion
E) Ectopic pregnancy
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>34-year-old woman</fact1> comes to the physician requesting prenatal care. For the past <fact2>2 months</fact2>, she has had increasing <fact3>breast tenderness</fact3>, <fact4>nausea</fact4>, <fact5>3-kg (6.6-lb) weight gain</fact5>, and <fact6>urinary frequency</fact6>. She is not sure about the date of her last menstrual period. She has been trying to conceive with her husband since she stopped taking oral contraceptives <fact7>6 months ago</fact7>; she was happy to tell him last week that she is pregnant. Her <fact8>temperature is 37.2°C (99°F)</fact8>, <fact9>pulse is 100/min</fact9>, and <fact10>blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg</fact10>. Physical examination shows <fact11>mild, nontender abdominal enlargement</fact11>. The <fact12>cervical os is closed</fact12>. <fact13>Urine β-hCG is negative</fact13>. Transvaginal ultrasonography shows <fact14>no abnormalities</fact14>. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A) Delusion of pregnancy
B) Pseudocyesis
C) Pregnancy
D) Incomplete abortion
E) Ectopic pregnancy

Answer: B) Pseudocyesis

Explanation: The patient's symptoms of <fact3>breast tenderness</fact3>, <fact4>nausea</fact4>, <fact5>weight gain</fact5>, and <fact6>urinary frequency</fact6> for the past <fact2>2 months</fact2> could suggest pregnancy, but the <fact13>negative urine β-hCG</fact13> and <fact14>normal transvaginal ultrasonography</fact14> results contradict this. Additionally, the <fact11>mild, nontender abdominal enlargement</fact11> and <fact12>closed cervical os</fact12> do not support the diagnosis of pregnancy or any other obstetric condition. The patient's belief that she is pregnant despite the lack of objective evidence, as indicated by her informing her husband of the pregnancy, suggests a psychological component. Therefore, pseudocyesis, also known as false pregnancy or phantom pregnancy, is the most likely diagnosis.

question:
A 45-year-old man presents to the physician because of a 1-day history of progressive pain and blurry vision in his right eye. He is struggling to open this eye because of the pain. His left eye is asymptomatic. He wears contact lenses. He has bronchial asthma treated with inhaled salbutamol. He works as a kindergarten teacher. The vital signs include: temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse 85/min, and blood pressure 135/75 mm Hg. The examination shows a visual acuity in the left eye of 20/25 and the ability to count fingers at 3 feet in the right eye. A photograph of the right eye is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
A) Angle-closure glaucoma
B) Epidemic keratoconjunctivitis
C) Herpes simplex keratitis
D) Herpes zoster keratitis
E) Pseudomonas keratitis
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>45-year-old man</fact1> presents to the physician because of a <fact2>1-day history of progressive pain and blurry vision in his right eye</fact2>. He is struggling to open this eye because of the pain. His left eye is asymptomatic. He <fact3>wears contact lenses</fact3>. He has <fact4>bronchial asthma treated with inhaled salbutamol</fact4>. He works as a <fact5>kindergarten teacher</fact5>. The vital signs include: <fact6>temperature 37.0°C (98.6°F)</fact6>, <fact7>pulse 85/min</fact7>, and <fact8>blood pressure 135/75 mm Hg</fact8>. The examination shows a <fact9>visual acuity in the left eye of 20/25</fact9> and the ability to count fingers at 3 feet in the right eye. A photograph of the right eye is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
A) Angle-closure glaucoma
B) Epidemic keratoconjunctivitis
C) Herpes simplex keratitis
D) Herpes zoster keratitis
E) Pseudomonas keratitis

Answer: Considering the <fact1>45-year-old man's</fact1> symptoms of <fact2>progressive pain and blurry vision in his right eye</fact2> and his history of <fact3>wearing contact lenses</fact3>, the most likely diagnosis is {E}. This is because contact lens wear is a known risk factor for Pseudomonas keratitis, an infection that can cause pain, blurry vision, and potentially severe complications if not treated promptly.

question:
A 12-year-old girl is brought to your psychiatry office by her parents, who are concerned that she has not made any friends since starting middle school last year. The girl tells you that she gets nervous around other children, as she cannot tell what they are feeling, when they are joking, or what she has in common with them. Her teachers describe her as “easily distracted” and “easily upset by change.” When asked about her hobbies and interests, she states that “marine biology” is her only interest and gives you a 15-minute unsolicited explanation of how to identify different penguin species. Mental status exam is notable for intense eye contact, flat affect, and concrete thought process. Which of the following is true regarding this child’s disorder?
A) Boys are more commonly affected than girls
B) Impaired attention is a key feature of the disorder
C) Intellectual disability is a key feature of the disorder
D) It is usually associated with a family history of schizophrenia
E) Typical age of onset is 3-5 years of age
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>12-year-old girl</fact1> is brought to your psychiatry office by her parents, who are concerned that she has not made any friends since starting middle school last year. The girl tells you that she gets nervous around other children, as she cannot tell what they are feeling, when they are joking, or what she has in common with them. Her teachers describe her as “<fact2>easily distracted</fact2>” and “<fact3>easily upset by change</fact3>.” When asked about her hobbies and interests, she states that “<fact4>marine biology</fact4>” is her only interest and gives you a <fact5>15-minute unsolicited explanation</fact5> of how to identify different penguin species. Mental status exam is notable for <fact6>intense eye contact</fact6>, <fact7>flat affect</fact7>, and <fact8>concrete thought process</fact8>. Which of the following is true regarding this child’s disorder?

Answer: 
Considering the <fact1>12-year-old girl's</fact1> difficulties with social interactions, such as not making friends and getting nervous around other children, along with her restricted interests in <fact4>marine biology</fact4> and her detailed, <fact5>15-minute unsolicited explanation</fact5> of penguin species, it suggests a diagnosis of Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD). Additionally, her <fact2>easily distracted</fact2> nature and being <fact3>easily upset by change</fact3> are also consistent with ASD. Furthermore, the mental status exam findings of <fact6>intense eye contact</fact6>, <fact7>flat affect</fact7>, and <fact8>concrete thought process</fact8> are also characteristic of ASD. Among the options provided, it is known that boys are more commonly affected than girls with ASD. Therefore, the correct answer is {A}.

question:
A 51-year-old Caucasian woman presents to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She had a Colles' fracture 2 years ago. The rest of her past medical history is unremarkable. She has a sedentary lifestyle. She has been smoking 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. She drinks alcohol moderately. Her mother had a fracture of the wrist when she was in her late 60s. The physical examination shows no abnormal findings. Dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (DEXA scan) shows a T-score of -3.2 standard deviations (SDs) in the hip. The patient is educated regarding her risk of falls. Exercise regimen and smoking cessation assistance are provided. Appropriate diet is indicated, as well as supplements with calcium and vitamin D. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in pharmacotherapy?
A) Alendronate
B) Calcitonin
C) Estrogen
D) Tamoxifen
E) No pharmacotherapy at this time
answer:
Reformatted Question: 
A <fact1>51-year-old Caucasian woman</fact1> presents to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. She had a <fact2>Colles' fracture 2 years ago</fact2>. The rest of her past medical history is unremarkable. She has a <fact3>sedentary lifestyle</fact3>. She has been <fact4>smoking 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years</fact4>.
